IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This application is for support of three training positions in an established program in digestive diseases that has been funded since 1975 at the Division of Gastroenterology, University of California, San Francisco. The Program’s goal is preparing trainees for careers in academic luminal gastroenterology, and its track record in this regard is outstanding, with numerous graduates of the program now in leadership positions. These talented individuals are well poised to capitalize on the exciting state of GI related research, with its transformative and translational potential.

PROJECT_TITLE: INRSA Training Grant in Gastroenterology

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substantial variation in radiologist rates of recommendations for additional imaging and in referring provider agreement appears to lead to disparities in care and diagnostic error. If effective, this study will serve as a model for the development and audited implementation of best practices that reduce variation, diagnostic error, and disparities in medical imaging care. Our approach could be implemented in any setting using our best practices, other groups’ best practices, or national society guidelines.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Addressing Variability and Inequities via Systematic Evidence-based Recommendations (AdVISER) for Head and Neck Imaging
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research is one of the first steps to understanding how and when self-injurious thoughts and behaviors (STBs) emerge in young children during middle childhood. Findings will help identify potential risk factors and mechanisms that may serve as targets for preventing STBs earlier in development before the adolescent period. Findings will set the stage for future research studies aimed at carefully understanding developmental pathways toward STB risk from childhood through adolescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: Alzheimer´s disease (AD) disproportionately impacts Hispanics/Latinos residing in the US, but the reasons are unknown. The physical and social features of living environments – the neighborhood or el barrio for Mexican Americans – likely influence the relationship between the aging process and individuals' cognitive trajectories but dissecting such contextual versus individual effects upon risk of Alzheimer´s disease (AD) is a complex problem. To overcome this knowledge gap, this project aims to determine the effects of neighborhood on AD-like cognitive trajectories in Mexican Americans, by a novel approach that integrates 1) individual differences revealed by high-dimensional -omics data and 2) mediation by family and el barrio dynamics; together yielding new evidence to assist neighborhood and city planners and policymakers to improve outcomes in this fastest-growing elderly population in the U.S.

PROJECT_TITLE: Integration of Socio-Spatial Data for Neighborhoods with Multi-omic profiles to Identify and Mitigate Factors Affecting Risk of ALzheimer's Disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The long-term vision of this LEADR proposal is to erase racial disparities in Alzheimer’s disease/Alzheimer’s disease related dementias (AD/ADRD) prevalence and burden. In this project, we will 1) develop a measure of structural discrimination and resilience, 2) use it to predict outcomes in AD/ADRD and 3) develop interventions to decrease prevalence and increase resilience. This program of work will move beyond individual and family interventions to address the structural determinants of AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement In this project, it is proposed that an important class of proteins exists universally in all organisms, that prevents damage to molecules, and that, in humans, these proteins constitute natural cancer- and neurodegenerative disease-prevention proteins. These protection proteins and their genes were not hypothesized or identified previously, in part because of inadequate genetic methods for finding and understanding them. The project includes—use of new methods capable of finding and defining the functions of these proteins; the development of new technology for increasing production of any specific natural protein to act as a drug for prevention of cancer and other age-related maladies; and creation of a simple blood-pressure- like general technology for pre-disease and early diagnosis of individuals who need these protection-protein therapies, at risk for cancer, neurodegenerative, Alzheimer, and many other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Down syndrome (DS) is the most common genetic form of intellectual disability and is associated with an increased risk for many adverse health outcomes, including structural heart defects, sleep apnea, thyroid abnormalities, hearing and vision problems, and early-onset dementia. NIH’s INvestigation of Co-occurring conditions across the Lifespan to Understand Down syndromE (INCLUDE) Project is funding a broad effort to collect data from a large group of people with DS across a range of ages and backgrounds to help researchers understand why individuals with DS are more likely to have these conditions, which will help guide treatments and interventions to improve their health and well-being. The INCLUDE Clinical Cohort Coordinating Center will play an important role in this effort by working with cohort collection sites to capture data from a wide range of health conditions and make sure these data are submitted to the INCLUDE Data Coordinating Center, where it will be accessible for researchers.

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will investigate the ethical question of how user perceptions, technology acceptance, and health effects of wearable robotics technologies, such as back-support exoskeletons, differ across sex and race. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Noninvasive imaging tests, including computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and nuclear medicine are performed millions of times every year in the United State. An estimated 20-30% of these tests do not benefit the patient and are considered inappropriate. Most of these tests involve radiation, which is imparts a small risk of future cancer. Inappropriate tests may delay or limit access to patients with appropriate indications for testing. Reducing inappropriate testing could reduce costs and make funds available for other Veteran services. In this award, we propose a series of investigations to better understand why inappropriate tests are ordered, what the cost is to the VA system, and implement a system to reduce inappropriate tests. Veterans will directly benefit from this research through reduction in wait times and avoiding harm from radiation; indirectly the VA health system will benefit from cost avoidance.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a major cause of disability in the Veteran population, often resulting in chronic pain and sleep disturbances, among other sequela. Extensive rehabilitative efforts are usually required and often prevent return to the workforce and community. Disturbed sleep and excessive daytime sleepiness are among the most pervasive and enduring sequelae after TBI, which we hypothesize is a significant contributor to these functional impairments and an impediment toward rehabilitation. Thus, our research aims to enhance sleep quality as a means to reduce pain and improve quality of life and functional outcome measures in Veterans with TBI. We predict that the proposed intervention, morning bright light therapy, if found effective, will be cost-effective, rapidly deployable, and highly accepted by Veterans with TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative: Magnetic resonance-guided focused ultrasound (MRgFUS) is a promising non-invasive treatment modality being investigated for various disorders. For these treatments to be safe and effective, the acoustic energy must be precisely delivered to the affected tissues. This project aims to improve the accuracy of transcranial acoustic modeling, which will enable better-individualized treatments. The results could remove a significant technical limitation, extending the current therapeutic ultrasound applications of mechanical and thermal ablation and paving the way for novel applications, such as blood-brain barrier opening and neuromodulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Understanding diapause and its ability to suspend and preserve life Project Narrative As a natural form of “suspended animation”, diapause is a dormant state which can suspend embryonic development and preserve life for an extended time without compromising following health and life. However, our knowledge of how diapause works, especially in a more complex vertebrate system, remains limited. Here we study diapause through two complementary angles – signaling pathways and functioning mechanisms – using a naturally short-lived African killifish for its remarkable ability for staying in diapause to survive the drought for up to years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Globally, the population aged 65 and above is growing faster than all other age groups posing a significant problem to the healthcare system, the exponential increase of many age-related diseases; one such disease is cancer, whose risk of incidence increases 11-fold as one gets old. Despite this, and contrary to other age-related diseases such as Alzheimer’s or diabetes, cancer research currently has virtually no framework that factors in the aging process. Here, I propose a new conceptual framework to precisely map how the aging process imparts into cancer progression and to identify novel therapeutic strategies for older cancer patients that factors in the reprogramming that occur with aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While lifespan has greatly expanded for people with Down syndrome (DS) in the last seventy years, the population still experiences burdensome morbidities and premature mortality. This project contributes to public health knowledge by developing the Down Syndrome: Towards Optimal Trajectories and Health Equity using Medicaid Analytic eXtract Project (DS-TO-THE-MAX), a 10-year retrospective cohort of >100,000 adults with and >4,000,000 adults without DS enrolled in Medicaid, a US public health insurance program for low income and / or disabled people. With these data, we will describe epidemiology, identify risks and social determinants, and use machine learning to identify factors that may predict occurrence or resilience of obstructive sleep apnea, dementia, and mortality in a diverse sample orders of magnitude larger than previous DS studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative: Down syndrome (DS), caused by triplication of human chromosome 21, is the single most common risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and people with DS typically develop early-onset AD and dementia by their 60s. Here, we propose to employ a novel human microglial chimeric mouse brain model that is created by transplantation of human DS induced pluripotent stem cell-derived microglia to study the role of human microglia in AD/DS in vivo. Results from this study will help us better understand the mechanisms underlying the AD in DS and may steer AD therapeutic interventions into a new direction of aiming at preventing microglial senescence or rejuvenating microglia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Memories are highly dependent upon the context in which they are embedded, yet neurocognitive models of human sleep consolidation downplay the role of context and focus instead on the reactivation (or “replay”) of individual, isolated memory traces. This proposal will disentangle the roles of individual memories and generalized contexts in sleep-related reactivation using functional MRI, EEG and behavioral methods for sleep manipulation, thereby creating a unified framework linking the context-memory literature, the nonhuman replay literature, and the human reactivation literature. The possibility of reinstating context during sleep will be exploited to weaken memories reactivated in a suppression context, providing evidence for the translational nature of the developed framework and possibly paving the way toward non-invasive memory-altering interventions for healthy and clinical populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because the identification of feasible, brief, and cost- effective interventions to decrease depression symptoms in adolescents with overweight/obesity offers the prospect of decreasing insulin resistance, and consequently, mitigating the risk of developing type 2 diabetes (T2D). Adolescents from historically disadvantaged racial/ethnic and socioeconomic backgrounds disproportionately face major stressful life events and psychosocial adversity, develop depression, and experience a high prevalence of obesity and earlier-life onset of T2D. By systematically studying the usefulness of a mindfulness-based intervention to decrease depression, and ultimately, to decrease insulin resistance in adolescents at-risk for T2D, the proposed research is highly consistent with NCCIH's mission to apply rigorous scientific methods to the identification of complementary and integrative health interventions and their roles in improving health and healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) the repeated cycles of muscle damage and repair lead to stem cell dysfunction but current therapies do not target muscle stem cells. The studies proposed here will assess the importance of telomere biology in the progression of muscular dystrophy, using new genetic mouse models that target the stem cell compartment. Our research is aiming to investigate the molecular mechanism of telomere dysfunction in skeletal muscle dystrophy.

PHR: Project Narrative Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) is a genetically inherited disease that affects 100,000 Americans and millions world- wide. Acute chest syndrome (ACS) is a type of lung injury and one of the leading causes of hospitalization among SCD patients; however, there is no available treatment to prevent ACS. We propose to identify new molecular targets that can be blocked therapeutically to prevent ACS in SCD patients.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative: Reducing variance in psychiatric diagnostic practice is one step toward diagnostic accuracy, because without consistency (i.e. precision in statistical terms), accuracy cannot be achieved. We propose to reduce diagnostic variance for mental health and thereby improve patient safety at two health system partners and in a national sample of physicians. We will reduce diagnostic variance by measuring between-provider differences in diagnostic practice with a mixed-method research design, quantifying between-provider agreement and agreement of providers with published diagnostic systems, and providing direct feedback to partners about their own levels of diagnostic agreement and variance.

PROJECT_TITLE: Reducing Variance in Diagnosis of Mental Disorders to Improve Patient Safety

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is a genetic disorder that predisposes affected individuals to tumors of the nervous system, and other disease manifestations. To identify how tumors form we are using mouse models and modern methodologies to study tumour-immune interactions. These state-of-the art interdisciplinary approaches allow us to study the role of NF1, early stages of tumorigenesis and to identify points for tumour prevention and therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Research Narrative Tuberculosis (TB) remains a major health problem in the world. While TB is primarily a disease of the lungs, extrapulmonary TB is common in children and immunocompromised individuals. We propose combining mathe- matical modeling and experiments to gain insights into mechanisms of Mtb dissemination using a novel system of infection of mice with an ultra low dose (1-3) of bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Artificial intelligence-driven robot-assisted surgery raises new ethical concerns relating to changes to surgeons’ professional autonomy, informed consent, confidentiality/privacy, and the surgeon-patient relationship. This study aims to examine ethical issues of informed consent and assess patient decision making for autonomous robot-assisted surgery. The impact of the proposed study will be to facilitate the adoption of innovative surgical techniques by better understanding ethical issues regarding autonomous robot-assisted surgery and guiding surgeon-patient communication so that the surgeon-patient relationship remains human-centered.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This INBRE administrative supplement pairs an INBRE and COBRE project leader for collaborative research to enhance their productivity and improve the environment for PUI undergraduate student research experiences. The project is relevant to the NIH and public health because it develops a novel insect model to study microbial pathogenesis that mimics the microbial content and physiological conditions of the human vaginal tract. It will lay the foundations for developing future therapies for vaginal infections by understanding the interactions that occur between pathogens and the microbiome.

PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE The Alaska Institutional Development Award (IDeA) IDeA Networks of Biomedical Research Excellence (INBRE) program invests in growing and enhancing the capacity of biomedical and behavioral health researchers to improve the health and well-being of Alaska and the nation. It also supports increasing and diversifying the pipeline of students seeking careers in biomedical research in Alaska. Through its One Health research theme and focus on health disparities in Alaska Native people, it emphasizes the importance of recognizing interconnections among the health of people, animals, and the environment to sustain healthy communities during a time of rapid change in the northern-most state.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) are the only output neurons which relay visual signals from the eyes to the brain. RGC death is a crucial element in many retinal diseases leading to blindness in veterans, such as glaucoma and traumatic optic neuropathy (TON). Because loss of RGCs will result in irreversible loss of vision and no effective treatment is currently available, effectively minimizing or preventing RGCs death and preserving vision are significant challenges faced by the VA healthcare system. This study will conduct proof-of-principle studies to establish the role of MHCI-TCR as a critical mediator of RGC death in retinal diseases, validate the efficacy of MHCI-TCR inhibitors on RGC protection, and establish the optimal strategy for using pharmacological agents regulating multiple mechanisms involved in RGC death for neuroprotection. The results of this study could provide valuable insights into the protection of neurons in eye diseases. Therefore, the experiments proposed in this study will have important implications in developing treatment strategies for VA patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Combat exposures such as inhaled sand and dust may lead to increased risk and severity of respiratory diseases including pulmonary fibrosis (PF) among Veterans. In addition, chronic psychological stress related to deployment is associated with chronic inflammation and may contribute to disease severity. Using a model of PF that mimics sand inhalation, combined with a model of chronic unpredictable stress (CUS), a novel circulating fibroblast precursor (CFP) cell was identified that is increased, activated, and promotes inflammation in PF. This study will determine how CUS exacerbates PF and identify CUS-driven mechanisms by which CFPs become activated to promote disease progression toward development of new therapies for PF. These studies are directly applicable to Veterans as they address the impact of chronic stress/mental health on a devastating disease disproportionately affecting our Nation’s Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Cigarette smoking is a significant and modifiable risk factor for many diseases that afflict those in the VA health system. However, as part of the attempt to quit smoking many Veterans are turning to electronic nicotine delivery systems, ENDS, (or 'Vaping'), which delivers nicotine to the lung in unprecedented high amounts and purity (compared to cigarette smoke). We know little about the effects on the lung by ENDS:nicotine (or the chemicals in the carrier solutions) and even less about how they affect recovery of the already damaged lung by prior smoking. The aim of this proposal is to determine how ENDS:nicotine affects normal lung function and measure its influence on recovery from lung damage induced by previous cigarette smoke exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will be the first study to use the theoretical framework of acceptability to create a tool (questionnaire) that assesses the acceptability of health-related social needs (HRSN) screening among Black patients receiving care at NYU Langone Health. With increased emphasis on patient-centered care in recent years in the US, there is growing interest in collecting information on patients’ clinical and social needs, providing unprecedented opportunities to identify socially disadvantaged individuals at increased risk of poor health outcomes. Examining the acceptability of HRSN screening tools will provide comprehensive information on the best approach for improving HRSN screening experiences for minoritized populations, with implications for shaping training of providers and staff in best practices for increasing acceptability, and inform recommendations for universal screening of HRSN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Millions of individuals suffer from skeletal muscle atrophy and contractile dysfunction (i.e. muscle weakness), a hallmark of several physiological and pathological conditions, including sarcopenia and cachexia elicited by cancer. Despite the significance of myopathy on quality of life and healthspan, no pharmacological therapies are currently available to mitigate the loss of muscle mass and function. The experiments in this proposal will test the impact of unacylated ghrelin on skeletal muscle weakness in aging and cancer cachexia. Our research has a high chance of translation based on its excellent safety profiles in humans and no effects on cancer cell growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Many characters of interest in biomedicine evolved long ago and are fixed in a particular species, distinguishing it from unaffected relatives; finding the genes underlying any such ancient trait has been a central challenge in the field. We have developed a method, RH-seq, for genetic dissection of interspecies trait variation, and applied it in invertebrate models. We now propose to study how species-defining alleles confer their effects, alone and together, in a yeast model system, and we propose to port our approaches for interspecies genetics to mouse cells, with a focus on cellular senescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Fostering Ethical Adoption of Artificial Intelligence-Enabled Assistive Robots (AIAR) Grounded in Person-Centered Dementia Care. Our research addresses a crucial gap in dementia care, where the use of AI-assisted robots often overlooks the involvement of people living with dementia (PLWD) in the decision-making processes about their care. This can lead to a sense of dehumanization and a violation of personal autonomy. Our project aims to revolutionize this approach by developing the first intervention protocol that centers on person-centered engagement of PLWD in continuous decision-making, transitioning from a solely efficiency-driven use of technology to the ethical adoption that enhances the well-being and autonomy of PLWD and their care partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This project narrative is for the parent award (R01 HL165251) and does not include information related to the proposed diversity supplement activities. PROJECT NARRATIVE. Leakage of the tricuspid valve, which is located between the right atrium and right ventricle, is extremely common and, if not treated, can significantly impact the health of patients. The current gold-standard for treatment is a surgical approach known as tricuspid annuloplasty, which unfortunately does not have high long-term success rates and fails in approximately one third of patients. This proposal is relevant to public health as we aim to better understand a new tricuspid valve disease mechanism, tricuspid valve maladaptation, that could be used as future therapeutic target toward improving the currently poor outcomes for patients with tricuspid valve regurgitation.

PHR: Project Narrative: Trauma and bacterial infections often necessitate extirpation of dental pulp. Regenerating the soft vascularized tissue in the canal is a major unmet clinical goal. We’ll develop a peptide hydrogel formulation that promotes vascularized soft tissue after pulpectomy, with low risk of bacterial colonization.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The Reproductive Scientist Development Program (RSDP) plan for career development serves as a model for postgraduate medical education and assures that some of the most promising young physician- investigators in the country will remain in academic investigative obstetrics and gynecology. Despite an urgent need for research in gynecologic oncology, less than 1 in 5 of the 114 RSDP trainees to date have represented that subspecialty. This supplement grant seeks a new funding source specifically directed to attracting, training and retaining gynecologic oncologists as career physician scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies in animal models and humans support the notion that disease-causing mutations for frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) may play critical roles in neurodevelopment. By studying children carrying mutations causing FTD or AD, this proposal will characterize and identify how early disease- specific neural circuit differences arise. These findings will reveal important insights into the underlying biology of these diseases and will determine how early biomarker trajectories in genetic FTD and AD diverge from trajectories in noncarriers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The parent grant aims to use two different imaging modalities to identify spatial changes in metabolites and proteins during the progression of Alzheimer's disease. In this supplement, we will focus on changes associated with astrocytes by comparing the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex to the primary visual cortex, to determine the changes in location, morphology, cell state, and cell interactions that contribute to regional neuronal vulnerability in Alzheimer's disease. Outcomes from this study will provide insights into the astrocytic mechanisms contributing to neurodegeneration and reveal targets that could be protective in Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Gut microbiota are important in the regulation of intestinal homeostasis and the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease, a chronic intestinal inflammation. However, it is unclear how this occurs. We will investigate whether a cellular protein, STING, which senses gut bacterial products, promotes T cell production of IL-10, an anti-inflammatory molecule, leading to the preservation of intestinal immune homeostasis and the inhibition of inflammatory bowel disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Few young children meet the recently adopted World Health Organization recommendations for movement  behaviors (physical activity, sleep, and screen-time), known as the 24-Hour Movement Guidelines, putting  children at risk for more behavioral problems, poor cognitive development, delayed motor skills, and obesity.  This study will advance current literature by addressing all three behaviors together and within the setting  where all three behaviors occur, the home. This pilot study will evaluate the feasibility and preliminary  effectiveness of a theoretically grounded and home-based mHealth intervention to improve adherence to the  24-Hour Movement Guideline, and ultimately child mental and physical health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The craniofacial skeleton is composed of diverse tissue types and their precise integration during development is necessary for normal structure and function. We propose to use mouse and human genetics to reveal the mechanisms that coordinate development, assembly, and maintenance of the craniofacial skeleton as multi-tissue system. Our overall goal is to reveal new insights into the etiology of congenital craniofacial disorders and harness this knowledge for therapeutic innovations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in basement membrane-associated genes cause amelogenesis imperfecta in humans. I will use mouse models to study an ameloblast-specific mineral ribbon attachment/elongation complex that is composed of these basement membrane-associated components. The completion of this proposal will advance our understanding of enamel formation, shed light on the therapeutic interventions of amelogenesis imperfecta, and provide insights for enamel biomimetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Dysregulation of molecular clock function in the placenta is a novel mechanism causing poor pregnancy outcomes, leading to lifelong health consequences for the newborn. This transdisciplinary project proposes a new, high impact virtual consortium that will advance fundamental knowledge into chemically-induced dysregulation of the molecular clock in the placenta. This work will transform our understanding of pregnancy disorders stemming from environmental exposures and set the basis for targeting preventive approaches related to the molecular clock.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because misdiagnosis is prevalent in younger women with dense breast tissue receiving breast cancer screening, which causes missed cancers, needless follow up testing, anxiety, and increased medical costs. We seek to be the first to characterize an innovative imaging agent by complementary MRI and optical imaging within a micro-device that mimics the environment of breast cancer. This new MRI contrast agent is expected to expedite, simplify, and enhance the accuracy of breast cancer diagnosis in the clinic to improve patient outcome and reduce wasted medical dollars.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplants (HSCT) are used to treat lymphoid malignancies, metabolic disorders and anemias / thalassemia. Ocular GVHD (oGVHD) with dry eye and ocular discomfort significantly reduces quality of life and occurs in more than 60% of patients that receive an aHSCT. In this proposal, we will use unique pre-clinical models to understand why the eye is a target tissue in GVHD and develop new translational targeted immunotherapies to locally prevent and treat oGVHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Delivery of broadly neutralizing antibodies against HIV at the time of antiretroviral therapy initiation can enable immune-mediated control of HIV infection in some people living with HIV after therapy is stopped. Here we will perform mechanistic and discovery based strategies to understand how this therapeutic strategy affects the long-lived HIV reservoir and improves HIV-specific immune responses in some individuals but not others. Understanding how infected cells survive and persist within the body will allow targeted development of HIV cure strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative The overall vision is to establish a craniofacial bone disease program focusing on skeletal stem cell plasticity as a central mechanism of craniofacial bone formation in intramembranous and endochondral pathways. This proposal aims to develop a research program addressing fundamental mechanisms of craniofacial bone diseases from the perspective of skeletal stem cells and their lineage plasticity. The research program is expected to establish skeletal stem cell dysregulation as a fundamental tenet of craniofacial bone diseases, which will serve as a critical therapeutic target of clinically prevalent conditions in autotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Narrative Commercial fishermen in Georgia and surrounding states work long hours in challenging conditions, leading to greater risk for and prevalence of injury and mortality relative to other types of occupations. The proposed program will systematically adapt and refine an existing fishermen first aid and safety course, and then implement that course for fishermen along the Georgia coast. Using a community-engagement approach we aim to reduce injury among fishermen, increase the number of instructors certified to provide safety training, and improve quality of life for the fishing community.

PROJECT_TITLE: Translating the Fisherman First Aid and Safety Training (FFAST) for Commercial Fishermen in the Southeastern United States

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This diversity supplement aims to build evidence on how an intervention to improve housing stability affects child mental health among those whose parents have been incarcerated. We will embed a qualitative study and a cohort study to explore the mental health of youth and their parents within an ongoing hybrid type 1 effectiveness/implementation study of an intervention that provides comprehensive financial education and financial support for housing in the form of rental assistance, down payment assistance, and low-interest home loans among family members of incarcerated people. This supplement will provide Dr. Destiny Tolliver with necessary skills to build an independent research career in the field of child mental health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Drexel FIRST initiative (Catalyzing Systemic Change at Drexel University to Support Diverse Faculty in Health Disparities Research) will create a collaborative structure involving University leaders, academic units and faculty to catalyze sustainable institutional change that supports scientific and inclusive excellence in the conduct of health disparities research. We will recruit 10 diverse early career scientists, support their career development, create sustainable institutional changes necessary to promote inclusive excellence broadly, and evaluate the outcomes of the program at multiple levels including scientific impact.

PHR: Project narrative Given the complexity and multimodal nature of the input to the child, learning language should be a challenging task, but most young infants proceed in achieving language competence with enormous speed. We hypothesize that the alignment and use of multimodal cues, including touch, in the input may play a key role in this achievement and explore this hypothesis in a series of experiments. The primary translational signiﬁcance of this work is the potential to provide insights into language learning mechanisms, which ultimately could impact treatment protocols and interventions or parent-training programs with high-risk infants consistent with the mission of NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Squamous cell cancer of the anus (SCCA) is increasingly common among the aging population of people living with HIV and recent, key studies have shown that immediate, early treatment of anal precancer after anoscopic screening and surveillance prevents invasive cancer. Unfortunately, current high resolution anoscopy (HRA) screening exams are limited by poor accuracy particularly with less experienced clinicians, inefficiency (separate patient visits for diagnosis and treatment), and patient discomfort (due to multiple false-positive biopsies). There is a great need for novel, culturally acceptable, community-based technologies that improve the accuracy and impact of HRA exams in low resource and community-based settings worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences) The HPTN 084 OLE allows for participants to discontinue contraception and if becoming pregnant to continue active dosing with CAB LA throughout pregnancy and breastfeeding. The HPTN 084 pregnancy substudy will provide important information for prevention of HIV in women during their years of reproductive potential, when they are often most vulnerable to HIV. In addition, the pregnancy substudy will provide valuable information about the safety and pharmacokinetics of CAB LA for pregnant and lactating people and their infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The public health significance of GAPcare II is immense as it proposes a multidisciplinary care coordination program that addresses the Healthy People 2020 goals of preventing and reducing injuries and enhancing life independence among older adults. This project is directly responsive to NIA’s “Strategic Directions for Research on Aging”, section B5: Identify, analyze, and track changing patterns of disability and mortality for older adults and better understand factors contributing to these patterns. Dr. Goldberg’s technology-assisted fall prevention intervention could provide a model of care to reduce subsequent falls in high-risk emergency department seniors and supports the further training of Dr. Goldberg to become a leader in geriatric emergency care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Diversity supplement narrative In order to grow a diverse workforce to help grow the biotech sector, we are helping to develop a Jamaican immigrant and now US citizen who has benn a vital part of our development of a novel way to create microfluidics using an automated lab process. Microfluidics (MF) are the test tubes of the digital age and play a vital role in drug discovery, biotechnology, lab- and organs-on-a-chip, personalized point-of-care diagnostics and treatment, disease research, and more. Phase, Inc. is developing a new 3D printing technology to create PDMS microfluidics that believe will fundamentally change the way PDMS microfluidics are fabricated and unlock the design freedom of additive manufacturing for the MF community, which will lead to significant advancements of in vitro MF models. This new 3D printing technology will allow researchers to quickly design and create microfluidic devices in a matter of hours – as opposed the weeks it now takes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It remains largely unclear which genetic factors underlie well-established sex differences in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). This proposal will fill in this gap by using a series of state-of-the-art innovative approaches to discover sex- specific genetic risk variants for AD, including performing the largest sex-stratified genome-wide association study of AD to date, studying for the first time the role of X-chromosome and sex-specific rare variant effects on AD, and using rich proteomics data to discover new AD risk genes. Findings from this work will help gain important insights into the pathophysiology of AD, identify novel sex-specific risk factors relevant to personalized genetic medicine, and uncover potential new AD drug targets that may more optimally benefit both sexes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The outreach goal of the proposed research project is to develop a new combination of targeted drug delivery and immunotherapy for the treatment of advanced pancreatic cancer. Our innovative designs of tumor penetrating and immune modulating theranostic nanoparticles, coupled with a novel nanoparticle PD-L1 inhibitor (Nano-iPD-L1), enable efficient delivery of chemotherapy drugs and immunotherapy agents into stroma-rich pancreatic cancer tissues to destroy drug resistant tumor cells, modulate an immunosuppressive microenvironment into a pro-immune environment, and generate strong immune responses. Results of this translational research project have the potential for the development of a targeted and image-guided cancer therapy that significantly enhances therapeutic efficacy, and activates tumor specific immune response, and improves survival of pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Title: NRF transcription factors in Environmental Stress and Disease Intervention PROJECT NARRATIVE  Chronic exposure to arsenic, an environmental contaminant that affects an estimated 160 million people worldwide, is a global public health concern. The goals of this R35 include in-depth mechanistic investigations of arsenic pathogenesis/NRF signaling and the translation of basic mechanistic knowledge into preclinical drug development. Completion of these goals will allow us to fill current gaps, advance environmental health research, and ultimately improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Puerto Rico faces frequent power outages due to the damage caused by natural disasters to its electric grid, which can in turn negatively affect the aging population (≥50 years) who are more likely to have multiple chronic health conditions. Research has demonstrated that access to energy independence through direct access to solar power can have positive health impacts on the population. We propose to explore, from a multilevel perspective, the perceived barriers and facilitators for adopting energy independence as described by individuals, communities, and policy makers, while also documenting resilience related variables that can explain effective chronic disease management among aging populations in need of electricity-based therapeutic treatments (i.e., renal disease, respiratory diseases, diabetes).

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Environmental Health Association (NEHA) project entitled A People-Centered, Technology-Driven, Scientific Approach to Advancing Conformance with the Voluntary National Retail Food Regulatory Program Standards (Retail Program Standards) is intended to:  • Build and implement a Flexible Funding Model system to provide significant subaward  funding to state, local, tribal, and territorial (SLTT) retail food regulatory programs, to  assist them in meeting the requirements of the Retail Program Standards,  • Assess and identify the retail training needs of SLTT agencies, and assist the US Food  and Drug Administration (FDA) in meeting those needs by building and establishing a  Retail Training Pre-Registration System; and  • Work with FDA to build and establish a National Retail Standardization Registry to  better promote and track retail Standardizations nationwide. These three objectives will advance the Integrated Food Safety System (IFSS) requirements found in the Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA) and support the goal of building New Business Models and Retail Standardization in the New Era of Smarter Food Safety.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A People-Centered, Technology-Driven, Scientific Approach to Advancing Conformance with the Voluntary National Retail Food Regulatory Program Standards

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Center for Research and Education in Multiscale Bioengineering, Bioimaging, and Biosensing (REMB3) Public Health Relevance The establishment of the Center for Research and Education in Multiscale Bioengineering, Bioimaging, and Biosensing (REMB3) at Delaware State University will strengthen the institutional research infrastructure necessary for the development of novel imaging and sensing technologies for improving human health. The Center will support investigators from different expertise who will team up to design novel biotechnologies with AI/machine learning capabilities. These biotechnologies will be tested and validated to become, for example, reliable diagnostic tools and treatment approaches of diseases or to create fair predictive tools for detection of early signs of diseases. All will translate into enabling and empowering the clinicians and stakeholders of the healthcare system P

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Studying gene expression signatures (RNA expression) in blood samples provides powerful insight into the molecular mechanistic changes induced by inflammation. Under the parent award, we developed a novel platform that enables at-home blood sampling and RNA stabilization, homeRNA. In this supplement we will conduct surveys and interviews to better understand experiences of U3 women who have used homeRNA in a longitudinal study, ultimately providing guidelines for the design of inclusive clinical studies and for the use of home sampling with telemedicine to increase healthcare access for U3 women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because cell division is a fundamental process of broad importance, yet the mechanisms underlying how cells grow and elongate in highly confining microenvironments for cell division are unclear. Therefore, the proposed research on understanding of the force-based mechanisms of cell division in highly confining microenvironments, via combined experimental and computational approaches, is relevant to part of NIH’s mission that seeks to develop fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burdens of human disability and disease. Ultimately, it is anticipated that this study will uncover new insights and provide a new perspective on cell division, which will contribute to our understanding of processes in development, homeostasis, regeneration, and disease, and will also potentially lead to new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Relevance – Age related cognitive decline creates substantial emotional and financial burden as well as reduced quality of life for patients and their families. Better tools are needed for study of these conditions in preclinical models. Implanted devices generate a chronic inflammatory state caused by vascular perforation and crushing of brain tissue which leads to encapsulation of the implanted device by scar tissue and loss of neural density. This SBIR project develops the Optical Neuroscience Insertion Tool (ONIT) for reduced insertion force and tissue damage during placement of optical imaging systems (fiber optic cannula, GRIN lenses) in preclinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed program addresses a significant gap by developing and implementing a novel model to train undergraduate and graduate students in applying data science methods for addiction research at major universities in Mississippi. The program integrates five components (webinars, summer academies, symposiums, a research lab, and an e-learning platform) innovatively to create a progressive learning pathway with a sustainable mechanism, first targeting campus-wide audiences for raising awareness and fostering interest and then offering students hands-on training and mentored research experiences. This program emphasizes engaging underrepresented students to promote a diverse data science workforce for addiction research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: In our preliminary studies, we have shown promising results to treat Alzheimer’s disease (AD) in animal models by inhibiting complement pathways with humanized recombinant Vaccinia Virus Complement Control Protein (hrVCP). This project will carry out characterizing a large scale of high quality hrVCP in pre-formulation saline solution that will be then tested in AD animal models for validation of our earlier results by an independent CRO laboratory so that we will be able to seek additional funds from governments and private investors pre-clinical and then clinical studies in animals and humans. If successful, it will contribute to an intervention for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will use electronic health record data to assess the prevalence and incidence of diabetes mellitus among children and adolescents, overall and by diabetes type and patient sociodemographic and clinical characteristics. Data will come from PEDSnet, a national pediatric clinical research network that has transformed EHR data to a common data model for over 6.5 million children. The study will address the Healthy People 2020 diabetes-specific objectives by providing new, detailed, and timely information on the pediatric epidemiology of diabetes mellitus in the US.

PROJECT_TITLE: DP20-001 Using EHR Data to Evaluate the Burden of Diabetes Mellitus in a National Network of Children's Hospital Health Systems

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure is the inability of the heart to pump adequately to supply the body with sufficient oxygen to meet its needs, and heart failure is a leading cause of death in the United States, the veteran population included. Of the 50,000 individuals diagnosed with heart failure each year, 70% of these patients have heart failure due to a previous heart attack (myocardial infarction; MI). The main objective of this grant is to use a mouse MI model to understand how one of the white blood cell types, the neutrophil, influences scar formation by regulating the wound healing response, particularly the inflammatory and reparative components.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: We propose a mixed methods study to evaluate the impact of VA-financed community care for Veterans with advanced kidney disease, and to identify subgroups within this population most likely to benefit and most likely to be harmed by receipt of nephrology care in the community. These patients comprise a high-cost high-needs segment of the Veteran population facing a critical health and care transition (onset of end-stage renal disease). The work we here propose is highly relevant to the VA mission (it will directly address three VA HSR&D priority areas), timely (the VA MISSION Act recently received strong bipartisan support in both the House and the Senate), and will directly inform evolving VA policy around the provision of community care for Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired metabolism is known to be strongly associated with a metabolically induced inflammation with an increase in white blood cells called myeloid cells (monocytes/macrophages) in animal models and studies in adults. However, risk for these diseases and inflammatory responses to obesity are not uniform and further identification of who is at risk could potentially prevent disease manifestation. This proposal seeks to evaluate if circulating monocyte gene expression and phenotype can characterize adolescents with obesity with a risk for meta-inflammation and if nutritional fatty acids can modify this risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of behavioral health disorders has climbed steadily among children in the U.S. over the past decade, disproportionately affecting children in lower income and minoritized populations including sexual and gender minorities (SGM). Access to appropriate diagnostic and treatment services can also be particularly challenging for these populations, but Medicaid accountable care organizations (ACOs) have the potential to address gaps in behavioral health care for children in these populations. This supplement enhances our parent study examining the effects of Medicaid ACOs on pediatric BH quality, utilization, outcomes, and disparities by augmenting our analysis of the experience of SGM youth.

PHR: Project Narrative The Oklahoma INBRE (OK-INBRE) program supports biomedical research and allows researchers in Oklahoma to be more competitive for federal research funding that leads to better medical diagnostics and novel therapies to treat human disease. OK-INBRE also enhances the pipeline of undergraduate and graduate students choosing careers in biomedical research to ensure there will be well-trained biomedical scientists in Oklahoma and throughout the country for future generations. The overall goal of the OK-INBRE program is to support faculty research and research mentoring, student participation in research, and enhancement of institutional research infrastructure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Infants and birthing people from communities of color experience the highest rates of mortality and morbidity in the United States due to the interacting effects of systemic racism, further exacerbated among sexual and gender minority (SGM) parents of color by stress due being part of a multiply marginalized community. Whereas popular programs for minoritized populations involve resource-intensive home visits or non- personalized health information materials, we propose extensions of the Rosie the chatbot software that addresses both possible limitations by representing a scalable tool that can have widespread reach across geographies and is personalized and responsive to an individual's specific informational needs. Results from our project can be utilized to inform system-wide and local strategies to reduce health disparities by lower barriers to access to timely and verified health information.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative For some liver cancer patients a liver transplantation represents a cure, yet this procedure involves ischemia reperfusion injury which effects graft function and leads to tumor recurrence. Glycan Therapeutics in collaboration with the University of North Carolina Chapel Hill, will investigate the use of dekaparin to reduce transplant associated ischemia reperfusion injury. The success of this project will offer a way to mitigate a common complication which has no existing therapeutics available.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Using in vivo models of G-CSF and phlebotomy we will define the cellular mechanisms through which different bones differentially responds to stress. We will demonstrate that differences in the cell composition and shape of the microenvironment can profoundly impact how each bone responds to stress. Together this will provide proof of principle for bone-specific manipulations for precise control of hematopoiesis in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug addiction is a disorder of the brain that puts a heavy burden on the society. Studies proposed herein are aimed at developing means for brain circuit selective manipuations with opioid receptor signaling aimed at dissociating analgesic effects of opioid drugs from the development of dependence. It is anticipated that the results will facilitate the design of novel strategies for the treatment of drug addiction addressing a critical need to combat growing opioid abuse epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: We will perform first systematic test of associations between maternal diagnoses around pregnancy and the risk of ASD in offspring. In order to understand whether the observed associations between maternal diagnoses and ASD arise due to genetic or non-genetic mechanisms, we will then analyze family and molecular genetic data available for this large cohort. Our goal is to identify potential novel risk factors for ASD, close important gaps in the knowledge about the etiology of ASD, and elucidate possible pathways to prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Mitochondria are the site of essential cellular processes such as metabolism and apoptosis (controlled cell death), which are often misregulated in cancer and neurodegenerative diseases. Proper mitochondrial function depends on a robust quality control system to remove old, damaged, or mislocalized proteins. Here, I propose experiments to test how mitochondrial protein quality control systems function, which could lead to new therapeutic approaches to cancer and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Youth in the U.S. legal system experience stark behavioral health disparities related to substance use and sexual health compared with peers who have not been arrested, yet they are among those in the country who are least likely to receive effective health promotion services. Low emotion regulation appears to be a common mechanism underpinning these health disparities and it can be improved via mindfulness meditation. This study will leverage strong community partnerships, mobile health (mHealth) technology, and implementation science to test the effectiveness and implementation of a meditation app developed with and for youth on probation to address substance use, sexual health, and emotion regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Streptococcus pneumoniae remains a leading cause of bacterial pneumonia and death due to infectious diseases worldwide despite the use of two approved vaccines targeting the serotypically diverse capsular polysaccharide. The infection rate remains high, especially in older adults, primarily due to infection with serotypes not included in current vaccines, and treatment options can be limited as there has been a rise in antibiotic resistance among non-vaccine serotypes. The research described in this R01 proposal will determine the protective efficacy and underlying structural and mechanistic correlates of protection of human monoclonal antibodies to highly conserved pneumococcal surface proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this administrative supplement is to identify social determinants of health (SDOH) affecting women (conditions in the environments where women are born, live, learn, work, play, and age) and how these intersect with biological sex and genetic variation to impact relationships between dental and systemic disease. We will utilize survey available through the All of Us Program Research Workbench to identify specific SDOH domains that are simultaneously identified with clinical and genetic data as most likely contributing to differences in the frequencies of select dental and systemic diseases. This study represents a major advance in the field and will provide critical information to develop a more comprehensive picture of individual and community-level factors underlying oral and systemic disease relationships affecting women in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Project Narrative We need better tools to predict the future distribution of and year-to-year variation in populations of the blacklegged tick, a key Lyme disease vector. Development of these tools is hampered because blacklegged tick populations are affected by stochastic extreme weather events which are poorly captured in current models. We will address this with a joint empirical-theoretical framework to develop better understanding of tick response to weather variation and extremes and a model structure to accommodate that understanding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Young transgender women (TGW) in Thailand face widespread stigma and discrimination. This discrimination may result from multiple marginalized identities including gender and sexual identity and perception of HIV status. “Intersectional stigma” may be one key barrier to HIV prevention and care (PrEP use, HIV testing). This project will develop and test a technology-delivered program designed to reduce HIV-related stigma and improve the use of HIV prevention services . If successful, the program could help young TGW in Thailand to live healthier lives and reduce risk for HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In Latin America, HIV disproportionately impacts sexual and gender minorities. Recent data from Peru suggests that the prevalence of HIV is as high as 12% among men who have sex with men and 21% among transgender women. We will leverage an ongoing social-behavioral intervention trial enrolling adolescents and young adults living with HIV and strong ties with the LGBTQI+ community in Lima, Peru to explore (1) how sexual identity aligns with prior consensual sexual behavior; (2) perceptions of common terms used to describe sexual and gender identity and differences according to education and socioeconomic status; and (3) reasons that sexual and gender minorities may refuse, withdrawal, or have limited in engagement in study and/or intervention activities. These activities will be critical to tailoring HIV prevention messages and deriving terminology that is intuitive and aligned with the Peruvian population for patient-centered HIV care and research activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Long-term exposure to fine particulate matter (PM2.5) air pollution has been indicated in prior studies to be associated with Alzheimer’s disease onset and progression, but there are few studies that have assessed the association between PM2.5 exposure and Alzheimer’s disease mortality, and even fewer on variations in particle origin or characteristics’ effects on PM2.5 exposure associations with Alzheimer’s disease. Utilizing a robust study design with a well characterized human cohort of over 500,000 participants, this Workplace Diversity Supplement research will evaluate this PM2.5-Alzheimer’s disease associations with a focus on particle size, source, and composition exposure variations, and will also evaluate the potentially modifying effects of diet and health opportunity disparity. The information gained from this study will help direct environmentally focused policies, potentially leading to mitigative approaches for such neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women who have experienced hypertensive disorders in pregnancy are at significantly elevated risk of future cardiovascular disease, but postpartum healthcare visits may not occur and/or may not adequately address this heightened risk. The proposed supplement will enhance our parent grant to examine how clinician factors contribute to cardiovascular risk management in primary care in the postpartum year for women from underserved populations. Findings will contribute to an improved understanding of system factors associated cardiovascular risk management in postpartum primary care for women at high risk, and help to identify interventions, healthcare quality metrics, and policy levers to improve clinical practice particularly for underserved women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work is relevant to public health given the high rates of opioid use disorder and resultant morbidity and mortality among individuals just released from jails. The project is relevant to NIDA's mission- driven strategic goals to improve opioid use disorder treatment among this high-risk population and to optimize clinical and implementation research to improve health and reduce disease. By building strategic partnerships with individuals with a history of incarceration and community and correctional policymakers, we will improve dissemination and implementation of evidence-based research findings into policy and practice.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Sexual harassment is endemic for physicians in medicine, negatively impacting victims and bystanders, and resulting in poor mental health, burnout, isolation, and attrition in the physician workforce. This study will help us understand why and how some institutions have better rates of sexual harassment and physician well- being. By identifying strategies used by top-performing institutions, we will be able to share these “best practices and policies” to improve physician well-being and mitigate the impact of sexual harassment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic stress can result in negative health effects, including inflammation, cardiovascular disease, and Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD); American Indian (AI) populations have endured excess stresses and traumas, but have also shown remarkable psychosocial resilience, which may be related to robust social support, community environment, cultural identity. It is unclear which of these psychosocial features may be most predictive of psychosocial resilience in AI adults, or whether any is protective against neurodegeneration and ADRD. A search on NIH Reporter uncovered many projects focused on cognitive reserve—sometimes also called resilience—but none on psychosocial resilience or its related features as protective health characteristics in adult AIs. This project seeks to fill this knowledge gap with novel data collection and analysis on trait-based psychosocial resilience, related features, cognitive function, and ADRD in 3000 adult AIs as part of the ongoing Strong Heart Study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our collaboration of diverse researchers, clinicians, and community members seeks to better understand the health research needs and priorities of intersex and variations of sex characteristics (I/VSC) communities: Existing models of health information and data collection completely omit I/VSC populations, inaccurately assess I/VSC status, or fragment the population by diagnoses. There is a dearth of literature that explores the social behavioral aspects of the lives of I/VSC people (e.g., alcohol use, depression), and little is known about the disparities of these factors among I/VSC individuals who are also racial/ethnic, sexual, or gender minorities. This supplement study can be a model of community building and healing as we leverage the tenets of participatory action research (PAR), grounding our work in community-based needs and emphasizing collective action, leading to community transformation and social change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The project aims to transform the management of chronic musculoskeletal pain in youth by harnessing wearable technology and advanced analytics. It is predicated on developing a real-time digital biosignature through machine learning algorithms, which will provide an objective, comprehensive assessment of the pain experience beyond self-reporting. This endeavor not only promises to enhance patient outcomes through personalized interventions but also stands to significantly reduce the economic and emotional burden of chronic pain by enabling timely and effective treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Turner syndrome, a condition exclusive to females, occurs when one of the X chromosomes (sex chromosomes) is absent or partially missing, affecting multiple organs. The aim of this administrative supplemental application is to fill a significant gap in tuner syndrome research by addressing how the missing sex chromosome impacts liver health in this unique female population. Knowledge gained from our studies may lay a critical foundation for future translational studies contributing to the well-being of Turner Syndrome patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Monitoring of illicit drug use is a critical component of care in drug treatment facilities and pain clinics, as well as in other situations where patients may be at risk of substance use disorders. This project focuses on improved analytical methodologies to perform this type of testing in point-of-care settings by using a compact capillary liquid chromatograph. The new approaches developed here will provide improvements to current point-of-care screening assays by providing higher specificity, rapid turn-around, and the capability to look at multiple drug classes with a single instrument.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) has no treatment and drug trials are increasingly focused on earlier AD stages, so we need to better understand and detect early AD pathogenesis. This project focuses on Apolipoprotein E (APOE), the strongest genetic risk factor for AD, using cutting-edge technologies to analyze the entire molecule including its glycosylation (sugars attached to the protein), and how this glycosylation affects the still unexplained role of APOE in the disease process at these early stages. We will use stem cells produced from patient skin samples to understand the functional impact of changes to APOE glycosylation seen in aging and AD and determine their effects on critical characteristics of AD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Although declining health of blood vessels in the brain is now thought to contribute to many cases of Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias, there are no treatments that target blood vessel health. Here, we will use gene and protein profiling from brain samples of human AD patients and mouse models to identify putative therapeutic targets. Data will be integrated and analyzed to prioritize candidate genes and proteins that will be tested for their ability to reduce damage to blood vessels in the brain using mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Down Syndrome (DS) is an Alzheimer’s disease related disorder (ADRD) that involves traditional AD neuropathology and cognitive impairment at an accelerated rate. We propose to use well- characterized, biobanked plasma samples from the Vitamin E in DS trial to characterize AD biomarkers and develop a precision medicine approach for use of anti-inflammatories in DS trials. In this proposal we will utilize our expertise in high throughput proteomics and analytics to better characterize our sample set and expand the database for this trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy increase the risk of adverse cardiovascular outcomes after delivery, including repeat hypertensive disorders in a subsequent pregnancy. There is a complex interplay between race, ethnicity, and nativity on hypertensive disorders of pregnancy and pathways leading to adverse cardiovascular outcomes. The proposed project will examine inequities in postpartum cardiovascular outcomes by domains of race, ethnicity, and nativity and elucidate the role of postpartum health-related social needs in a safety-net hospital population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As part of the work conducted in Aims 1 and 2 of the parent R01, which focus on estimating the risk of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRD) associated with wildfire PM2.5 (Aim 1) and identifying individual- and area-level susceptibility factors that exacerbate the association between wildfire PM2.5 and MCI and AD/ADRD (Aim 2), we are modeling daily exposure to wildfire- specific PM2.5 levels using a two-stage machine learning (ML) approach. With this administrative proposal, we plan to establish a new collaboration with AI/ML and data experts at Harvard University with the goals of improving the vast and wide range of data sources, developing reproducible pipelines, annotating, documenting, and processing the data, ensuring computational scalability, encouraging community engagement, and disseminating these important AI/ML ready datasets for the prediction of wildfire PM2.5 to a wider research community. Developing robust and reproducible pipelines to make the data inputs ML/AI ready will allow a more rigorous assessment of exposure and therefore will increase the scientific rigor of the results of the parent grant, as well as allow for the datasets to be disseminated to a wide researcher user base.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Sexual minority women (SMW) are one of the highest-risk groups for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), hazardous drinking (HD), and comorbid PTSD and HD (PTSD-HD) due to psychosocial stressors, including trauma, sexual identity-specific stigma, intersectional stigma, and persistent stress reactivity. Extant research is limited by a lack of studies on the temporal precedence of PTSD in HD development and maintenance, physiological stress reactivity to intersectional stigma and its role in elevating the risk of PTSD-HD, and the development of brief, tailored treatments for PTSD-HD among SMW. The proposed research aims to address these gaps by 1) examining prospective longitudinal associations between PTSD symptom severity and HD over 11 years; 2) assessing the acute effects of intersectional stigma exposure on alcohol craving and state PTSD symptoms through biological mechanisms; and 3) guided by ADAPT-ITT phases 1 and 2, conducting formative interviews with SMW and Community Advisory Board members to adapt an existing cognitive- behavioral therapy module focused on cognitive reappraisal into a single-session intervention to reduce stress reactivity, PTSD symptom severity, and alcohol craving within the context of cue reactivity paradigms in SMW.

PROJECT_TITLE: Testing a Biopsychosocial Model of Violence Exposure, Minority Stressors, and Hazardous Drinking among Sexual Minority Women

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. As economically vulnerable adolescent girls transition into young adulthood, they are at increased risk of HIV infection, disruptions to cognitive development and poor mental health as risk-taking behaviors including sexual risks and substance use become more pronounced. The Suubi4Her-R2 study, building on the efficacious Suubi4Her project, aims to longitudinally assess the impact of economic empowerment and family strengthening interventions on HIV risk behaviors, cognitive and mental health outcomes, and the cognitive mechanisms of change in adolescent girls who previously participated in an economic empowerment and family strengthening program in rural Uganda. Findings from this large longitudinal dataset may contribute to the scientific knowledge on the potential value of investing modest economic resources in poor and vulnerable girls during early adolescence and how these resources may offer long-term protection against known HIV, cognitive and mental health risks, with potential replicability in other low-resource countries.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative Postpartum care and health disparities persist, especially in rural and racially marginalized communities in the Southern United States. Hospitals play an essential role in mitigating adverse maternal outcomes during the postpartum period as over 98% of childbirths occur at the hospital settings; yet, despite the increasingly worse postpartum health, maternal mental health, and perinatal substance use disorders, little is known on how hospital obstetric patient race/ethnicity mix, obstetric workforce care model, capacity, and birth volume would impact these outcomes. We propose to evaluate the effectiveness of these hospital attributes in reducing postpartum health and healthcare disparities in South Carolina to inform equitable and comprehensive intrapartum and postpartum care model at health care systems with hospital services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Through this application, our goal is to join efforts with the larger VCID (vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia) initiative to advance fundamental understanding of how hyperlipidemia and atherosclerosis contribute to impaired brain vessels. We will determine whether correction of hyperlipidemia may delay AD progression or severity. In addition, the efforts put forward have the potential to identify biomarkers of disease progression contributed by components of the brain vasculature.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Misuse of opioid drugs and opioid overdose pose major public health concerns. Existing medications for opioid use disorder (OUD) are inadequate, as evidenced by the high rate of relapse to opioid seeking and opioid- associated deaths. Here, we propose to validate the neuropeptide receptor neurotensin receptor 1 (NTSR1) as a therapeutic target in OUD and to discover small molecule probes for this receptor that may serve as the basis for novel medications for relapse prevention.
