IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative. This project employs wearable biosensors and artificial intelligence to advance understanding and prediction of heavy drinking episodes during initial recovery from alcohol use disorder. It focuses on developing real-time predictive models and identifying neuroclinical and physiological mechanisms that influence recovery dynamics. Integrating high-density sensor data, machine learning, and intensive longitudinal research, the project aims to create personalized, timely interventions for individuals in early recovery stages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antenatal care commonly fails to meet the needs of low-income pregnant individuals, who are at increased risk for adverse pregnancy outcomes due to effects of racism, poverty, and inadequate attention to social determinants of health. Addressing the pervasive disparities in maternal and neonatal health requires innovative, sustainable, and more effective models of antenatal care delivery; one strategy may be patient navigation, a barrier-focused, longitudinal, patient-centered intervention that offers support for a defined set of health services. The Partnering with Antenatal Navigators to Transform Health in Pregnancy (PATH) proposal to evaluate a novel, comprehensive antenatal patient navigation program among low-income pregnant people has the potential to meaningfully improve maternal and neonatal health and reduce disparities in maternal morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The system comprising the bacterium Escherichia coli and its virus, bacteriophage lambda, serves as a simple paradigm for the way gene regulation drives the choice between alternative cellular fates. The outcome of the proposed work will be a predictive, quantitative description of gene regulation and fate choice in the system, at the single-cell level. The conceptual and experimental tools developed in this work will further our understanding of how gene regulation drives cell-fate choices in higher systems, and ultimately, in the context of human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative This mixed-methods study will examine the impact of state-level telehealth policies on perinatal behavioral health outcomes (e.g., emergency department visits, overdoses, and suicide) and maternal-infant outcomes (e.g., maternal morbidity, preterm delivery), overall and among historically marginalized populations. We will use event-time modeling, a quasi-experimental approach, to estimate the relationship between telehealth policies of interest and key outcomes, with a focus on identifying inequities by race/ethnicity, rural residence, and disability status; then apply the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research in a series of in- depth interviews with patients and providers to explain the quantitative findings through an examination of factors that influence telehealth policy implementation and associated health outcomes. Study findings will be immediately actionable for providers, health system leadership, advocates, and policymakers seeking to improve perinatal behavioral health outcomes and address a preventable cause of maternal mortality.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to develop new chemical technologies for efficient preparation of fluorinated molecules, carbonyl compounds, and functionalized carbohydrates. These chemical entities are involved in every aspect of life and can be found in natural products, pharmaceuticals, dyes, pesticides, lubricants, polymers, clothes, and inhaler propellants. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: To decrease the prevalence of preventable blindness due to glaucoma, we need to: 1) screen high-risk populations with increased disease prevalence and decreased access to care and 2) support people who screen positive in accessing appropriate eye care. Federally qualified health centers exist throughout the US to provide care to medically underserved populations – the same populations who are at increased risk of glaucoma. Testing whether telemedicine- enhanced eye disease screening is more effective than usual care in detecting glaucoma at a federally qualified health center will inform best practices for scaling eye care at these health centers and ultimately, mitigating disparities in eye health outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP24-081 Michigan Screening and Intervention for Glaucoma and Eye Health through Telemedicine (MI-SIGHT) Program: A Pragmatic Randomized Trial

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will investigate the role of blood flow abnormalities in glaucoma using novel magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) techniques to study the effects of a novel treatment strategy to increase ocular blood flow on glaucoma progression. These findings could have strong clinical significance and impact by providing new insights into the association of ocular blood flow with glaucomatous damage and by validating a novel therapeutic strategy for glaucoma. These translational MRI and treatment approaches and the knowledge gained could be extended to future human studies, to ultimately prevent visual impairment or blindness from glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance. Riboswitches are metabolite-sensing elements found in the messenger RNAs of many bacterial pathogens. We discovered a very small riboswitch that senses preQ1 using ‘cooperativity’, whereby two identical metabolites are held in close proximity to improve each other’s affinity, which extends the riboswitch’s preQ1-sensing range in cells. This proposal will determine crystal structures of this novel preQ1 riboswitch, develop tools to quantify its cooperative sensing, and probe its function and conformation in live bacteria, thereby elucidating a new gene-regulatory pathway that is relevant to antibacterial discovery.

PHR: Project Narrative Mutation is the source of all evolutionary novelty and diversity shaping both the structure and sequence of genomes. The genomes of individual somatic cells also accumulate mutations throughout the lifetime of organisms impacting cellular functions and contributing to diseases. The goal of the proposed research is to understand at both the cellular and organismal level how cell-type, genotype, selective pressures, and evolutionary histories influence the structure and sequence of the genome.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Breast cancer is currently the most often diagnosed cancer and despite recent advances in treatment, remains the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths among women. Once breast cancer has spread (metastasis) it is especially difficult to treat because targeted agents are usually not available. These cancers are prevalent in men and women Veterans and are particularly aggressive in African- American Veterans diagnosed with breast cancer. Mitochondrial metabolism plays a prominent role in drug resistance and breast cancer progression to metastasis, which is associated with poor clinical outcomes. The proposed study seeks to define the role of and the molecular mechanisms underlying metabolic signaling in breast cancer and the therapeutic potential of a small molecule inhibitor selectively targeting mitochondrial metabolism. Defining how genetic changes in cancer regulate nutritional needs of cells will likely have translational impact and is relevant to the VA health care mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis, the body’s response to a bloodstream infection, is often life-threatening. Timely administration of appropriate antimicrobials is critical for successfully patient outcomes. However, current diagnostics for identifying the infection, necessary for selection of the appropriate antimicrobial, require several days to provide results. The proposed efforts described in this Commercialization Readiness Pilot program proposal will advance the maturity of a novel, fully automated test capable of identifying and characterizing these infections directly from blood in only a few hours. Success in this effort will result in a critically needed diagnostic device, ready for manufacturing scale up as required for FDA trials and market launch.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative To end the HIV epidemic, we need integrated care models that address HIV and PrEP care, and co-existing substance use (SU) disorders that disrupt uptake and consistent use of effective interventions. The overarching goal of this R01 proposal is to conduct a randomized controlled trial to assess the ability of a Collaborative Care Prevention, Treatment, Navigation, Engagement, Resource (PrTNER) intervention to increase initiation of preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP) (for those at-risk for HIV) and decrease viral load (for those living with HIV) among young Black and Latino men who have sex with men (YBLMSM) aged 15 to 24 through engagement in SU treatment. This model moves beyond the individual to consider the broader context in which, substance use and HIV risk are (re)produced.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Organoids are powerful laboratory models of functional organs in the human body. However, their clinical utility is limited because they don’t fully mimic their full-scale counterparts. Here, we seek to address limitations with current methods for growing intestinal organoids in the lab by using engineered biomaterials to characterize and guide growth to build better mini-guts with increased translational potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ST. JOSEPH'S HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synaptic dysfunction is considered an early event during disease manifestation and progression in many dementias, including frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and has been proposed to be associated with microglia dysfunction, including microglia-mediated synaptic pruning. The question remains to whether it is the aberrant proteome of the synapse or the disease-associated microglia dysfunction that triggers early synapse loss. Here we aim to define a disease-associated synaptome via multi- omics analyses of human C9orf72 FTD brain tissue derived cortical synapses and to assess whether an aberrant synaptome triggers aberrant microglia phagocytosis using human C9orf72 FTD patient- derived iPSC neuron-glia cell culture models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE  Many complex disorders of the brain, such as schizophrenia, autism, and depression, can be construed as disorders of brain connectivity. This research aims to bridge the gap between gene expression and connectivity towards elucidating the genetic programming of neural circuit architectures. Decoding the genes that play a role in the formation and maintenance of neuronal networks can provide entry points toward developing therapeutic targets for mental health disorders related to brain connectivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although consumption of marine fish oils appears to be associated with lower cardiovascular risks, the evidence is inconsistent and the mechanisms for their cardioprotective effects remain elusive. Our preliminary findings suggest different component of fish oils (EPA vs DHA) have differential effects on blood clots. Our proposed studies will provide insight into a new paradigm of understanding the puzzling clinical evidence of fish oils and may ultimately lead to the development of more targeted therapies to combat cardiometabolic risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The incidence of acute type B aortic dissection is proportional to the prevalence of uncontrolled hypertension. The results of the IMPROVE-AD trial (including 1100 participants in the US) will provide important clinical guidance on the most appropriate patient-centered ways to reduce mortality and major morbidity by testing two distinct therapeutic strategies. It will also inform decisions regarding racial and gender disparities in patients with uncomplicated type B aortic dissection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic bacterial pathogen that can survive antibiotic treatment even without identifiable antibiotic resistance genes and cause chronic or recurrent infections. The central objective of this project is to understand the mechanisms that P. aeruginosa uses to survive treatment with two different classes of antibiotic and how interactions with another species, S. aureus, affects P. aeruginosa’s phenotypic responses to the drugs. Completion of this research can inspire novel treatment strategies to reduce the burden of P. aeruginosa infections and preserve the effectiveness of existing antimicrobial agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dynamic nature of G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) enables these sensory proteins to recognize and bind a wide range of extracellular molecules with different shapes and chemical properties. We plan to directly visualize the dynamic behavior of GPCRs in real-time using single-molecule fluorescence microscopy, which reveals hidden structural characteristics that should provide new insights into GPCR functions in native-like environments. We initially apply this state-of-the-art microscopy technique to investigate the dynamic behavior of two human GPCRs: an adenosine receptor that regulates inflammation and a glucagon receptor that binds the main metabolic hormone in the human body.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Reference cigar tobacco products are a necessary tool for measuring and reporting harmful and potentially harmful constituents in tobacco products as required under the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act. Three new, machine-made, sheet-wrapped, certified cigar reference products representative of large cigars (processed leaf filler, non-premium), little cigars (brown cigarettes) and small cigars (cigarillos) will be manufactured in one manufacturing run each to ensure product uniformity, and will have certified characteristics to allow for a proficiency testing program, instrument calibration, employee/student training, method validation and for investigational purposes. The University of Kentucky Center for Tobacco Reference Products (CTRP) will expand our program for tobacco analysis and reference tobacco products to support collaborative studies, improved constituent analysis, storage and stability research and the manufacture and distribution of cigar tobacco reference products with significant proposed improvements and development in all of these areas.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Cigar Reference Products Program

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Neurodevelopmental impairment (NI) is a significant sequala in survivors of the neonate disease necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Neuroinflammation is a key factor in the development of NI, and we have developed a novel therapeutic probiotic that protects the intestines from experimental NEC and attenuates the inflammatory responses that can affect long term neurodevelopment. In this project, we take advantage of our novel platform that enables beneficial probiotic activities to be tuned, and thus enhanced, for specific benefits as we aim to identify, prevent, and treat neuroinflammatory responses capable of driving NI related to NEC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will advance knowledge of the pathogenesis of Alport syndrome, a hereditary disease that leads to end stage kidney disease in affected individuals. The disease is caused by mutations in the type IV collagen genes encoding 3, 4 and 5 chains, which reside in the glomerular basement membrane. Although their role in glomeruli is well-studied, the role of these collagen chains in kidney tubules is largely unknown. Here we will examine the contribution(s) of tubular cells to the clinical signs, pathogenesis, and progression of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to develop a novel, cost-effective, and highly flexible therapeutic platform to treat a range of respiratory viruses. We will use an innovative design approach, based on targeting host cell proteases, and test both the therapeutic and prophylactic response and protective response in a mouse and ferret models. Due to the conserved nature of the target, we anticipate that our approach will be applicable to and effective across a wide range of existing and emerging viruses.

PHR: Project Narrative - OADDL Testing Support for CVM Vet-LIRN Oklahoma Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory (OADDL) will offer its expertise and services to participate in critical disease testing and surveillance projects initiated by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), Center for Veterinary Medicine (CVM) Office of Research Veterinary Laboratory Investigation and Response Network (Vet-LIRN). OADDL will provide testing support and expertise in foodborne and other disease investigations, disease surveillance studies, pathogen characterization, and test methods development. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Head and neck cancer patients experience severe pain and stress. The proposed studies investigate how sympathetic and sensory nerves interact to drive cancer pain and promote cancer growth. This approach has the potential for new therapeutic strategies to treat cancer progression and pain by targeting neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The capsids of lentiviruses (family Retroviridae) are involved in multiple, post-entry interactions with host factors, including both host-dependency factors and antiviral (restriction) factors. In this project, we seek to understand the dynamic evolutionary interplay between lentivirus capsids, the major nuclear pore component Nup358, and the capsid-targeting restriction factor TRIM5. To achieve the project goals, we use a comparative approach encompassing the human viruses HIV-1 and HIV-2, and the related simian immunodeficiency viruses of old world primates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: My group develops biosensor tools that enable the visualization of enzymatic processes inside living cells as they move. This is an important area of study in basic biology because it increases understanding about mechanisms that differentiate normal cells (e.g., immune cells) from diseased cells (e.g., tumor cells) as they move and migrate throughout the human body. I will develop molecular imaging tools that enable the simultaneous recording of two different enzymatic protein activities in living cells, which will then allow me to decode the coordination of multiple signaling proteins that regulates cell movement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma is the second leading cause of blindness in the United States, with over half of those with glaucoma unaware that they have it, especially underserved minority populations. We will screen for glaucoma using innovative autonomous AI-grading of retinal photographs already being obtained to identify diabetic eye disease in community clinics serving at-risk populations. The project will track the outcomes of these individuals and compare these to those of individuals undergoing diabetic eye disease screening who are not being screened for glaucoma to determine the costs and benefits of the program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) is common among the elderly as, with age, the liver undergoes substantial changes in function and structure that are associated with impairment of the liver’s normal functioning and operations (e.g., detoxification and metabolic activities). Ample data demonstrate that, in MASLD, impaired lysosomal acidification results in loss of autophagic flux and accumulation of lipid/fatty acids within the liver. We propose novel acid-activated, treatment called LysoGen, with tunable acidification capability, as a treatment for high-fat diet (HFD)-induced MASLD wherein the LysoGen polymer regenerates lysosomal acidity, restores autophagic flux and reverses the functional and histological hallmarks of MASLD.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Excessive burnout and burden are complex and increasing problems affecting nearly all healthcare workers (physicians, nurses, staff) with significant consequences on provider well-being, patient safety, and care qual- ity, especially in primary care and under-resourced community health settings serving challenging patient pop- ulations. While the broad adoption of asynchronous care technology (patient portals, EHR email, text messag- ing) can significantly improve care and patient experience, it also contributes significantly to time stresses, work-after-work, and burnout – further exacerbated by (and contributing to) staff shortages, inefficient pro- cesses, and non-resilient systems. This project integrates systems science, engineering, and health service research methods, as recommended by National Academy of Medicine and US Surgeon General burnout re- ports, to better understand and address the relative impacts, etiology, effective strategies, and dynamics of these interrelated issues on caregiver burnout and patient safety.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Understanding and Addressing Community Health Center Burden, Resiliency, and Burnout - Systems Engineering Analyses and Approaches
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is among the most common chronic diseases worldwide, with prevalence growing in parallel with the obesity epidemic. In order to treat T2D more effectively, it is necessary to more fully understand how metabolic health breaks down in obesity. The work proposed in this application will study how reactivation of the Notch signaling pathway in the liver contributes to insulin resistance, a hallmark of T2D that is a major driver of the difficult-to- control high blood sugars that are characteristic of the disease.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will be the largest population-level study of health characteristics of individuals with fragile X syndrome from diverse racial and ethnic patient groups. This study offers an opportunity to 1) evaluate the rate of underdiagnosis across different racial and ethnic groups and quantify the gap between professional recommendations and clinical practice; 2) characterize lifetime clinical risk associated with this FXS; 3) assess the impact of access to specialty care; 4) develop novel pre-screening approaches that could be used to assist physicians in referring potential patients for FXS testing, which will reduce the duration and associated stress of the “diagnostic odyssey” for patients and families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Natural Killer (NK) cell-mediated antibody dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is correlated with delayed progression of HIV disease, but exactly how antibodies regulate ADCC activity through immune complexes is not well-understood. This project will illuminate how the molecular nature of antibody binding to HIV influences NK cell ADCC activity by utilizing cutting-edge fluorescence microscopy to examine antibody receptors at the synapse between NK cells and their targets. The data from this project will form guiding principles to engineer HIV antibody therapeutics and vaccines aimed at eliciting more potent ADCC activity, with potential long-term applications to other human viruses and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE In 2019, EEEV exhibited an unprecedented outbreak in the United States resulting in 38 confirmed cases and 15 deaths, as opposed to a recent average of 5-8 cases and 1-3 deaths. The outbreak occurred throughout the EEEV-endemic areas of the US (northern tier of eastern states, New England, south eastern seaboard and gulf coast) suggesting a nation-wide increase in virus activity (www.cdc.gov/easternequineencephalitis). Considering the virulence of EEEV, this raises significant concerns regarding the future incidence of EEEV disease, which may be impacted by climate change, mosquito vector and reservoir abundance, and human activity. In contrast with EEEV, Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus (VEEV), a related member of Alphaviruses, causes a much less severe disease in humans and 0.5-1% mortality in symptomatic cases. VEEV is endemic along the gulf coast of the US and also Latin and South America. Reflecting the human virulence of EEEV and potential biowarfare/bioterrorism uses of both viruses, they have been placed on the National Select Agent Registry and the viruses are considered Category B Priority Pathogens by the National Institutes of Health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) have the ability to generate all blood cell types and are the cornerstone of bone marrow transplantation. Despite extensive research on how HSCs become committed to mature blood cells, metabolic cues that instruct HSCs to commit to the erythroid lineage remain unknown. Our study aims to unravel how iron affects the erythroid gene expression and erythroid differentiation of HSCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This randomized trial will assess the feasibility, effectiveness, and cost-effectiveness of telemedicine-based glaucoma screening for high-risk populations using optical coherence tomography (OCT), intraocular pressure (IOP), and visual field assessment. The targeted population will consist of Black individuals ≥ 50 years, Latino individuals ≥ 65 years, and people with diabetes who receive care at a Federally Qualified Health Center in northern California. This study is of public health relevance because it addresses the long-term goal of reducing blindness due to glaucoma through telemedicine screening approaches in areas with poor access to care.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP24-081 Novel telehealth technologies to detect and manage glaucoma and vision-threatening eye diseases in high-risk populations

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Fatigue is a significantly disabling symptom for many Veterans with MS (VwMS) that is poorly managed with no available US FDA approved therapies. A survey of more than 400 Veterans with MS (Hatzakis et al. 2005), 68% reported moderate or high fatigue levels and only 40% were prescribed non FDA approved fatigue-modifying medications. Research suggests failure of the energy production pathways in the nerve cells to contribute to MS fatigue, therefore novel therapies targeting these pathways are needed. Oral Mitoquinol (MitoQ), an antioxidant may improve nerve function by improving nerve cell energy pathways that may improve fatigue, cognition, quality of life and mood in VwMS. This 12-week study will primarily evaluate the effects of two different (20 or 40 Mg) but once daily dose of MitoQ or placebo on fatigue in VwMS and explore effects on other MS symptoms and blood immune and oxidative stress markers. We will evaluate outcomes at baseline, 6 and 12 weeks post study initiation and compare them in those receiving active study drug versus placebo.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Delays and waits for needed health care result not only in lower patient satisfaction but adverse impacts on patient outcomes. While VHA has long struggled with access problems as a result of influxes of Veterans after wartime or in response to needs of new (e.g., traumatic brain injury) or aging cohorts (e.g., long term care), VHA's highly publicized access crisis in 2014 drew demands for immediate action. That action has taken the form of expansion of Veterans' access to community providers and policy and practice action within the VA. Improving how VHA manages access through more effective deployment of clinic personnel, resources, and processes to achieve timely access is a top priority. Oddly, the evidence base on effective access management strategies remains scant, requiring new approaches to accelerating how research can support VHA access improvement efforts. The proposed study aims to provide a national profile of how VHA has responded to the access crisis, and explore what drives or hinders successful efforts to improve access.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Major recent transformations in health care financing and delivery within and outside of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) are now presenting Veterans with unprecedented health care choices. These choices give Veterans opportunities to make decisions about their use of VA and non-VA health care that optimize the timeliness, affordability, quality, and patient-centeredness of their care. However, these decisions also carry great potential for unintended consequences if they are not well-informed. Despite such high stakes, little is known about how Veterans are currently making decisions about using VA and non-VA health care, what information they want to use in this decision-making, and how the provision of information to Veterans about their health care options could be improved. This research will examine how Veterans are now making decisions about using VA and non-VA health care and identify promising new strategies to better support Veterans in making well-informed, personalized decisions about their VA and non-VA health care options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) is widespread throughout the entire African continent and in some endemic areas over 50% of the population is exposed by adulthood. Activity of the innate immune system is key to mitigating the severity of disease and the virus has actively evolved ways to abrogate innate immune function. In this project we will define how biologically relevant primary human cells recognize and respond to RVFV infection, determine which innate signaling pathways function to provide protection from disease, and define the contribution of hematopoietic cell infection to in vivo pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emergence of Plasmodium falciparum strains with resistance to first-line artemisinin-combination therapies threatens malaria control and elimination efforts across the Horn of Africa. Improved understanding of the epidemiology and determinants of drug-resistant falciparum malaria, including infections by drug- and diagnostic-resistant strains with hrp2/3 deletions, is needed to inform clinical management and policy decisions in the region. We will conduct population surveys across Ethiopia and characterize resistant parasites, integrating our findings into a point-of-care clinical tool for identifying individuals with drug-resistant falciparum malaria and into a model to predict the future spread of resistance mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This supplement requests critical upgrades at the University of Idaho Imaging and Data Acquisition Core, part of the larger INBRE Data Science Core. The equipment includes a super- resolution structured illumination microscopy (Deep SIM) add-on to the current Crest X-Light V3 confocal microscope and an additional, independent epifluorescence/widefield microscope system. These upgrades will allow Idaho researchers to keep pace with recent surges in demand for high-performance microscopy. This, in turn, will directly contribute to Idaho biomedical research productivity and competitiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of the proposed study is to improve the understanding of JAK2 inhibitor-induced drug resistance in Ph-like ALL. Furthermore, we will prove that the conserved mechanism of cell differentiation induced upon inhibition of the JAK2/STAT5 signaling pathway can be effectively harnessed for therapeutic targeting of Ph-like ALL cells. By characterizing the biology and mechanisms of drug resistance, we will develop specific multi- targeting treatment strategies for subsequent clinical translation to improve overall survival of patients with Ph- like ALL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative G-protein coupled receptor kinase-2 (GRK2) is upregulated in several cardiac diseases including hypertrophy, hypertension, and heart failure. In this proposal, we seek to determine the mechanism by which phosphorylation of GRK2 at S670 alters mitochondrial function, metabolism, and cell death signaling pre- and post- cardiac injury. The long-term goal of our work is to exploit phosphorylation of GRK2 at S670 and its downstream signaling to develop new pharmacological strategies to treat cardiac diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although obesity is a major risk factor for type 2 diabetes, only about 30% of obese patients develop diabetes due to their genetic risk. The current proposal identifies genetic variants that reduce a gene called ZC3H13, leading to impaired function of insulin-producing cells. The results may help develop tools to identify high-risk obese patients for diabetes prevention and early intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reductions in kidney blood flow can lead to permanent damage to the kidneys, known as chronic kidney disease, which can progress to complete loss of kidney function and can shorten life span. We propose to investigate whether information about kidney blood flow that we will obtain from contrast enhanced ultrasound will help identify which individuals with chronic kidney disease are at high risk of experiencing progressive loss of kidney function. The high-risk individuals can then be included in future clinical trials to test new treatments for chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 10-20% of toddlers fail to meet speech and language milestones by their second birthday. Despite its prevalence, the underlying mechanisms, predictors, and developmental profiles of these “late talkers” remain poorly understood. This proposal aims to combine three large extant datasets to characterize the neural trajectories and psychosocial factors that underlie late talking during infancy, before children begin to fall behind, which could pave the way for early identification of children at elevated likelihood of language delay and disorder and provide the opportunity to intervene when intervention may be the most effective for preventing cascading adverse language and socioemotional outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  People with opioid use disorder (OUD) have limited access to HIV prevention services, especially HIV screening, HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), and medication for OUD (MOUD). The integration of HIV prevention services into care settings where people with OUD is promising to expand HIV prevention services and reduce HIV incidence in the long run. This study will propose an innovative and multidisciplinary project to quantify healthcare usage (All Payers Claims Database (APCD) and State Emergency Department Database (SEDD)), identify optimal strategies to integrate HIV prevention services and MOUD into clinical settings (implementation methodology guided workgroup), and estimate the effect of selected implementation strategies on reducing HIV incidence among people with OUD who are at great risk of HIV acquisition (mathematic modeling).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Adolescent/young adult kidney or liver transplant recipients have unacceptably high rates of immunosuppressant medication nonadherence and, thus, are at elevated risk for nonadherence-related organ rejection, graft loss, or death. Our research involves (1) validating a new, non-invasive Real-Time Adherence Measure based on real- time adherence data easily downloaded from electronic pillboxes to accelerate provider identification of when nonadherence puts patients at risk for rejection, and (2) designing and pilot testing an innovative just-in-time adaptive mobile health intervention, leveraging real-time electronic pillbox data to support in-the-moment adherence at the point of medicine dosing. Both of our clinical tools have immense public health potential for improving medication adherence, reducing nonadherence-related health problems, and improving health-related quality of life among AYA kidney or liver transplant recipients and for other people taking daily medicine for chronic illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease affects more than 2 million American women of childbearing age, and is associated with decreased fertility and increased risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes. Planning for pregnancy prior to conception is advocated for all women but is especially important for women with kidney disease because of their potential complications. This research will develop and test a decision aid that will help women and their kidney doctors share information to support informed decision making related to reproductive health care and pregnancy in women with kidney disease.

PHR: Project Narrative This supplement to U01 CA279862 promotes the research career development of Mr. Sergio Farias, an undergraduate student at the University of Massachusetts Boston. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proper spatial and temporal organization of organelles underlies many cellular processes including cell division, migration, differentiation, and communication. Mitochondria are essential organelles that can adapt their morphology and spatial distribution to changing environmental conditions–but the molecular mechanisms governing these physiological processes are still poorly understood, especially in morphologically complex cells like muscles and neurons, which suffer disproportionately from mitochondrial dysfunction during disease- and age-related degeneration. This project will provide fundamental and much-needed knowledge on the molecular mechanisms of regulated mitochondrial morphology for developing a molecular understanding of mitochondrial function in human cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cases of pre-diabetes and type 2 diabetes (T2D) in children and adolescents have been rising at alarming rates, which is concerning in light of data showing that T2D in youth is more severe and more likely to cause complications than T2D diagnosed in adulthood. Currently it is difficult to predict whether a child with pre- diabetes will go on to develop T2D. Our proposal aims to discover predictive biomarkers to identify youth at highest risk of progressing from prediabetes to T2D, which ultimately will allow for earlier detection and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE By modulating the activity of ligand gated ion channels (LGICs) and G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs), complex natural products have the potential to reveal critical insight into the function of these therapeutically important membrane receptors. This proposal investigates the synthesis and evaluation of two classes of natural products and their development into new chemical tools to investigate LGIC and GPCR pharmacology. By providing new directions to rationally design small molecules that engage their receptors targets, the results from this research will ultimately lead to safer, more effective medicines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Human nephrogenesis is complete by 34-36 weeks gestation, with 60% of nephrons forming during the third trimester. Given improved survival of periviable gestational ages coupled with the fact that nephrogenesis continues for no more than 40 days after premature birth, preterm infants are at the low end of nephron endowment and at greater risk for chronic kidney disease and end stage renal disease in adulthood. Uncovering the molecular mechanisms governing primate-specific late gestation nephrogenesis will have a positive impact on the health of preterm infants by identifying potential druggable targets that will help extend this critical period postnatally.

Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the mission of NIGMS in understanding biological processes as a foundation for advances in disease diagnosis, treatment, and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Given the promise of bystander programs to reduce youth sexual violence, we have used bystander theory to adapt an evidence-based program directed toward the prevention of commercial sexual exploitation and trafficking (CSE/T) of children (Priority Area 4). A statewide, middle-school based randomized controlled trial will be conducted in 32 Kentucky counties over 4 years with the primary goal of evaluating the effectiveness of our novel Bystander-informed See it Stop it (BiSiSi) program, as implemented among middle school staff as interventionists, to increase screening and identification of CSE/T in intervention versus attention control schools, in the short term years 0-2), and prevent CSAET in the longer term (year 3)

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS, UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF
PHR: The risk for suicide increases by nearly 50% in the first year that service members transition from the military to civilian life underscoring the need for effective strategies to facilitate help seeking among Veterans vulnerable to self-directed violence. Yet despite a great need for treatment, more than half of returning Veterans at risk for suicide do not initiate mental health services. VA has embarked on the regular use of communication campaigns as part of a public health approach designed to reach the larger Veteran population with messages promoting help seeking. However, what types of messages effectively change beliefs and behaviors for at-risk Veterans resistant to seek treatment is unclear. The main objective of this study is to develop and test the use of public messaging to increase treatment seeking among Veterans at risk for suicide and resistant to seek mental health care following separation from military service. This represents the first study to systematically develop public messaging strategies for populations at risk for suicide.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: In this project we will examine Alzheimer’s disease (AD) genetic risk and its relationship to cognitive impairment in middle and old age to determine the extent to which effects of AD genetic risk are observable in advance of the onset of dementia. We will also evaluate whether AD genetic risk influences PTSD symptomatology in aging veterans. Finally, will look for evidence that combat trauma and traumatic brain injury (TBI) exacerbate the effects of AD genetic risk on AD. Early detection of AD risk has been noted as key to the identification of effective treatments for AD. Hence, this project has the potential to lead to better informed and more effective AD interventions. By examining how genetic factors interact with TBI and trauma we hope to pave the way for the development of diagnostic algorithms specifically tailored to a veteran population designed to identify those at risk for dementia.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cutaneous T cell Lymphoma (CTCL) is an indolent but life-threatening cancer of T lymphocytes that reside in the skin. One recent study using the VA Informatics and Computing database estimated a 6-8 fold higher incidence among Veterans than the general population. Although prognosis worsens with increasing disease stage, CTCL patients of all stages suffer from chronic skin inflammation that can produce unsightly or disfiguring skin lesions, itching, pain, and sleep disturbance that interfere with daily activities, and cause emotional distress. CTCL are often misdiagnosed as benign skin conditions, delaying appropriate therapies. The goal of the proposed studies is to have a positive effect on the health of Veterans by (1) identifying epigenetic and gene expression biomarkers that can improve diagnostic specificity in early disease, (2) increasing understanding of genetic dysregulation that promotes CTCL pathogenesis, and (3) overcoming barriers to progress in studies of skin-derived T cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Public Health Relevance Statement How the collective action of distributed neural systems in the human visual pathway leads to our rich percept of the visual world is not well understood, and disorders of the circuits involved in perception, especially those involved in face and object recognition, can significantly impair normal social function. Understanding the neural computations that support human vision and their locations in the brain will offer valuable insights into the development of visual neuro-prostheses, guidance for neurosurgery, and strategies for recovery from brain damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: To understand the etiology of metabolic disorders and motivated behavior it is essential that we gain better insight into the neuronal mechanisms that regulate metabolism and behavior. We propose studies that will assess and define the role of lipid metabolism in the arcuate melanocortin neurons in the regulation of feeding behavior and energy metabolism. The proposed studies are a logical continuation of our ongoing studies and, if successful, their completion will unmask a novel mechanistic principle in central regulation of feeding and systemic metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative This project is relevant to public health because it addresses a novel mechanism of mesenchymal lineage dysfunction and bone loss in aging. If successful, it will provide a scientific basis for development of new strategies to prevent and/or treat bone loss. It is also expected to advance the field of bone biology by elucidating yet unknown mechanisms connecting phagocytic activity of mesenchymal stromal cells, subsequent metabolic disruption, senescence and their dysfunction leading to decreased osteogenic capacity and bone loss. This is highly relevant to the NIH mission of developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human aging and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE BRCA1-BARD1 and BRCA2 are involved in DNA double-strand break repair and replication fork preservation by homology-directed DNA repair (HDR). Our research project strives to elucidate the functions of these factors and their associated HDR partner proteins in the execution of key HDR stages. This is now possible because we have developed robust systems to obtain highly quality protein preparations for mechanistic workup. As such, we are well positioned to leverage our expertise in biochemistry, biophysics, structural biology, and cell biology to fill knowledge gaps regarding HDR mechanisms and regulation in human. The information that will emanate from our work has strong health relevance, as DNA repair deficiency is associated with aging, neurological disorders, infertility, and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent and young adult (AYA) cancer survivors, live with emotional distress and health care demands that exceed those of their peers, but can have difficulty accessing the care they need. In a 5-site national study, this research will adapt a tested, personalized, interactive digital and telehealth survivorship program to the needs of AYA survivors. We will test the AYA-focused survivorship intervention in a randomized controlled trial to see if it improves emotional distress and adherence to health care guidelines after 3 and 12 months when compared to AYA survivors who receive access to a website of annotated links to existing survivorship resources followed by delayed access to the digital survivorship program after 12 months.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Microglia are non-neuronal cells in the CNS that can potently affect the function and integrity of neuronal synapses. Here, we will use novel approaches to study whether intracellular organelles called lysosomes can simultaneously regulate multiple microglial attributes that impact synapses, revealing new strategies for targeting these cells to preserve synaptic function throughout the lifespan. This work will determine how regional differences in microglial lysosome function during aging may contribute to regional differences in synapse loss and dysfunction, which are tied to age-related decline in movement and cognition and may increase risk of neurodegenerative disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genome mining of natural products from sequenced microbial genomes is a promising strategy to new human therapeutics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STD AND TB PREVENTION
PHR: Project Narrative An historic shift has occurred in the approach to infant feeding among mothers and other parents with HIV (MoPWH) in the United States (US). US guidelines have been updated to support shared decision-making regarding infant feeding choices in MoPWH on treatment with sustained viral suppression. The UPLIFT study will address knowledge gaps regarding infant feeding preferences, practices, and outcomes among MoPWH and providers in the US. Study findings will inform best practices for infant feeding counseling and the care of MoPWH who chose to breastfeed in the US.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a chronic illness resulting from loss of insulin producing beta cells leading to high blood glucose levels. Restoring autonomous glucose control in T1D requires beta cell replacement therapy, which is dependent on strategies to regenerate endogenous beta cells and expand islets ex vivo for transplant. This proposal will define new signaling mechanisms governing beta cell proliferation that may exert therapeutic benefits for people with T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Late talking in toddlers is a common reason for pediatrician concern because it can be a precursor of either persistent language disorder; worsening functional ability such as autism or global delay; or, oddly enough, the opposite: a neurotypical outcome, and yet, predictors of such dramatically divergent outcomes remain elusive. In a large representative sample of late talkers, we will identify toddler period precursors and predictors of five different preschool language and clinical outcomes by leveraging our cohort of N=1,667 late talkers and contrast typical and autism toddlers all uniformly ascertained, recruited, deep phenotyped, and demographically characterized. In an eye tracking (ET) and precision medicine-based approach, we will use normative data from our innovative social auditory and social visual attention ET paradigms to identify multimodality late talker social ET-clinical subtypes and novel subtype predictors of pre-school outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  As more adolescents with type 1 diabetes (T1D) opt to follow very low carbohydrate diets to improve glucose control, it is becoming increasingly important to study the metabolic and neurological changes that occur on these diets and how these effect patient safety. Understanding the impact of dietary changes on metabolic and neurological factors will help guide clinical advice about the overall safety and efficacy of these diets in the pediatric T1D population. This work will be the basis of future studies testing dietary interventions to improve glycemic control and ensure that these dietary interventions are safe for growing youth with T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative (From R35) Humans have many unique features that distinguish them from other animals, ranging from behavior and social organization to susceptibility to infectious and chronic diseases. Elucidating the origin of these novelties is essential for understanding the genetic basis of human biology, individual variation, and health risk factors. The goal of this project is to reconstruct the molecular mechanisms of evolutionary innovations at all levels of biological organization, from new functional elements in the genome to new genetic pathways to new anatomical structures, using experimentally tractable animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative The scientific goal of this supplement is to develop a cutting-edge paradigm using emotional reactivity to movie clips as a lens for assessing language capacity in aphasia. More accurate measurement of language abilities in individuals with stroke-induced aphasia will facilitate the optimization of fMRI language mapping in other populations proposed in the parent grant (aphasia induced by brain tumor), and other populations in general (e.g., aphasia induced by epilepsy). Critically, if our proposed approach using implicit emotional reactivity and eye behavior as proxies for language comprehension gains empirical support, it will catalyze a substantive reevaluation in how language and cognition are assessed in persons with aphasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obstacles on messenger RNAs cause ribosomes to collide with each other, resulting in a collision complexes of two ribosomes (disome) that are recognized and regulated by disome surveillance pathways. Perturbations of these surveillance systems result in neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative diseases, but the mechanisms are poorly understood. At the completion of the proposed project, I aim to understand how disome homeostasis is regulated and how its dysregulation leads to neuronal diseases.

PHR: Late language emergence (late talking), affects one in five children. Late talking research has mostly relied on data from relatively small studies, and included participants who may not be representative of broader pediatric populations growing up in America today. This study will use real world data from electronic health records (EHR) to improve our understanding of late talking developmental trajectories thereby informing clinical decision-making and referral practices for late talking children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hispanic adolescents are disproportionately burdened by type 2 diabetes and social determinants of health that negatively impact health behaviors and contribute to the development of this costly disease. This study will adapt a 12-week, evidence-based, culturally-grounded diabetes prevention program for delivery via telehealth and will test the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of the telehealth intervention. This study will provide novel information on the use of telehealth to reach and engage high-risk youth from vulnerable, health disparate communities in disease prevention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People and animals learn associations between sensory cues and motor actions through trial and error to survive in a changing environment, yet, in some cases, people act on harmful learned associations, for example, in addiction, PTSD, OCD, autism and anxiety. We know that such cue-action learning requires a “rewiring” of brain circuits, i.e., synaptic plasticity between the neurons representing the sensory cue and the neurons representing the motor action, but we still do not know where in the brain this associative synaptic plasticity occurs. Here I propose to apply an innovative behavioral paradigm and optogenetic tools to dissect a candidate pathway underlying the learned association between a cue that is the activation of visual cortex and a forelimb motor action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many patients awaiting transplant die due to an inadequate supply or organs. One possible solution is the use of organs from animals, specifically pigs, but this is impeded by a robust xeno-immune response, physiologic incompatibilities and fear of xeno-zoonosis. We proposed to test novel gene editing techniques to address these barriers using a translational xeno-liver transplant model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The scope of screening programs for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, an often underrecognized cardiac condition associated with significant morbidity and mortality, is limited by the reliance on comprehensive imaging and genetic tests that are costly, time-consuming, and not widely available. The current project proposes a point-of- care strategy for the efficient screening of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy using a combination of electrocardiographic and echocardiographic algorithms specifically adapted for use with wearable devices and portable ultrasound technologies. The proposal will develop and test a multimodal, point-of-care strategy that will empower non-specialist providers to screen for this underdiagnosed condition, with the hope of improving early detection and timely referral to specialized centers.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: The VA has considered promoting increased use of lithium (LI) and clozapine (CLOZ) to prevent suicidal behavior. This study will analyze VA databases to greatly advance understanding of LI and CLOZ safety, and conduct a nationwide survey of VA MH prescribers about barriers and facilitators to LI and CLOZ use. VA databases contain far more LI users than previously studied, allowing crucial issues to be evaluated. These include identifying which patient groups would be the safest to target for increased use, and whether existing treatments and dosing strategies should be more widely used to prevent serious side effects. Findings will be summarized for Program Partners and providers, including in a user-friendly Guide and Patient-Provider Communication Tool prepared with the assistance of an Advisory Board of Veterans, VA leadership, providers, and subject experts. The survey will identify factors that might interfere or assist efforts to increase LI and CLOZ use. This state-of-the-art study will greatly enhance any future VA efforts to expand LI and CLOZ use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disruption of mitochondrial dynamics and quality control are key components of leading causes of disability, such as cerebrovascular disease and age-related neurodegeneration. The proposed research aims to investigate the contributions of dysfunctional mitochondrial quality control to cerebral ischemia/reperfusion injury, as well as the onset and progression of neurodegenerative disease. Utilizing innovate molecular and computational techniques, these studies will advance our understanding of mitochondrial dysfunction and inform the development of future therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative There are a dearth of opportunities for students from underrepresented backgrounds to obtain specialized post-baccalaureate training in neuroscience, though such training is becoming increasingly important for admission to top neuroscience PhD programs. Here, we propose further development of PiNBAC, a post- baccalaureate program launched in 2021 with significant mentorship, research and educational components housed in the Harvard Medical School Department of Neurobiology, and affiliated with the T32-funded Harvard PhD Program in Neuroscience. Early program outcomes suggest that PiNBAC is an effective approach to train a diverse neuroscience workforce by preparing talented trainees from underrepresented groups for successful application to, and success within, competitive PhD programs to continue their training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Maquat-lab research focuses on RNA metabolism in human health and disease. The lab’s view is that understanding the molecular mechanisms of normal gene expression and what goes wrong with these mechanisms in disease are critical for the development of effective therapeutics. Disease states to be examined include fragile X syndrome, which is the most common single-gene cause of intellectual disability and autism, and a runaway innate immune response, which can lead to a cytokine storm in cases of bacterial or viral infections, including COVID-19.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vestibulodynia (VBD) is a complex chronic vulvar pain condition that impairs the psychological, physical, and sexual health of 1 in 6 reproductive aged women in the United States. Here, we plan to conduct a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled clinical trial to 1) compare the efficacy of peripheral (lidocaine/estradiol cream), centrally-targeted (nortriptyline), and combined treatments in alleviating pain and improving patient- reported outcomes and 2) determine cytokine and microRNA biomarkers that predict treatment response in women with distinct VBD subtypes. Positive findings from this study will readily translate to improved patient care, permitting the millions of women with VBD, their partners, and their clinicians to make more informed decisions about pain management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The pilot data collected for this study will inform the development of a randomized controlled trial evaluating the efficacy of an environmental intervention designed to increase engagement in rewarding alcohol-free social activities and reduce heavy episodic drinking and related negative consequences among college students who are members of a fraternity or sorority. This intervention has the potential to engage a difficult to reach group of college students who are at high-risk of experiencing significant alcohol-related harm, as well as benefit these students by providing alcohol-free alternatives to developing social connections. Environmental approaches such as this are needed to not only change the social context of high-risk drinking environments for college students, but to also provide drinking alternatives to maximize the effects of individual-level alcohol interventions that increase college students' motivation for behavior change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although progress has been made in the development of ViCPS-conjugate vaccines for typhoid, the majority of fatal systemic Salmonellosis is caused by bacterial that lack expression of ViCPS. CD4 Th1 memory T cells are required to resolve this non-typhoid systemic disease, meaning that new vaccine approaches will be required. This application explores a new mRNA vaccine approach for Salmonella that attempts to elicit hepatic Tissue-Resident Memory Th1 cells. Our preliminary data show that these cells are essential for protection and differ from other TRMs in expression of IL-18R. Our goal is to test the requirement for IL-18R in protective immunity and elicit TRMs using an mRNA vaccine approach. Successful completion of this exploratory project will validate a new approach to vaccination for intra-macrophage pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Administrative Supplement to Purchase Thermocycler Instruments Summary of Parent Grant RNA functions as the central conduit of information exchange in all cells. RNA molecules encode this information in both their primary sequences and in complex structures that form when RNA folds back on itself. The broad and fundamental importance of RNA structure is clear, but there remains a profound knowledge gap: We generally have only rudimentary understanding of RNA structure across vast regions of most messenger and non-coding RNAs. We need to move beyond modeling RNA structure to directly detecting through-space structural communication and interactions in cells. In essentially every instance where we have applied rigorous and quantitative technologies to study RNA structure-function interrelationships, new insights regarding biological regulatory mechanisms have emerged. We have also shown that RNA elements with higher-order structures are more likely to contain high-information-content clefts and pockets that bind small molecules, broadly informing a vigorous field of RNA-targeted drug discovery. Our work has sustained long-term impact due to pursuing three overarching opportunities. First, the project focuses on development of decisive, concise, and broadly implementable technologies for discovering and assessing higher-order structure in RNA. Second, this project applies these direct and experimentally concise methods to challenges of broad importance, from identification of structures essential for replication of pathogenic viruses to understanding how RNA conformational ensembles govern transcriptional gene regulation and pre-mRNA splicing. Third, understanding the propensity of RNA to form higher-order structures – and often clefts and pockets – opens up the possibility of targeting these motifs with small molecules, an opportunity we will exploit with the long-term goal of inventing facile and straightforward strategies for creating RNA-targeted therapeutics. Overview of Need for Equipment Purchase This administrative supplement requests funds to purchase and replace thermocycler instruments to be used by the Weeks research laboratory, which is currently supported by NIGMS R35 GM122532 (Dr. Michael Sakalian, PO). The cost of the essential instruments is $19,999.98 and is outside the range of equipment that can be purchased in the context of the current budget. Our grant budget is fully encumbered, and will zero out, for the next year. The requested instrument will be shared and used by multiple members of the Weeks group. The need for replacement thermocyclers was unforeseen at the time of the original research proposal. Thermocyclers are essential for all modern RNA genomics experiments. Our current, non-functional instruments were purchased in 2012, twelve years ago. Stuff breaks, and we absolutely need to replace these instruments to do our MIRA-funded work. We need two instruments due to the volume of work and sequencing that we do. Diverse researchers will benefit from this purchase. The thermocycler instruments will be used by all Weeks group members, from undergraduates to postdocs (14 total). The simple operating design and user interface of the requested instruments will allow all members of the lab to use the instruments efficiently. Plan for training and upkeep. The instruments will be maintained by the Weeks lab. A lead user in our laboratory will be assigned and will facilitate training and ensure the instruments operate efficiently.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Azoles are common antifungal agents widely-used in clinical applications and agriculture. In vertebrates, exposures to azoles during early embryonic development results in developmental toxicity outcomes, including, craniofacial and axial defects. In this study, we aim to delineate mechanisms underlying azole-induced developmental toxicity utilizing single cell transcriptomic-based approaches, gene-editing tools, and established alternative model systems of early embryonic development.

PHR: Project Narrative Neuronal plasticity is how neurons change their connections with other neurons and is essential for normal brain development and function. However, plasticity also underlies addiction and is misregulated in disorders such as autism and schizophrenia. We propose to identify and study novel molecular mechanisms of neuronal plasticity, using circadian clock neurons as neurons with highly predictable plasticity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project supports the ABCD-ReproNim Educational Program, which provides research training in responsible, reproducible, and valid analyses of data from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study. Participants first receive didactic training across a 16-week online course that includes lectures, readings, and data exercises; at the completion of the course, participants will contribute to team-based, collaborative data analysis projects during a five-day hackathon at the host institution, Florida International University, in Miami, Florida. Program success will result in well-trained researchers who are able to apply responsible, reproducible, and valid practices to ABCD data, affording them the opportunity to better utilize the valuable ABCD resource.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The major goal of this administrative supplement application for the Parent Grant P40 of the Caribbean Primate Research Center (CPRC) is to improve and expand the storage and housing areas at the Sabana Seca Field Station. This in turn is essential to support any expansion of the Center's IO rhesus colony. The CPRC is one of the most important national resources for any research program using indian- origin (IO) rhesus macaques with no history of admixture and with well-defined genetic and virological backgrounds. Since 1938, the Center has supplied the scientific community with Indian origin rhesus macaques with known backgrounds and of the same genetic pool for use in studies of basic biology and diseases. In the last three years (2020-2023), 700 animals (app 230/year) have been available from this program in support of NIH-high priority HIV/AIDS-research, mainly R01, P01, U01- funded academic investigators and NIAID-DAIDS-SVEU programs. The CPRC has vast experience in the establishment and maintenance of rhesus macaque breeding colonies. The animal care and use program of the CPRC is in compliance with the directives established by the Animal Welfare Act (AWA), PHS and other agencies. The Center is AAALAC fully- accredited. The population management program has been designed to optimize the health and well-being of the monkeys, enhance the value of the colony for research, and provide healthy animals to the scientific community for a variety of studies. The Center is in the urgent need of creating storage area and to renovate a quarantine housing area needed when SPF candidates animals undergoes viral testing. This renovation will support the CPRC to achieve the objective of the expansion and maintenance of the SPF-P40 colony within the original scope of the parent grant.

In this cooperative agreement, the UI VDL is pleased to assist the Vet-LIRN program to 1) respond to complaints in animal food and treats, 2) collect bacterial pathogens and examine their antibiogram to help the program to develop antimicrobial stewardship for veterinary and human medicine practitioners, 3) participate in Vet-LIRN-led proficiency tests and new test development and validation to enhance the accuracy of diagnostic approaches. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project narrative The junctional epithelium (JE) serves as the first line of defense against periodontal diseases, and its barrier functions are maintained by a stem cell niche. Here, we will identify and characterize the roles of Wnt/β-catenin signaling in maintaining the stem cell pool during JE homeostasis and during injury repair. We also test a biochemical approach for re-establishing JE barrier functions after damage and disease that, if successful, opens up new avenues for periodontal disease treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Macrophages, a component of our immune system, have a paradoxical role in cancer – they can promote metastasis. We previously discovered that macrophages spill their internal contents into cancer cells during metastasis, but what is the functionally important information in the contents? We recently discovered that mitochondria are transferred, and we seek to answer how thieving even small amounts of mitochondria can drive big changes in cancer cell metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients aged 65 and older account for an increasing portion of traumatic brain injury (TBI) patients while also suffering increased morbidity and mortality compared to young TBI patients. The interplay between microglia, infiltrating immune cells, and the gut is still unknown but connections between immune infiltration in the brain and poor neurologic outcomes after TBI have been made. We will use a model of microglial depletion and a fecal microbiota transfer (FMT) model to assess the impact of microglial activation and the gut on immune cell infiltration in the aged brain after TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) is a noninvasive brain stimulation method with current FDA approvals for treatment of major depressive disorder (MDD) and obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) but most clinical applications are focused on single brain target. This project employee a novel multichannel TMS (mTMS) system specifically designed for multifocal brain network stimulation that can be used to enhance the connectivity between brain areas. When combining multifocal brain stimulation with electrical measurements of functional connectivity using electroencephalography (EEG), this technology can be used to optimize the network-level stimulation protocols paving way for improved therapeutic outcomes with minimized side effects and treatment duration in future.
