IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthcare-associated infections due to antibiotic resistant organisms are an extremely important cause of morbidity and mortality. We will use models and simulations to enhance our ability to respond to this threat in two major ways: by making infection control efforts more effective and efficient, and by guiding improvements in use of antibiotics
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CK-20-003: Modeling and Simulation to Support Epidemiological Decision-Making in Healthcare Settings

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Project Narrative The models developed through this proposal will improve understanding of how biological factors associated with the transmission of multidrug-resistant organisms (MDRO) impact interventions to reduce hospital-associated infections (HAIs). This will aid predictions of patients' risk for colonization and infection, as well as improve understanding of how interventions can most effectively be combined to reduce the likelihood that patients will suffer from these high-consequence pathogens.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CK20-003: In silico Randomized Control Trial Framework for Assessing Infection Control and Prevention Interventions in the Hospital

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to use mathematical modeling, agent-based simulation and machine learning approaches to build decision-making technologies that improve the risk assessment, prevention and control of healthcare- associated infections and antibiotic-resistant infections. Our proposed technologies will account for spatial and temporal dynamics, provide continuous, real-time feedback to clinicians and are robust to changes in risk factors and disease prevalence over time. We concentrate our efforts on two of the most important healthcare- associated infections: methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus and Clostridioides difficile infections.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CK20-003: Modeling of infectious network dynamics for surveillance, control and prevention enhancement (MINDSCAPE)

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Project Narrative Healthcare-associated infections (HAIs) affect about two million patients in American hospitals each year. Of particular concern are multidrug resistant organisms (MDROs) that can be ampliﬁed in hospitals, transmitted to other hospitals, long-term or skilled-care facilities, and then, eventually, exported to the community at large. The goal of this project is to build high-ﬁdelity models of HAI transmission within and across healthcare facilities from large, complex, ﬁne-grained data sources. Simulations based on these models can be used to better understand the transmission of HAI pathogens, compare alternative infection control interventions, and provide effective and practical guidance on best practices to reduce the transmission of MDROs and other HAI pathogens.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CK20-003: Contact Network Transmission Modeling of Healthcare Associated Infections

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infections by antimicrobial resistant (AR) pathogens are a persistent threat to human health in healthcare settings. Here, for this MInD Healthcare network project, we propose to use hospitalization records and diagnostic data for multiple AR pathogens from four major hospitals in New York City to conduct a series of modeling studies. Our aims are to: 1) model the spread of AR pathogens in healthcare systems at individual and facility levels; 2) infer key epidemiological parameters and asymptomatic carriage probabilities; 3) predict outbreaks of AR pathogens in healthcare facilities; 4) evaluate and optimize potential intervention measures; and 5) partner with other network modeling groups to test interventions across different models.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CK20-003: Analysis and Simulation of Bacterial Infections and Resource Strain in Hospitals during the COVID-19 Pandemic

IC_NAME: Center for Global Health
PHR: NARRATIVE (ADMINISTRATIVE CORE) The Washington State University (WSU) and the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine (LSTM) propose to use their collective administrative and technical experience in Kenya and excellent relationships with the Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI) to support KEMRI in the management of the KEMRI/CGHR Research Platform (KRP), cost-effectively and sustainably. The platform includes the population-based health and demographic surveillance systems, laboratories, clinical research centers, offices, and shared services. Following extensive discussions with KEMRI that led to this joint application, we agreed to implement a highly cost-effective management plan that develops strong organizational capacities within KEMRI, which is required to assume successful and sustainable management of the KRP infrastructure in support of their public health research in Kenya. In addition, we demonstrate clear technical expertise to lead the Research Core areas identified in the RFA, using the same approach of twinning experienced WSU and LSTM scientists with KEMRI and CDC counterparts to design, implement, and publish finding from the studies, an approach designed to train and mentor KEMRI scientists in applying and managing research funding.

PROJECT_TITLE: GH21-003, Advancing Public Health Research in Kenya

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Principal Investigator: Hongzhe Li Narrative Project Title: Maximizing hearing recovery from peri-synaptic damage Narrative  Many Veterans suffer from noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) due to exposure to high intensity sounds during their military service. Wounded soldiers and Veterans often receive critical lifesaving antibiotics to treat and prevent bacterial infections, which also put them at a high-risk for a drug-induced ototoxicity. Increasing evidences suggest substantial noise- and drug-induced hearing loss can include synaptopathy, which may be reversible, if treated on time. Thus, this type of neurological injuries has potentially significant implications for military Service Member performance, long-term received Veterans health, and noise exposure standards. The present study is designed to better understand cochlear synaptic damage and to investigate rehabilitative strategies to disrupt such neural degeneration. Study results will contribute to Veterans Health Administration’s (VHA’s) goal to help improve the quality of life of Veterans, who suffer from hearing loss due to noise damage and drug-induced ototoxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: The overarching goal of this study is to identify the relationship between Medicaid expansion, poverty, and rural-urban ethnoracial mortality disparities in the United States from 2011 to 2019 using large-scale restricted data and novel estimates of poverty. The project will use the state-by-state roll out of Medicaid expansion to evaluate the association between Medicaid expansion and rural-urban ethnoracial mortality disparities, as well as the mediating role of poverty in this relationship. The results of this study will provide essential information for future public health policy initiatives at the health care system-level, while also providing important evidence on the impact Medicaid expansion has, or has not had on poverty and mortality disparities in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial/ethnic minorities are disproportionately affected by breast cancer outcomes as Black and Hispanic women are 20% more likely than White women to be diagnosed with advanced stage breast cancer; and have up to 70% and 14% increased risk of death, respectively. This K01 project aims to identify areas of low mammography screening, and to elucidate the racial/ethnic specific barriers on the uptake of adequate mammography screening for Black and Hispanic women within the defined high-risk areas. The long-term goal of this research trajectory is to contribute to the reduction of racial and geographic disparities in breast cancer outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research and product development delivers a rigorously designed and tested social engagement technology (OneClick) with online games tailored to the needs, abilities, and interests of older adults with and without Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI). The online games will be well-known and enjoyable to older adults, and facilitate and enhance social interaction between older adults with and without MCI and their close friends and family members. The games will make it easy for people to connect, thereby stimulating social interaction and engagement, which is beneficial to health and quality-of-life outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pervasive race and gender disparities in the provision of healthcare are well-documented among those suffering from pain. The proposed project aims to identify patterns in medical student race and gender biases in pain assessment (inclusive of gender diverse patients) and how these biases impact treatment decisions and care. Findings will identify opportunities to tailor and implement effective intervention approaches aimed to reduce pain assessment biases among medical students with the goal to reduce future pain treatment disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  The internal body clock, our circadian rhythms, control a broad range of processes in humans, timing our sleep cycles, metabolism, the immune response, and many other physiological functions to be optimally coordinated with our persistent day/night cycle. Due to the widespread integration of circadian control over many essential biological processes, the disruption of circadian rhythms has been linked to numerous medical conditions, including chronic inflammation, metabolic disease, and cancer, making an appreciation of clock control over physiology vital to human health research. Given the strong functional conservation between fungal, murine, and human clocks, our investigation of the fundamental mechanisms of intrinsically disordered proteins and their effects of circadian post-transcriptional regulation in mice and fungi will broaden the understanding of circadian regulation over human physiology, paving the way for the development of effective chronotherapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), the most prevalent anxiety disorder in primary care, is often misdiagnosed, particularly in individuals from marginalized sociodemographic groups. The proposed study leverages large- scale, epidemiologic and electronic health record datasets to evaluate two potential contributors to GAD diagnostic disparities: 1) psychometric bias, or indications that GAD’s diagnostic criteria fail to capture the same construct across sociodemographic groups or over time, and 2) disparities in patient-centered care, which is characterized by collaborative decision-making and respecting patients’ values, culture, and context. Findings from the proposed study will inform efforts to achieve equitable GAD diagnostic practices and treatment access by illuminating how minoritized groups experience GAD and how it can be accurately diagnosed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Development of a successful HIV vaccine is a grand challenge of modern vaccine science. Recently, the concept of shepherding the immune response toward protective B cell responses through a series of repeated immunizations has shown promise, but many fundamental questions about how such sequential immunization vaccines should be designed and optimized remain unanswered. In this proposal, we aim to develop several parallel practical approaches to enhance the ability of sequential immunizations to drive the development of broadly neutralizing antibodies that have the potential to be protective against HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The manipulation of a subset of glutamate-octopamine dual transmitting neurons results in increased levels of high intensity aggression. The goal of our study is to understand how dual transmission is regulated and how the release of two transmitters from the same neuron leads to changes in aggressive behaviors. A better understanding of the mechanisms by which dual transmission is controlled may lead to novel strategies to treat elevated aggression that are associated with psychiatric disorders or neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative The prototypic BG505 SOSIP.664 protein is a potent HIV-1 immunogen currently in two phase I clinical trials. RNA vaccines induce immune pathways distinct from protein-based vaccines, and if successfully developed, our proposed replicating RNA (repRNA) vaccine can complement the clinical vaccine and potentially boost waning immune responses. We will develop a repRNA vaccine expressing BG505 SOSIP.664 and evaluate protective immunity in a non-human primate challenge model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black, Latino/a/e/x, and Multiracial (BLM) sexual and gender minorities who have sex with men (SGMSM) are at disproportionately high risk for HIV infection, yet little research has been powered to examine whether exposure to oppressive socio-structural factors vis-à-vis inequitable risk environments drives BLM SGMSM’s inequitable rates of HIV. In this study, we will establish a large nationwide cohort of BLM SGMSM and follow them longitudinally to examine socio-structural predictors (i.e., state- and local- level laws, policies, and social climate) of HIV seroconversion and access to emerging HIV prevention technologies (e.g., PrEP and ART). We will integrate Intersectionality and the Social Ecological Model to identify modifiable socio-structural targets for future public health policy and community-level intervention, with an emphasis on developing guidelines that can be integrated into the U.S. Ending the HIV Epidemic initiative to promote not only overall reductions in HIV but specifically target drivers of HIV inequities for BLM SGMSM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES

PHR: NARRATIVE This LITE-2 (RFA-AI-21-018) proposal responds to a resurgent epidemic of methamphetamine (meth) use in sexual minority men (SMM) by: 1) identifying multi-level and bio-behavioral determinants of amplified HIV seroconversion risk in meth-using SMM; and 2) testing the effectiveness of telehealth motivational enhancement interventions for optimizing for optimizing entry or re-entry of SMM who use meth into the PrEP care continuum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RESEARCH STRATEGY FOR THE SUPPLEMENT SCIENTIFIC JUSTIFICATION FOR THE REQUESTED EQUIPMENT  We use Arabidopsis thaliana as model to discover and characterize novel genes and functional natural polymorphisms that control genotype-specific telomere lengths. Aim 1 is focused on characterizing functional natural variation in telomerase function, expression, and enzymatic activity. We also employ innovative and comprehensive genome-wide screens to identify novel trans-regulators of TERT expression and inhibitors and activators of in vivo telomerase activity. In Aim 2, we perform a series of experiments to characterize the role of previously identified candidate genes in telomere biology and length control. We also exploit several cutting-edge genomic approaches to identify additional regulators of telomere length. We have developed an effective research pipeline for candidate gene analysis that led to the identification of several novel genetic factors and pathways and we anticipate making more new discoveries. Our high-throughput assays allow us to screen up to 20 different T-DNA mutants for telomere phenotypes simultaneously. Genetic and transgenic experiments to validate the role of candidate genes in telomere length control include: 1) knock-out analysis of candidate genes for defects in telomere length; 2) transgenic rescue experiments; and 3) quantitative complementation tests. Collectively, these studies will reveal and characterize the complex genetic landscapes that underlie natural variation in telomere length set point.  Both Aims 1 and 2 rely heavily on the measurement of telomere length in hundreds of various transgenic mutants and natural populations of Arabidopsis. This Southern blotting technique requires the use of radioactive P32 oligonucleotide probes to hybridize telomeric DNA in gels and subsequent scanning the signals with a Phosphor Imager. Our lab previously had a Typhoon FLA 7000 machine suitable for these assays, but unfortunately this machine is now not operational. We had a Cytiva technician come to the lab to look at it, and he had indicated that the unit cannot be repaired, as this model is so old that Cytiva is no longer manufacturing parts or providing any service. Thus, currently we do not have a Phosphor Imager, and no other lab at Marshall University has this type of equipment for imaging.  We are currently using X-ray films as an alternative. However, this method has major crucial drawbacks and limitations compared to Phosphor Imaging which substantially slows down work and adds unnecessary costs. Specifically, Phosphor imaging provides a much greater linear dynamic range and higher sensitivity than X-ray film when detecting radiolabels. This allows very precise quantitation of nucleic acids which is incredibly important for our high-throughput project and not really sustainable long-term with X-ray films. With P32 half-life being only 2 weeks, without digital imaging we simply cannot analyze the necessary number of samples with X- rays before the signal disappears, especially when some assays often need to be repeated. Having access to a Phosphor Imaging capability is a major necessity, and it will be routinely used for the duration of the project.  I have received a quote for Azure Sapphire FL Phosphor Imager, which is the next generation of biomolecular imagers with many benefits and extra features over the Typhoon models. It features customizable and user- changeable optical modules, laser based scanning system supporting 375 nm excitation to 900 nm emission, adjustable Z focus, 5-1000 micron resolution. Through the use of laser excitation and photon multiplier tube (PMT) detection, Sapphire FL is able to scan storage phosphor screens with exceptional dynamic range and image quality; these features are integral to the success of our study and provide unparalleled advantages for everyday use in comparison to X-rays. Sapphire FL Phosphor Imager is essential for both aims of our research project and will substantially speed up our progress.  The quote for Sapphire FL Phosphor Imager covers the price of the Imager, Phosphor Standard Optical Module, dedicated Desktop Workstation with External High-Resolution Monitor for Sapphire FL, shipping & handling, device installation and training of the personnel, and AzureSpot Pro software for downstream analysis. Warranty period is for 1 year. The future recurring costs associated with the requested equipment include additional years of service contract, which will be covered through PI’s startup funds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This information has not changed from the Parent Award While successful genome inheritance requires that each gamete – sperm or egg – receives one copy of each chromosome, an estimated 35% of human zygotes contain an incomplete chromosome set, resulting in miscarriages and birth defects. The research proposed here addresses the mechanisms that regulate interaction and information exchange between the parental chromosomes during sexual reproduction, which is essential for correct chromosome segregation into gametes. A better understanding of the structure and dynamics of chromosomes during sexual reproduction will elucidate the mechanistic principles that control chromosomes across biological processes, ranging from gene expression to cell division, and will ultimately shed light on the chromosomal dysfunctions that lead to cancer.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Veterinary diagnostic laboratories (VDLs) play a pivotal role in maintaining animal health, aiding veterinarians, animal owners, researchers, and those involved in the veterinary sector. These laboratories are also integral to the public health sector's efforts in monitoring and preventing zoonotic diseases. There is a crucial need to build and maintain the capability of VDLs. Collaborative efforts among VDLs should also be coordinated to maximize the use of resources. This project seeks funding to enhance and sustain the Clinical Diagnostic Laboratory (CDL) at The Ohio State University's Veterinary Medical Center. The CDL will actively engage in the CVM FDA Vet-LIRN program, focusing on three key areas: 1) contributing bacterial samples for the Vet-LIRN Whole Genome Sequencing Project, 2) upgrading laboratory equipment, and 3) facilitating staff development through training and participation in proficiency tests.

PROJECT_TITLE: Laboratory capacity FDA CVM Vet-LIRN veterinary diagnostic laboratory program

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Emergence of antibiotic resistance continues to be a threat to both human and animal health around the world, and this burden can be reduced with the prudent use of antibiotics through culture and susceptibility testing. The AHDC Bacteriology laboratory is engaged to continue its cooperative agreement with the FDA Vet-LIRN to promote the areas of food and feed surveillance, antibiotic susceptibility testing, quality management, animal health, food safety, and food security. As a continued participant in the Vet-LIRN network of veterinary diagnostic laboratories, the AHDC Bacteriology laboratory can provide surge capacity for large-scale testing in the event of an emergency.

PHR: Narrative Scientific data, such as the trajectories of biomolecular simulations, is being produced at prodigious rates, making analysis increasingly difficult using traditional methods. Here, we propose to build a cloud-based module that will train scientists in using machine-learning approaches for analysis of molecular dynamics simulation trajectories in order to extract novel insights from otherwise large and noisy datasets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Rhythmic behaviors and physiological processes are temporally organized by the central circadian pacemaker to occur at the optimal time of day. Disruption of this precise organization due to disease or lifestyle (shift work, artificial light at night) is associated with negative health outcomes including metabolic, cardiovascular, and mood disorders. Our research program aims to determine the interaction between the genes, neurons, and circuits that time rhythmic behaviors, which will provide a foundation for the investigation of the mechanisms of circadian dysfunction that both lead to, and are a symptom of, disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Astrocytes are highly elaborate cells that are key regulators of brain development, function, and maintenance, and astrocyte dysfunction results in devastating neurological conditions. We propose to dissect a novel, evolutionarily conserved pathway that is required for normal astrocyte growth and brain function. Our work will define fundamental cellular mechanisms that control astrocyte development, their contributions to brain health and function, and should provide critical insights into our understanding of astrocyte dysfunction in human disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this VA CDA-2 proposal is to develop the candidate into a successful VA research scientist and determine how immunotherapy can be used in combination with standard chemotherapy (FOLFOX) in colon and rectal cancer. Colon and rectal cancer affects a large number of veterans. Despite excellent screening programs, a sizable number of these patients present with advanced disease. While treatment for patients has improved, there is still significant need for progress. An ideal area to target is combination immunotherapy with FOLFOX. Cytotoxic T cells are associated with improved survival and treatment response in colorectal cancer and are the primary mediator of anti-tumor immunity. In this proposal, we will test how FOLFOX chemotherapy alters cytotoxic T cells in the tumor and the abiliy to combine these therapies. The data garnered in this study will serve to establish the PI's research program and develop future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences) This doctoral readiness program, Iowa Diversifying Research Experiences And Mentorship (iDREAM), capitalizes on an outstanding T32 supported (JSPTPN) Neuroscience Graduate program with a highly successful track record of training neuroscientists from diverse backgrounds, particularly those from backgrounds underrepresented in STEM. It integrates an outstanding interdisciplinary neuroscience research environment with evidence-based practices designed to cultivate self-efficacy and a strong sense of belonging within the local and global neuroscience research communities. In doing so, iDREAM is designed to provide high quality research experiences and didactics to post-baccalaureate students from institutions that do not offer undergraduates substantial research opportunities, ultimately empowering trainees to be competitive for and successful in rigorous, top-tier neuroscience graduate programs and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Both cognitive aging and epigenetic change appear to be highly influenced by life experiences, and this project will examine how these are linked. The project has two main objectives: (1) to examine how DNA methylation and RNA transcriptomes are tied to several measures of cognitive status and change, and (2) to examine how life experiences are biologically embedded via epigenetic mechanisms to impact cognitive aging. Findings from this study will add significantly to research on the life course origins of dementia and cognitive aging by taking into account how lifetime social and environmental exposures and their timing impact cognition in older life via DNA methylation and gene expression, and it may point to potential areas of intervention to improve the cognitive health of the population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinx individuals are 1.5 times more likely to develop Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) than non-Latinx whites, and have higher rates of under-diagnosis. As the proportion of US Latinx older adults is expected to increase five-fold over the next 30 years, it has become obvious that they experience unique barriers to access ADRD care services. This proposal seeks to perform a comprehensive assessment of the barriers experienced by Latinx individuals, and co-design with stakeholders a human-centered intervention that can increase access to ADRD services in low resource settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Innate immune responses of insect vectors of human diseases are likely to affect the their ability to transmit pathogens to hosts. The long term goals of this research is to gain understanding of proteins in insect hemolymph that mediate innate immune responses, using a model system, Manduca sexta, well suited for biochemical studies. The knowledge gained from this project will enhance understanding of the evolution of innate immune mechanisms and can be applied to future investigations of arthropod disease vectors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this project is to develop a sophisticated new set of light activated chemical reactions that selectively form covalent bonds with specific types of biological structure. These new reactions will facilitate advances in biomedical sciences by enabling the design of new therapeutics and new approaches for the study the molecular nature of disease states; ultimately leading to opportunities for developing more effective treatments. In this project, we extensively employ LC-MS for biological mass spectrometry and proteomicsbased analytical workflows, and this supplement will support the acquisition of a new UHPLC system that will enhance our LC-MS capabilities and, in turn, our ability to perform these essential analytical workflows.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how ethnic and racial factors modify Alzheimer’s disease risk can yield new insights into race- dependent biological mechanisms which in turn can inform future diagnostic and therapeutic interventions. An unbiased proteomic approach will be employed to examine the diagnostic and prognostic ability of plasma exosomes as biomarkers for AD. Successful completion of this study will significantly advance the field of exosome biology in neurodegeneration and may lead to the identification of novel biological targets for therapeutic development of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to characterize the transcription cycle structurally and functionally in the actinobacteria phylum, focusing on the pathogen Mycobacterium tuberculosis. RNA polymerase, the central enzyme of transcription, is a proven target for antimicrobials, and regulators of the transcription cycle are often clade-specific but essential for viability and virulence. Understanding how these factors regulate Mycobacterium tuberculosis RNA polymerase informs us on unified and clade-specific mechanisms, providing a more comprehensive understanding of the transcription cycle that can lead to new therapeutics against specific bacterial pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Communication between cells of gastric epithelial glands and surrounding stromal cells is indispensable for normal stomach function and misregulation of the signaling networks executing this communication can cause inflammation and precancerous lesions that can become cancerous. Helicobacter. pylori infection, the highest risk factor for gastric cancer, disrupts signals originating from stromal cells that maintain normal growth and function of epithelial glands and prevent inflammation. The current proposal will define how misregulation of protein kinase A (PKA) signaling causes inflammation and precancerous lesions via disrupting stromal-epithelial communication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Administrative supplement is requested to enable capabilities for high-speed three-dimensional imaging of living cells by the Lattice LightSheet system to study the endocytosis of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and the role of endocytosis in EGFR signaling. EGFR plays important roles in mammalian development, wound healing, tissue regeneration and tissue homeostasis in adults. EGFR is also involved in various cell abnormalities, most notably, tumorigenesis and metastatic processes. The mechanisms regulating EGFR endocytosis and its role in signaling are incompletely understood. The proposed research will address the fundamental question of how multiple intertwining signaling pathways activated by EGFR are regulated by the subcellular localization dynamics of the constituents of those pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Just like the skeleton in our body, cells have a cytoskeleton, which provides a framework for their shape and thus their function. The key cytoskeletal element, microtubules, are generated at precise locations and times in order to build cellular structures. In this proposal, I will determine how MT nucleation is used to drive the formation of two microtubule-based structures, the mitotic spindle and neuronal dendrites, which will provide the underlying principles of microtubule self-organizing and how it gives rise to specialized cell architecture and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Fluorescent molecular imaging reagents for blood vessel detection have important applications for medical diagnosis. For example, fluorescein is widely used in ophthalmology to check any blood vessel abnormalities during eye exams. The proposed project acquires a modern fluorescence spectrometer, which will be used to aid the development of new imaging reagents for selective detection of blood vessels. Success in the study could lead to novel imaging reagents, which will enable simplified applications and facilitate a wide range of developmental studies by using zebrafish model organism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the blue-light hazards in dentistry are well known to date, there are no alternatives to this problem because of the lack of photoinitiators that absorb longer wavelengths and few studies evaluating the safety of longer wavelengths in the oral cavity. We aim to fill this gap by investigating a novel red-light activated photoinitiator and the human pulp and gingival tissues responses to red light following its application to restorative dental treatments compared to blue light. The results of this work will lay the groundwork to achieve our long-term goal of using red light as a safer and more effective treatment strategy to improve oral health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Concerns of permanent undesirable off-target DNA edits has hampered acceptance of genomic editing tools to treat genetic disorders. The long-term goal of this proposal aims to treat these disorders by selectively editing the RNA transcripts to produce functional protein. Guide oligonucleotides will be screened and optimized to target mRNA mutations that can be repaired by the cell’s RNA editing enzymes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Each of our cells inactivates many of its available genes to perform a unique function. Failure to properly inactivate genes underlies developmental disorders and devastating pediatric brain and blood cancers. This project investigates how cells inactivate the correct genes at the correct time during development to understand how defective gene inactivation can cause disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative PRMT1 is a human protein that plays a critical role in the ability of cells to communicate and organize chemical reactions in the cell. In this project we will investigate how grouping PRMT1 molecules together and how stress damage of PRMT1 affects the ability of the protein to function. Additionally, we will test a new way of controlling the activity of PRMT1 using designed small molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Request Justification  The parent award (R01GM147548-01A1) has a heavy reliance on microscopy. Our overall research goal has not changed and our access to high-end microscopy (point-scanning, high-resolution, multi-photon) in our campus’ Light Microscopy Core Facility (LMCF) has not changed. The Supplemental request is for a replacement of our 27-year-old microscope (a NIKON E800, purchased in 1996 on NIH GH52953). The E800 has been a workhorse and contributed heavily to my entire portfolio of publications with a cell biological orientation (the most relevant to the project is listed in my Biosketch), including a new paper in Cell, listed as the last entry in my Biosketch. There have been many generations of microscopes marketed by NIKON since the E800. While we coped the best we could with out-dated technology, the functionality of our microscope has been on a slow decline over the past decade due to increasing difficulty in acquiring replacement parts. In the last service call (January 2023), I was warned the E800’s capability would continue to decline to below the limits of operational needs (such as moving shutters in and out, filter turrents etc.; yes these are all in manual mode).  The requested microscope will provide hours of access for training and pilot experiments prior to using the LMCF facility, which charges by the hours on all microscopes. Our original budget has depended on the E800 (located just steps from my office and lab). Declining ability to do so translates to a full reliance on the LMCF (hourly users-fees are set between $22.05–$26.25 for point-scanning confocals, and $33.60 for multi- photon). The added costs will be unsustainable. It will also incur extraordinary hardship for the many hours of on-hand training (typically provided by the PI and a senior trained personnel, to postdoc) needed to initiate each new trainee. Research strategy  The goal is to achieve the originally planned research using the requested microscope (a NIKON Ti2-E microscope with CREST V2 spinning disc components). The new microscope will be many generations advanced from the NIKON E800 and the added spinning confocal capability will provide an enhanced imaging capability before advancing to the microscopes in the LMCF. Proposed activities: A. Pollen and pollen-derived molecular trigger-induced stigmatic cell responses to initiate pollen hydration and germination. Figs. 1, 2 are examples of how we shall meet our imaging needs.  • Typically (Fig. 1A), we monitor hydration for 10-30 minutes (Wildtype completes in 10, mutants take longer). We use epifluorescence to monitor the rise or fall in nitric oxide (NO) or ROS (not shown), which do not require the resolution of confocal imaging, but extended time on the microscope. The next is pollen tube emergence and penetration of the stigmatic papilla cell (Fig. 1B). This relies on confocal imaging. Fig. 1B shows one hr after pollination, when a pollen tube is seen attached to a papilla cell. The goal is to monitor pollen hydration and tube germination with papilla cell responses [revealed by, e.g., Ca2+, water channel (see Fig. 2) cell wall quality reporters] over the time course. The requested microscope will provide on-hand training for students and collect preliminary observations for the optimal time frame for each response to guide the more refined imaging needs at the LMCF. Fig. 1A. (upper) Wide-field imaging  of stigmatic NO response upon  pollination. (Lower) Bright-field, time  course of wildtype pollen hydration  from time of deposition to full  hydration (published). Fig. 1B. Point-  confocal scanning image of a  germinating pollen tube (acquired in  LMCF). New student acquired images.  • Fig. 2 (next page) shows how we shall examine stigmatic cell responses to pollen-derived molecular trigger (pollen coat protein-Bγ, PCP-Bγ) partially on the requested microscope (Fig. 2A) and partially at the LMCF (Fig. 1B). Typically, and using Ca2+ dynamics as an example, we screen the efficacy of recombinant molecules by bright-field (top) and epifluorescence (bottom) (Fig. 2A, the green fluorescence shows extracellular Ca2+, reflecting efflux from the papilla).  The determined optimum reagent, dosage and time frame (requiring  considerable microscope time) will inform on experimental conditions used for confocal microscopy to acquire refined data (Fig. 2B,  acquired by point-scanning confocal at the LMCF).  • Fig. 2C shows how the trigger PCP-Bγ had impacted the activation (reflected by higher plasma-membrane intensity of the probe aquaporin- Cherry). The images were acquired on a Crest V2 demo session. The proof of principle experiment provides solid support and justification to move forward to higher spatial resolution point-scanning confocal or high-resolution STORM microscope at the LMCF. The savings based on using the requested microscope will allow higher qualitative and quantitative achievements.  Fig. 2A (legend). Pollen trigger PCP-Bg induced Ca2+ efflux from papilla cells. Co-imaging (upper, bright-field; lower, epifluorescence). Pilot experiments to  establish MBP-PCP-Bg has higher efficacy. Fig. 2B. Point-scanning confocal  image of MBP-PCP-Bg-triggered papilla cell Ca2+ efflux, permitting considerably higher resolution details. Fig. 2C. PCP-Bγ-induced enhance membrane  association of aquaporin, facilitating water transfer to hydrate deposited pollen  grains. Acquired by a demo on CREST V2. B. Another goal of the parent grant is to reveal how the target female cells respond when pollen tubes approach, arrive, penetrate and burst to release sperm for fertilization. We can refine the temporal and spatial windows (e.g., see Fig. 3A,B, under semi-in vivo condition where access to imaging is easier), which takes a lot of time, on the requested microscope. The we migrate to the LMCF to monitor detailed dynamics of ovule responses. Fully in vivo experiments are even more challenging. Fig. 3C shows a typical time course for in-vivo pollination. Typically, we establish the pollen tube front (arrow) migration rate using the requested microscope. The information will inform on how to set up higher-resolution experiments that monitor the female cell dynamics during pollen tube entry and burst with the microscopes in the LMCF.  Fig. 3. (A) Pollen tube growth and  targeting under semi-in vivo conditions.  (B) Monitoring the process over three to  four hours from the start of observation  till completion of pollen tube burst and  sperm release in our basic set up for  these experiments. these were acquired  by the E800 a couple of years ago. (C)  typical preliminary experiments to define  the pollen tube front achievable in the  E800 and will be done on the requested microscopes. C. Training and maintenance plan. Four frequent users (currently one senior research associate, 3 graduate students) and 3-4 new trainees (1 new graduate student, 3 undergrads) will be initiated on the microscope. The PI and senior research associate (Dr. Mingche Liu) will be responsible for training; Dr. Liu will be charged with upkeep duties and training of students on general equipment care after each use. The proximity of the requested microscope to the lab and PI’s office allows close supervision at the beginning and drop-in help and consultations as needed. We will also have access to consultation with the LMCF staff as needed and for transition to use the facility there. After the initial warranty (five years on the microscope, 1 year on electrical and third-party parts), service contracts will be financed partially by a budget allocation from the parent grant and partially from departmental contribution based on the lab’s research activities. We anticipate a low level of sharing (< 10%) from departmental colleagues’ labs; their use will be prorated towards a contribution for service expenses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reversal learning, a form of cognitive flexibility, is impaired in schizophrenia, substance use disorders, and other psychiatric and neurologic conditions, but we lack adequate treatments for these debilitating impairments. This proposal will investigate the role of the thalamus in regulating acetylcholine release in the striatum during reversal learning. This research will provide insight into brain circuit specific control of neuromodulation and learning that will influence future development of treatments for impaired cognitive flexibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Molecular communication across cell types is central to life—communication between cell types in a human organ is critical to normal function, and microbe-host or microbe-microbe communication drives microbial ecosystems. This proposal will study signaling between human immune cells and fibroblasts and signaling between microbes relevant for human health (e.g., commensal and pathogenic bacteria and fungi). We will develop a suite of microfluidic tools to broaden the scope of mechanistic questions that can be addressed, ultimately enabling the development of therapies to target dysfunctional signaling and inflammation in human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Chronic musculoskeletal pain is a significant public health problem that is often refractory to available pain management strategies, and new, non-opioid treatments are urgently needed. Increasing evidence shows that colored light delivered to the retina can relieve pain. This proposal will elucidate the neural mechanisms of pain relief driven by light by recording from neurons in the retina, tracing retinal inputs throughout the brain in rodent pain models, and identifying central targets in humans using functional neuroimaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rural legally involved youth have high substance use rates yet cannot access needed prevention resources. We will codesign a multilevel substance/overdose prevention intervention with diverse multisector partners and input from a broad advisory board. We will use a stepped wedge hybrid 2 design to evaluate implementation success/effectiveness in 15 rural county courts and 470 youth (360 complete cases).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project description  Sterols are critical for the structure of eukaryotic cells and serve as important signaling molecules. Some bacteria also engage with these lipids, but the molecular mechanisms of these engagements are not known. Inspired by our recent discovery of bacterial proteins that transport sterols, we seek to uncover the molecular determinants of sterol recognition and transport in other bacteria, including pathogens and the gut microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondria are essential for cellular function and maintain their health through dynamic properties including fusion, division and transport on microtubules. Mitochondrial dysfunction is associated with neurodegeneration and mitochondrial fusion is protective against declining function. This proposal seeks to understand the molecular machinery that mediates mitochondrial fusion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: As the human population ages, the ability to maintain cognitive function with a brain accumulating tau pathology relies on the preservation and maintenance of synaptic networks. Therefore, understanding the mechanism by which tau contributes to network and synapse dysfunction is critical for developing preventative therapeutics. This proposal aims to determine the cellular mechanisms(s) by which pathologic tau drives neuronal network dysfunction and propose a training plan catered to the applicant that will promote success as an independent researcher in the field of aging research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The aim of this proposal is to determine how microglia, the central nervous system macrophages, contribute to disease progression in models of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) and Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD). I will explore how loss of expression of a proinflammatory molecule, gasdermin-D, impacts survival and changes microglial immune responses in two discrete mouse models of ALS and FTD. This will further our understanding of how microglial reactivity impacts neuron health and potentially unveil novel druggable targets to ameliorate disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The short-term goal of this K99/R00 application is the development of the PI as an independent investigator skilled in the use of participatory systems science and community-engaged approaches to select and adapt an intervention, lung cancer prevention and risk reduction interventions, and intervention development and implementation science. The proposed research will select and adapt an intervention protocol to reduce lung cancer risk among Central Appalachian Kentucky women through a community-engaged process and will pilot test the selected intervention using a two-armed randomized controlled trial. The long-term goal is to reduce lung cancer disparities among Appalachian women and for the PI to become an independent researcher and expert in community-engaged intervention development for cancer risk reduction among Appalachian women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Many cortical and subcortical brain regions work together to coordinate social emotional brain states. In this study we propose to build a model from experimental data that explains how these regions work together to generate aggression. We will test this model using established and emerging therapeutics utilized to treat aggression in the clinic, and we will develop new brain stimulation methodologies to regulate aggressive brain states uncovered by our model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Below is the Original Narrative to fill this Mandatory Field PROJECT NARRATIVE  Adaptive genome evolution has produced the remarkable diversity of life on Earth, yet it is also the process by which pathogens and cancers resist drug treatments and evade the immune system. High- throughput experimental evolution is a powerful and versatile technique that provides a way to test evolutionary theory in the laboratory with exquisite control over experimental parameters. By identifying the genes and pathways that respond to selective pressures, the proposed experiments will not only advance our understanding of the process of adaptive evolution but will lead to new mechanistic insights into how genetic variation produces the phenotypes on which selection acts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Ciguatera fish poisoning (CFP) is a form of seafood poisoning that affects tens of thousands of people on an annual basis, and is expected to increase with climate change impacts. There is no practical way to screen seafood to safeguard for consumption, nor reliable diagnoses and treatment options for people afflicted with CFP. The Greater Caribbean Center for Ciguatera Research aims to identify the mechanisms of toxin production and transport into at-risk seafood, and to examine the mechanisms of toxicity on a cellular level, in order to better protect and treat people from this malady in an era of climate change processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Our studies will reveal how immune receptors recognize and respond to viral infections; understanding their fundamental biochemical properties will pave ways to develop new antivirals, vaccine adjuvants, immune activators. Our research will provide the mechanisms of enzymes that transcribe and replicate the human mitochondrial DNA whose maintenance is vital for energy production. This foundational knowledge will provide the basis to discover treatments for mitochondrial related diseases caused by malfunctions of these enzymes.

PHR: Project Narrative This application seeks to continue long-standing support for the UCSD Medical Scientist (M.D./Ph.D.) Training Program (MSTP), which combines both M.D. (through an Integrated Scientific Curriculum in the UCSD School of Medicine) and Ph.D. training in areas of the biomedical sciences, including cellular and molecular biology, neuroscience, and bioengineering. Excellent trainees are recruited throughout the United States and graduates typically pursue careers as academic physician scientists. This MSTP has evolved through not only expanding research opportunities and support at UCSD and affiliated institutions (Salk Institute for Biological Sciences and the Scripps Research Institute) but also growing a pool of diverse, high quality applicants and faculty.

PHR: Project Narrative Faithful segregation of chromosomes underlies genome integrity in all organisms. My R01GM141242 project aims to identify the mechanisms by which broadly conserved structural maintenance of chromosomes (SMC) complexes organize and compact replicated chromosomes in the cell. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy has revolutionized the treatment of relapsed and refractory hematologic malignancies; however, the immunologic impact and risk for infections and mortality following treatment have not been well-characterized. This Career Development Award focuses on applying advanced clinical epidemiology and simulation modeling to understand the immunologic impact of CAR T-cell therapy. Our overall objective is to identify predictive risk factors and cost-effective screening methods to allow for risk stratification, protocols for immunologic monitoring, and initiation of earlier interventions to mitigate the risk for morbidity and mortality and improve quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The accumulation of hidden genetic variants over generations potentially represents a mechanism by which complex multigenic traits can be suddenly revealed in response to environmental challenge. This proposal aims to use the natural case of eye variation in the blind cavefish, Astyanax mexicanus, as a model for vertebrate cryptic variation. By leveraging the strength of systematic analysis in the zebrafish, we will dissect out the specific molecular mechanism by which the chaperone molecule, Hsp90, buffers cryptic variants that contributed to the evolution of eye-loss in the Astyanax cavefish.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-translational modifications of histones and transcription factors are critical to gene function and misregulated in several diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with inherited bone marrow failure syndromes have significant morbidity and mortality due to complications of aplasia and myelodysplasia. These patients have no curative options other than hematopoietic stem cell transplant and no proven medical therapies are available. This proposal aims to determine which patients with inherited bone marrow failure will develop hematopoietic complications and identify a specific therapeutic target for these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Anastasis is a newly discovered cell recovery phenomenon that enables dying cells to survive by reversing the apoptotic cell death process. The mechanisms and consequences of anastasis remain unclear. By developing a biosensor to detect anastasis in live animals, and identifying key regulators of anastasis, our project will develop critical tools and knowledge to study the physiological, pathological, and therapeutic implications of anastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Rising suicide fatality rates in the US underscore the need to identify novel and effective therapeutic targets for suicide risk, beyond existing monoamine-focused treatments such as antidepressants. Evidence suggests that glutamatergic neurotransmission is important to the pathophysiology of suicide. This project will assess alterations in brain glutamatergic signaling both at rest and during task-related activity in depressed individuals at risk for suicidal behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative All living organisms produce and release small extracellular vesicles. In humans, they have been implicated in cell-to-cell communication and pathological conditions such as neurodegenerative and cardiovascular diseases and cancer progression. This project seeks to acquire a device to measure size, amount, and surface properties of extracellular vesicles and other types of small nanoparticles. The device is a critical tool for researchers using the presence of extracellular vesicles as a diagnostic indicator for disease and co-opting extracellular vesicles or synthetic nanoparticles to deliver therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to develop an effective universal overdose prevention intervention for youth given rising overdose deaths for youth, and the risks associated with fentanyl and other emerging drugs in the drug supply. Primary care providers provide anticipatory guidance for injury prevention to youth as part of annual physical exams and are therefore well positioned to deliver a universal overdose prevention intervention. An effective universal overdose prevention intervention will directly benefit youth by decreasing their risk, and will benefit public health generally as they will be more prepared to recognize and respond to others who have an overdose.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Comorbid Childhood Apraxia of Speech (CAS), a motor speech disorder affecting speech movement planning, may be one factor limiting the ability of some minimally verbal children with autism to acquire spoken language. This project aims to identify a cohort of minimally verbal children who meet criteria for autism and CAS and, using kinematic analysis of speech, to quantify how CAS affects speech movement consistency and precision. The relationship of speech movement parameters, intelligibility, and signs of CAS will be investigated in order to identify movements that are both disordered and intelligibility-reducing. These procedures will be used to create a set of mono- and bisyllabic stimuli, unique to each participant, that can reveal whether CAS-specific treatment, appropriately modified for minimally verbal children with autism, improves their speech.

PHR: Narrative During the critical search for drugs to treat COVID-19 patients, it’s important to select drugs with maximum antiviral efficacy and minimal side-effects. Using a combination of computer modeling and animal studies, we will test the potential for COVID-19 therapies to cause hearing loss; a side-effect of many drugs not often detected during clinical trials. Our goal is to help develop safer COVID-19 therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood obesity is a major public health concern, particularly among Latino and Black children, who experience a disproportionate burden, compared to white children. The proposed research is focused on understanding the impacts of vertical microbiome transmission on childhood overweight and obesity outcomes in Latino and Black populations. Understanding the role that vertical microbiome transmission plays in the development of childhood obesity may have far-reaching public health implications and is critical for developing novel interventions and therapies to prevent childhood obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nager syndrome (OMIM#154400) is a developmental disorder characterized by hypoplasia of the facial bones and a variety of limb defects. Mutations in the SF3B4 gene, which encodes a protein involved in the maturation of pre-mRNA, is a major cause for Nager syndrome. In this application I propose to gain novel insights into the mechanisms underlying Nager syndrome craniofacial defects through in vivo and in vitro modeling of the disease, and carry that knowledge over to the modeling of other craniofacial disorders to determine if there is a common root cause.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative While obesity accounts for over 50% of septic surgical patients and is independently associated with 90-day mortality, the mechanism underlying how obesity modulates sepsis outcomes is lacking, particularly in surgical patients. This proposal will integrate mechanistic in vitro studies with sophisticated murine modeling of obesity and intra-abdominal sepsis to provide crucial data on possible therapeutic targets to mitigate the disparities in mortality between obese and non-obese septic surgical patients. This proposal has the potential to deliver fundamental insight into disease regulation and novel therapeutics to optimize sepsis management in a highly relevant clinical patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Protein arginylation is increasingly recognized as a global biological regulator essential for physiological processes, including angiogenesis, embryogenesis, aging, and cell migration. ATE1 is the sole enzyme responsible for protein arginylation and has recently been implicated in human cancers and neurodegenerative diseases, but its catalytic mechanism and regulation remain poorly understood. This project aims to understand the structural, catalytic, and regulatory mechanisms of protein arginylation, which may lead to new therapeutic strategies for preventing the development and progression of Parkinson’s disease and Metastatic Cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Project Narrative: Adolescents with a chronic medical condition (A-CMC) have high rates of risky drinking and drug use and account for the majority of pediatric inpatient hospitalizations. However, A-CMCs are not routinely screened for alcohol use in pediatric inpatient settings, highlighting a major missed opportunity. This mentored research proposal will facilitate the implementation of SBIRT in inpatient units within a large urban pediatric hospital, while providing preliminary data to inform the development of a highly scalable approach that can be used in pediatric hospitals across the country.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Reducing the incidence of devastating birth defects requires a mechanistic understanding of cell signaling and force transmission in developing tissues. My lab uses Drosophila to investigate force generation by the actomyosin cytoskeleton and its regulation within cells and across tissues. These studies will provide insight into the interplay between contractile signaling and force generation, providing a framework for understanding emergent tissue shapes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative It is estimated that 10-25% of human embryos have the wrong number of chromosomes, resulting in a high incidence of miscarriages and birth defects. Most of these abnormalities are the result of mistakes generated when female reproductive cells (oocytes) divide, yet surprisingly little is known about the mechanisms that underlie the vulnerability of oocytes to these errors. This project seeks to gain insight into this important question, focusing on the assembly and stabilization of a structure called the spindle that mediates the segregation of chromosomes during cell division.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE Cardiovascular, kidney and metabolic diseases are the leading causes of mortality and morbidity in the United States, especially in Mississippi which has the highest prevalence in the nation of these diseases. This is a critical area for research development in Mississippi in view of the emerging opportunities to develop a comprehensive, multidisciplinary research center at UMMC that focuses on these major causes of mortality and morbidity. This proposal represents a plan for continued development, via Phase 3 COBRE funding, of a unique, Cardiorenal and Metabolic Diseases Research Center (CMDRC) that is dedicated to improving lives through research, discovery, innovation, and translation to prevent and reduce death and disability from cardiorenal and metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: It has been a major unmet medical need for the development of efficient brain delivery across the blood-brain barrier with wide distribution of the therapeutic macromolecules to many types of brain cells in treating a wide variety of neurological diseases. The goal of this project is to develop a novel platform with advanced brain delivery of therapeutic proteins by coalescing in vivo epigenetic alteration of microRNA with targeted gene transfer and restricted transgene expression for improved CNS treatment of Hurler syndrome, a neurologic lysosomal storage disease (nLSD). Such therapeutic approach would have significant and broad application across many other nLSDs or neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will construct a consensus atlas of cell types in the mammalian entorhinal cortex, a region critical for memory and navigation and vulnerable to pathology. It leverages advanced single nucleus multiomic sequencing and spatial transcriptomics to elucidate the composition and molecular evolution of cell types across 14 species, including humans and diverse model organisms. Jessie Puckett will receive comprehensive computational and biological training in this multi-disciplinary effort, enhancing the project with detailed analyses of evolutionary changes and contributing to a broader understanding of brain function and disease susceptibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Membrane homeostasis is a fundamental aspect of cell function and requires the coordinated control of multiple metabolic activities, including phospholipases involved in lipid turnover and acyltransferases involved in lipid synthesis and remodeling. Defects in membrane lipid homeostasis can contribute to the development of many diseases, including obesity, diabetes, and cancer. The proposed studies characterize a novel acyltransferase and its affect on membrane homeostasis and cell physiology. The requested Sapphire FL Biomolecular Imager provides enhanced capabilities for the performance of research essential to the grant.

In this proposal I will characterize mechanisms of regulation and induced stabilization of the oncogenic Myc family transcription factors, specifically the stabilizing influence of Aurora Kinase A (AurA). These AurA-Myc in- teractions and other regulatory protein interactions will be structurally characterized and probed in cancerous cellular environments to determine their physiological relevance. These studies will serve as a basis for under- standing the mechanisms governing Myc dysregulation, responsible for 30% of all cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Principal Investigator/Program Director (Last, First, Middle): Afonin, Kirill, A PROJECT NARRATIVE  Beyond their traditionally known roles as carriers and regulators of genetic information, nucleic acids have auspiciously emerged as versatile therapies for taking advantage of cellular pathways to drive the sensing, targeting, and silencing of a variety of diseases. With MIRA support, we will explore additional nanotechnology- based therapeutic options that enlist a biocompatible nucleic acid-encoded platform (SMART NANPs) for the controlled immunostimulation and modulation of therapeutic responses. This research program aims to advance the envisioned technology towards personalized medicine and aid in addressing top public health challenges in the U.S. as they relate to cancer (through vaccines and immunotherapies), cardiovascular diseases (through regulated coagulation), and drug overdose and safety (through the biodegradable nature of the platform and its functional regulation).

PHR: Project Narrative As residents of the human body and the biosphere, microbial communities perform essential metabolic processes for maintaining human health. At present we do not understand how the genomic structure of microbial communities, and the environment in which they reside, gives rise to their emergent metabolic processes. With to goal of ultimately designing and controlling communities of microbes to improve human health, this project aims to discover the principles governing how environmental variation impacts the metabolism of microbial collectives.

PHR: NARRATIVE The high tissue penetrability of ultrasound (US) waves presents untapped and exciting opportunities for accessing structures throughout the mammalian brain. In this supplement to our RF1 project, we will further advance methods pioneered in our labs to extend the depth penetration and resolution of optoacoustic imaging to support whole-brain functional imaging of distributed neuronal activity in scattering tissue, with a focus on the olfactory bulb in awake, behaving animals. These developments would break new ground in the field of brain function in large mammalian brains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is a complex, devastating public health concern with interrelated issues of a lack of adequate available treatments, and limited understanding of the underlying pathophysiology. FDA-approved for the treatment of treatment-resistant depression (TRD), repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is a non-invasive neuromodulation intervention that has both immense therapeutic potential and a conceivable role in elucidating the pathophysiology of disease in multiple other psychiatric conditions, including suicide. The purpose of this project is to demonstrate the anti-suicidal efficacy of a new rTMS treatment paradigm (bilateral accelerated theta burst stimulation; [bilateral aTBS]) and enhance our understanding of the neurophysiological signature and treatment targets for individuals with TRD and suicidal ideation using combined TMS and electroencephalography (TMS-EEG), with the ultimate public health and patient care goals of reducing the morbidity and mortality of suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative/Abstract Heterocycles and strained rings are valuable motifs in pharmaceuticals and natural products, thus highlighting the need for unique ways to access them. The K99 phase will establish the first total syntheses of azetidine- containing metabolites that affect biofilm and pigment production in the pathogenic bacterium P. aeruginosa; the R00 phase will center on development of distinctive methods to access multifunctional chemical building blocks. This project is relevant to the NIH’s mission because 1) in the short-term, it will expand fundamental knowledge in the synthesis of bioactive natural products and pharmaceutically relevant motifs, and 2) in the long-term, findings from biological studies of molecules in the K99 phase could lead to new anti-virulence treatments for those infected with P. aeruginosa, and methods in the R00 phase could aid in rapid access to pharmaceuticals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Protection of DNA against damages and errors are integral to maintaining genomic stability. Defects in DNA metabolic processes that replicate and repair the genome lead to genetic instability and chromosomal rearrangements causing cancers, aging, and inherited disorders. Replication Protein A is central to coordinating almost all DNA replication and repair processes in the cell and our work focuses on deciphering the underlying molecular mechanisms which can be exploited to develop novel chemotherapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The product of this research will immediately provide new, critical, and fundamental knowledge on the relative importance of mitochondrial fission adapter proteins for synaptic function. Furhter, this project will elucidate the reasons why dysfunction in the mitochondrial fission protein DRP1 is more severe than loss of mitochondrial fission adapters: we posit that DRP1 facilitates synaptic vesicle biogenesis, independent of its function in mitochondrial fission. Pursuit of this knowledge is important, as DRP1 has been identified as a therapeutic target to alleviate core causes of aging and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s Disease. The motivations for this project are to increase our basic science knowledge of synaptic function in the brain, and also enhance healthspan in populations increasingly subject to age-related neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES A. HALEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Aging and Parkinson's disease (PD). Aging is the primary risk factor for PD. Despite reported success with neurotrophic or neuroprotective therapeutic drugs or cell replacement therapies in animal models of PD, none have led to a clinically effective treatment avenue, curing all aspects of the disease complex. Inflammation in the brain, in particular, activation of microglia has been increasingly associated with the ongoing pathogenesis of PD. Aging impacts immune cell phenotype, reducing the efficacy some therapeutics. We have identified exosomes derived from human adipose derived stem cells as a potent modulator of inflammation. Exosomes are an ideal vector for delivery of neuroprotective agents because of their unique ability to home to tissues, and their increased stability compared to un-encapsulated RNA. This project seeks to establish exosomes as a therapeutic alternative for PD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Recent years have seen significant advances using targeted and immunotherapies for melanoma, but most patients remain at high risk for recurrence and metastases necessitating the need for more effective therapies. US veterans between ages 55-59, 50-54, and 45-49 are 450%, 17%, and 6% more likely to develop melanoma than the general US population. The survival rate of patients with advanced melanoma at 5 years is less than 5%. Recurrent and/metastatic melanoma is notoriously resistant to all existing forms of cancer therapies. We discovered that a protein named IL-1 receptor associated kinase-M (IRAK-M) is deficient in melanoma but plays a central role in 1) the ability for cancer cells to metastasize and 2) shutting down antitumor immune responses. We will test the novel idea that restoring IRAK-M in melanoma cells, by repurposing already FDA-approved compounds, will prevent metastases and reinstate tumor immunity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Patients with critical surgical disorders such as trauma, thermal injury, shock, sepsis, and massive surgical operations are commonly complicated with gut mucosal injury and bleeding, but effective therapies to preserve epithelial integrity are limited to date. Delayed mucosal repair causes disruption of mucosal epithelial integrity, thus contributing to morbidity and mortality. Although mucosal healing after acute injury is crucial for maintaining epithelial integrity during critical surgical stress, the exact mechanism underlying this process remains unclear. The immediate goal of this study is to define the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying intestinal epithelium homeostasis under critical surgical conditions. We will test the possibility that an important protein α4 controls gut mucosal homeostasis by altering given noncoding RNAs. Completion of these experiments will create a fundamental basis for development of novel therapies to preserve epithelial integrity in our VA patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functioning in a social group is fundamental to the human experience and is critical to the health of both the individual and society. Here, to illuminate the molecular origin of complex social behaviors, I will study a novel transcription factor whose expression in prefrontal cortex was previously determined to protect against stress- induced social deficits in laboratory rodents. I will use novel synthetic transcription factor variants, virally delivered to the prefrontal cortex of mice, and combined with behavior and transcriptomic analyses to evaluate the causal role of this transcription factor in regulating gene expression and complex social behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The human intestinal microbiota is a diverse microbial ecosystem that carries out many essential functions for human health, such that a wide range of illnesses have been linked to an altered gut microbial community. This proposal will examine the roles, ecological relevance and evolutionary dynamics of a set of mobile genes that is shared by many gut bacteria and mediates biofilm formation. This knowledge will further our understanding of intestinal ecology and its recent changes in human populations, and will provide one more key step towards the design of reliable targeted microbiome interventions for therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wnt signaling is a biological pathway that allows cells to communicate and to coordinate their behavior during animal development, tissue maintenance, and regeneration. It is also often dysregulated across a wide variety of human diseases. We are working to discover the mechanisms that allow Wnt signals to induce the activation of genes and thereby regulate changes in cell growth and differentiation. Our discoveries will be applicable to new therapeutic strategies that regulate signaling in Wnt-driven developmental disorders and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthy aging is associated with a striking paradox: As adults age, they typically have better control over their emotions while also simultaneously experiencing decline in cognitive functions and brain systems that have been associated with emotion regulation. This study will investigate the brain basis of emotion regulation in middle- and older-age adults, and how a history of depression might impact the typical pattern of age-related improvement in emotional control. Ultimately, the proposed research will help to improve quality of life for healthy older adults, while also providing treatment targets to prevent recurrence of depression for those with a depression history.

PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia worldwide. However, available therapies have not been shown to delay its onset or progression. The current application aims to understand a novel mechanism underlying lipid deficiency- induced activation of a type of brain cell (i.e., astrocytes) in AD. Positive results may lead to new understanding of AD pathogenesis and development of novel drugs for effective treatment of AD.
