IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep is an essential pillar of human health and sleep disruption later in life is believed to be a source of vulnerability in the development of Alzheimer's disease (AD), a devastating neurodegenerative condition. The proposed study will examine the mechanisms of age-related sleep disruption and its impact on the synapse. Based on our molecular understanding of sleep's restorative processes, we will test the ability of new sleep- based medicines to limit AD progression or even to reverse age-related pathology and cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is a rare disease that can cause kidney failure and liver complications and currently does not have any available FDA-approved treatments. Even though several drugs have appeared promising in animal studies, there are few clinical trials in humans due to a lack of detailed information about the natural history of ARPKD and difficulty in recruiting enough patients who are able and willing to take part in trials. The goal of this proposal is to accelerate clinical trials for ARPKD by creating PKDnet, a resource that will help to inform future clinical trial design by identifying children with ARPKD and efficiently collecting high quality, large-scale natural history data from PEDSnet, a large National Pediatric Learning Health System, and by performing patient and family surveys to identify research priorities and understand factors affecting willingness to participate in clinical trials.

PROJECT_TITLE: PKDNet - ARPKD Learning Network

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public relevance Emotional well-being is critical for maintaining quality of life and preventing dementia among older adults. A thorough understanding of the brain mechanisms of emotional well-being as well as the relationship between emotional well-being and dementia will form the basis for identification of biomarkers and intervention strategies for promoting positive well-being and preventing dementia among older adults. PHR: Project Narrative This MIRA application seeks to uncover the specific functions of a growing family of trans-editing proteins that play a universal role in maintaining the fidelity of protein synthesis. The therapeutic potential of trans-editing domains has not been exploited and represents another major gap in the field that we hope to address by our planned studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance  We wish to understand how DNA is segregated and packaged in the special filamentous organisms that produce the majority of biologically active compounds used to treat bacterial infection and cancer. These organisms are major producers of the compounds that we all rely on for our health and quality of life. Basic knowledge of fundamental cell functions of these organisms may lead to better production of known and novel compounds, which may lower the cost of buying medicines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transfer RNAs (tRNAs) are the universal adaptor molecules essential for protein synthesis in all living cells and their coordinated and accurate processing is critical to ensure production of a high-quality tRNA pool. Mutations in the human tRNA methyltransferase enzyme Trm10 are associated with a multi-faceted disease phenotype that indicates important functions for Trm10. This project will uncover how diverse Trm10 enzymes modify their specific tRNA substrates and the biological effects of the modification they introduce, to define the role of Trm10 in maintaining optimal cellular health and as a potential novel target for therapies for human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the mitonuclear interaction is altered is altered in a number of different diseases including cancer, obesity, neurodegeneration, and aging. Given that the mechanisms regulating mitonuclear interaction are conserved from yeast to humans, understanding this genetic network may allow us to identify new therapeutic targets for potential interventions for human diseases associated with harmful consequences of mitochondrial dysfunction. Therefore, the research is relevant to NIGMS’s mission in supporting basic research that increases understanding of biological processes and laying the foundation for advances in disease treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NIH SuRE Project Narrative  This NIH SuRE proposal aims to develop and utilize highly selective metal catalyzed carbon carbon bond formation reactions that will lead to efficient synthesis of novel selenium, sulfur, and oxygen-containing heterocycles with rich biological activities. Further elaboration of this chemistry will likely allow the first enantioselective synthesis of very important classes of heterocycles such as biselenoflavonoids, bithioflavonoids and bioactive biflavonoids, potential small molecule therapeutics for Alzheimer’s disease. This SuRE project is expected to significantly enhance and expand the research capacity towards a sustainable research excellence that actively involves underrepresented minority students in funded research at WSSU, a HBCU.

PHR: Project Narrative  Improving access to evidence-based mental health treatment is critical to improving outcomes for children who experience maltreatment. This study will develop and pilot strategies to improve multidisciplinary team functioning and facilitate implementation of a mental health screening and referral protocol in in rural Child Advocacy Centers. The proposed training and research will prepare the investigator to advance NIMH Strategic Objective 4.2 – “establish research-practice partnerships to improve dissemination, implementation, and continuous improvement of evidence-based mental health services” – and has the potential to positively impact public health by improving the capacity of systems in rural areas to meet the mental health needs of vulnerable children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Parent Grant 5R35GM146923-02 Narrative: Intermediate filaments are abundant cytoskeletal proteins that interact with numerous cellular proteins and contribute to a variety of cellular processes, yet we lack a complete mechanistic understanding of their function. Here we propose to interrogate how intermediate filaments are regulated and how they contribute to inflammation by focusing on the intermediate filament vimentin and its role in neutrophil inflammatory processes and trafficking. The successful completion of this proposal is highly likely to identify new mechanisms by which intermediate filaments contribute to inflammation and to cellular and tissue function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Primary cilia are microtubule-based projections on virtually every cell type and are linked to multiple signaling pathways. Among the best studied is Sonic hedgehog (Shh), which requires the cilium for signal transduction. Here we use a series of mouse models to genetically uncouple ciliogenesis and vertebrate Hh signaling, and in the process paint a clearer mechanistic picture of each. These proposed experiments have great potential to give us the fundamental knowledge we need to develop strategies to treat diseases related to abnormal cilia or Shh signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Research Strategy Our NIH award 1 R15GM152969-01 entails the synthesis and characterization of fluorescent-based probes operating in the red to near-infrared region to determine pH levels within organelles. It is critical to produce probes that would function ratiometrically as that would negate erroneous measurements based on differential diffusion rates. The syntheses of these probes involve many steps and at the end of each stage, as the compounds cannot be separated based on solubility differences, silica gel chromatography is employed. This requirement ends up adding days to the synthesis. Chromatography requires lots of glassware to do the synthesis and collect all the various fractions, not to mention the huge quantities of solvents such as dichloromethane that are utilized in these steps. Great skill is also required to prepare the columns and, while this is quite constructive, some preps are not as good as others and, in some cases, effective separation of the compounds is not accomplished. Unfortunately, we do not possess such a system in our laboratories. Our synthesis schemes are very involved,1-23 and we are going to use this equipment to purify compounds at every step of the process. We propose acquiring a preparative high-pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC) system for the purification of our reaction products, moving away from the conventional approach involving silica gel packed columns. This shift is driven by the superior capabilities of preparative HPLC, which excels in achieving enhanced resolution and improved separation of closely related compounds. Our decision is grounded in the intricate nature of our probes, composed of multiple fluorophore components linked through complex, multi-step synthetic procedures, where traditional packed silica gel column chromatography used in organic labs is often incapable of effectively separating side products with subtle structural variations. An example of one synthetic pathway is shown below. OO ,O  O  HO Pd(PPh3)4 HO  N Toluene, water O DCC, DMAP HN Toluene, acetic acid, isopropylamine  I O H O Dean Star apparatus  26 OH 100 oC, 8-h OH CH2Cl2  OH reflux OH O H HOOC O CH3SO3H N O N O H2N R1O R1  100 oC, 5 h (HO)2B OH N O R1O N  COOH I 29 O 30 25 27 28 OH 31 OOH  OR1 or  group BN OR1  R1 , sodium ascorbate, THPTA 32 FF N OR1 33 N  CuSO4 FB OR1 O H O FN  O R1 HN R1 HN N3 O O NH OS NH2 R HN O O O O 8O OH OH 36a OH R  HN  OR1 OR1 OR O  N3 O N OH  OR1 OR1 O 8 HN O OR OR HN O HN O O N 36b N  F B N FNB N FFB N  HN O OR  OH F OH F O OH N  35 N3 O O NH S Probe A1 OH FFB N  34 36c O SO3  N3 N Probe A2  R1O OR1 N or RO OR  R1 O P  N3 O 8 36e  N R Where  36d N N N N SO3  NN NN NN N O P  R group N O O N O N N O O Br N N  O NH S NH2 O O NH S 8  8 8O O  O 8 O amphiphilic zwitterion moiety  Goblegni zaepnpeasrautlufosn-sapmeicdiefic Lysomsoormpeh-oslpineecific Mitochondria-specific Cell membrane-specific  ER-specific p-toluenesulfonamide triphenylphophonium bromide Preparative HPLC provides the advantage of employing different stationary phases and fine-tuning mobile phase conditions, allowing targeted separation of complex reaction mixtures. The increased plate counts associated with HPLC columns further facilitate efficient separation, especially when dealing with high load volumes necessary for preparative-scale purifications. This not only ensures the production of higher purity products but also expedites the purification process. In the specific context of our probes, incorporating oligo(ethylene glycol) moieties with organelle-specific functional groups, preparative reverse phase HPLC is particularly advantageous. It enables the use of water-rich mobile phases, overcoming the limitations associated with silica gel normal phase column chromatography, which utilizes organic solvents that could excessively solubilize polar products, resulting in broad peaks and co-elutions. With preparative HPLC, we gain precise control over solvent strength, yielding tight, concentrated bands that can be efficiently collected at the preparative scale. Rationale: High-performance liquid chromatography is an essential technique in modern analytical chemistry, allowing for the separation, identification, and purification of chemical compounds. The preparative column with a refractive index detector is particularly valuable for our research, and the chosen system offers the following advantages:  1. High-Resolution Separation: The HPLC preparative column will provide high-resolution  separation of complex mixtures, allowing us to isolate target compounds with greater precision.  2. Purification Capability: The preparative column we are hoping to obtain is designed for 1 g of  material, making it suitable for the purification of compounds at preparative scale, a critical  aspect of our research objectives.  3. Refractive Index Detection: This will enable the detection and quantification of compounds  based on differences in their refractive indices. This will be useful for the separation of all  molecules as it is non-selective and responds to everything coming off a column. Unlike UV  detection, it does not rely on chromophores in the mixtures. Additionally some compounds have  weak UV absorptions. In essence it provides universal detection of compounds.  4. Reverse Phase: As the system is reverse phase, water or a water-based solvent can be used in the  mobile phase. This has many advantages over normal phase HPLC including lower costs  compared to other HPLC methods, less toxicity, accurate results, reduced solvent evaporation (as  polar solvents utilized), can change pH to affect separation, elimination of skewed analyte  retention times, and increased accuracy of gradient separations.  5. Non-toxic solvent use: Finally, another significant advantage is the ability to analyze samples  containing polar (hydrophilic), non-polar (hydrophobic), ionic, and ionizable compounds, due to  the use of a hydrophobic stationary phase. Benefits to NIH: The acquisition of the proposed HPLC preparative column with a UV detector will not only advance our research capabilities but also align with the NIH's mission to support groundbreaking scientific discoveries. The resulting research outcomes will contribute to the understanding of ratiometric fluorescent probes, with implications for the development of new diagnostic tools, therapeutic agents, or other applications that align with the NIH's broader goals. Conclusion: The acquisition of a preparative HPLC system is motivated by its unparalleled resolving power, flexible solvent options, and scalability in purifications. This strategic shift addresses the challenges inherent in the composition of our probes, ensuring efficient and high-quality purification tailored for their intended biomedical imaging applications. The chemistry department will maintain and preserve this instrument beyond the 3-year timeline of the NIH proposal GM152969. A confirmation letter from the department chair Dr. Athar Ata is attached.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: We seek to construct biocompatible chemical tools that can interrogate the dynamic molecular events of living systems across space and time. By embedding highly eﬃcient reactions within 2D/3D nucleic acid scaﬀolds, we will build toolkits with the speed and sensitivity to capture the deep complexity of living cells and tissues. With architectures that can translate chemical events into new sequence information, we aim to erase boundaries between in vivo chemistry and nucleic acid biotechnologies, transforming (bio)molecular tracking and sensing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many pathogenic bacteria are notorious for surviving harsh environments, adapting to different niches in the human body, and developing tolerance to drug treatments, all examples of phenotypic plasticity. Cellular organizations, as a hallmark of cell phenotype, dictate the physiological state and fitness of bacteria, and unraveling the origins and consequences of its plasticity is key to understanding the survival, growth, adaption, and drug tolerance of pathogenic bacteria. Exploring the optimality principles for the cellular organization could help identify bottlenecking cellular processes that can serve as non-molecular-specific targets with minimal concerns of rising drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We focus on highly characterized bacterial RNA polymerases, which have a high degree of conservation of structure and function from bacteria to man. The bacterial RNA polymerase is a proven target for antimicrobials, such as rifampicin (or its derivatives), widely used in combination therapy to treat tuberculosis, but bacterial strains resistant to rifampicin arise with appreciable frequency, compromising treatment. Insights into the mechanism of bacterial transcription, as well as into the inhibition mechanism of inhibitors, can lead to new avenues for the development of antimicrobials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: Project Narrative The CAG microsatellite expansion diseases are a large group of rare neurodegenerative and neuromuscular diseases including spinocerebellar ataxias (SCAs) and Huntington’s disease (HD). Our preliminary data and lessons learned from other repeat expansion disease suggest that targeting the repeat expansion mutation that underlies many of these SCAs and HD will provide therapeutic potential across multiple diseases. Here we will test whether CAG SCA lead candidate compounds are capable of providing therapeutic benefit in HD models and whether combining our RNA regulating compounds with protein regulating compounds can enhance this therapeutic benefit.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: The botulinum neurotoxins are some of the deadliest known yet are also revered for their pharmaceutical utility. These toxins are marvels of protein evolution able to inject a toxic cargo enzyme into a specific cell type using a self-contained delivery system. Our unique combination of expertise in single molecule imaging, molecular simulations and protein-engineering will allow us to answer long- standing questions about the delivery mechanism by overcoming the structural heterogeneity that challenged previous studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The application of chemical properties to alter the reactivity of reagents for the synthesis of biomedically important compounds provides an opportunity to enhance the biomedical sciences. The chemical properties of hydrogen-bond-donor organocatalysts will enable the general, selective synthesis of 2-deoxy-β-glycosides, which remains elusive despite the importance of carbohydrates in biological systems, biological chemistry and medicine. Additionally, the properties of sulfur and the C–S bond will provide novel photochromic materials, addressing the stagnant synthetic approach to Stenhouse adducts, which are used in drug delivery, dynamic phase transfer, polymers, liquid crystals, wavelength-selective photoswitching, and chemosensing applications.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Congenital Central Hypoventilation Syndrome (CCHS) is a rare and complex disease, causing a life-threatening inability to regulate breathing and oxygen levels necessitating life-long ventilatory support, in addition to severe Hirschsprung disease, neural crest tumors, and autonomic co-morbidities. Despite limited treatment options and no cures, recent advances in pharmacology, bio-technology, and understanding of the molecular underpinnings of CCHS have paved the way for clinical trials that could advance treatment and reduce morbidity and mortality for these patients. This project will merge traditionally siloed CCHS data, expertise, resources and cohorts to capture extensive, longitudinal natural history data using rigorously defined protocols, common data elements, and established measures reflecting patient and caregiver voices, enriching knowledge of CCHS, establish measures that best correlate with disease severity, inform therapeutic development, and accelerate progress toward clinical trials.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Progressing toward clinical trial readiness in CCHS: Natural history study to incorporate patient voice, harmonize clinical and registry data, and standardize assessments

These molecules, and their interactions, regulate the complex cellular processes underlying many devastating diseases. Specifically, the technologies developed in this Resource are being used to advance our understanding of many human conditions including diabetes, Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, and heart disease, among others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative from active award number R16GM149204 There has been little innovation in the development of the new analgesic drugs that target novel mechanisms of action. We will focus on the structure-activity relationship studies, biological evaluation, behavioral testing, and optimization of the new dual inhibitors of soluble epoxide hydrolase and fatty acid amide hydrolase enzymes, to increase the levels of anti-inflammatory and analgesic metabolites in the body. Through in vitro and in vivo studies, we aim to demonstrate that the designed dual inhibitors are effectively inhibiting both aforementioned enzymes simultaneously, are metabolically stable, and can produce pain relief in a rat model of chronic inflammatory pain with the potential to become novel, safe, and effective non-opioid treatments for patients suffering from chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Mitosis is the process by which duplicated sister chromosomes are evenly distributed to identical daughter cells, and in cancer cells, improper chromosome segregation during mitosis (e.g., such that chromosomes are unevenly distributed between daughter cells) is widely observed, and has been linked to poor prognosis, including decreased overall survival time and fewer treatment free years. In this study, we will make use of physical principles and advanced microscopy to evaluate the role of controlled forces in ensuring proper chromosome segregation during mitosis, and to dissect the role of microtubule structure in the targeting of microtubule- associated proteins. The results generated from our studies will be applicable both towards better understanding the fundamental biophysics of cell division, and also towards providing mechanistic information to shed light on current cancer therapies.

PHR: Project Narrative  The overall goal of this proposal is to elucidate the cellular and molecular mechanisms governing the assembly of motor and sensory circuits required for coordinated movement. Our studies will investigate the role of cell fate determinants in establishing synaptic specificity in spinal circuits, and determine how developmental programs contribute to the emergence of specific motor behaviors. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Tight junctions (TJs) are protein assemblies involved in cell adhesion and intercellular transport of molecules through endothelial and epithelial tissues. While many proteins amass at TJs, two families of membrane proteins predominate TJ assembly, organization, and function. The goals of this research are to establish a fundamental understanding of how these two membrane protein families structurally assemble TJs, to identify how their disassembly contributes to TJ dysfunction, and to apply this knowledge by creating new strategies for tissue-specific treatment of TJ-linked diseases in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance In all living organisms, a molecular machine called the ribosome synthesizes proteins, and decodes the genetic code of messenger RNA (mRNA) in the process of translation. Some mRNAs are translated orders of magnitude more efficiently than the others for reasons that are poorly understood. Translational control by mRNA structure plays an important role in cancer development, and is critical for the infectivity of human viruses such as immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and SARS-CoV-2, which causes the COVID-19 pandemic. We study how structural signals in mRNA regulate translation. Our studies will provide the basis for future development of antiviral and cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRI & TECH ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed study seeks to examine the combined effect of lead (Pb), cadmium (Cd), mercury (Hg), perfluorooctane sulfonic acid (PFOS), and perfluorinated alkylated substances (PFOA) on stress, cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk and CVD mortality. The primary analysis will include: (1) assessing the effects of Pb, Cd, Hg, PFOA, and PFOS exposures on individual and neighborhood stress and (2) determining the effects of Pb, Cd, Hg, PFOA, and PFOS exposures on CVD risk and mortality. This study will help close the gap in knowledge of the effects of multiple environmental pollutants on stress and cardiovascular health and will further our understanding of the role that the social environment and the physical environment pose for potentially serious health risks to individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Stiffening and disorganization of the extracellular matrix (ECM) can serve as important cellular cues that can promote degenerative processes. The proposed study will determine the relevance of substrate stiffness and topography on the activation of the mechanoreceptor TRPV4 in annulus fibrosus cells and will elucidate whether TRPV4 regulates ECM synthesis/remodeling. Investigating cell-substrate interactions in the annulus fibrosus is of high significance as it will help to properly understand mechanotransduction processes underlying spinal health and disease (e.g. intervertebral disc herniation) and advance tissue engineering approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is a malignant primary brain cancer which carries a dismal prognosis. STAT3 has been shown to be a very attractive therapeutic target for GBM; albeit, small molecule inhibitors of STAT3 signaling are ineffective, as they exhibit very poor blood brain barrier permeability. Our interdisciplinary team will develop and evaluate a novel and scalable bi-compartmental nanoparticle delivery system that allows controlled co-release of STAT3 siRNA and the chemotherapeutic agent, paclitaxel. This work may result in a new treatment modality for GBM, a tumor type, for which no effective treatments exist.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Natural products are a critical component of modern medicine and discovery of new molecules and pathways has the opportunity to positively impact human health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Biological patterning relies on the coordination of cell-cell communication events across large and small distances, and defects in patterning can lead to human disorders and disease. Cytonemes are one example of an active cell process that coordinates cell signaling for many patterning events during vertebrate and invertebrate development. The goal of this work is to understand both how cytonemes are regulated at the cellular scale and how they contribute to the overall progression of patterning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will tackle a challenge central to public health – understanding the cellular and molecular mechanisms controlling tissue degeneration, regeneration and return to homeostasis in vertebrates – using a comparative approach of organisms that demonstrate varying degrees of natural and cyclical tissue degeneration and regeneration. These efforts will provide insight into mechanisms underlying tissue patterning and homeostasis and the pathological states of hypertrophy and degenerative disease. The specialized equipment requested in this supplement will not only enhance the acquisition of data from current experiments addressing these goals, but will also propel the development of innovative new comparative approaches for answering the overarching questions of the parent award.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Results from the proposed study are expected to provide fundamental knowledge on the role of sensory experience-mediated changes in chromatin and gene expression in flexible behavior. The proposed experiments will identify basic epigenetic, molecular, and circuit principles by which the environment induces changes in gene expression to alter the function of an individual or ensemble of neurons within a circuit and ultimately modify organismal behaviors. Thus, our findings may lead to novel and cheaper sensory experience-based therapeutic strategies that harness similar types of plasticity against psychiatric disorders, such as autism spectrum disorders, and depressive and anxiety disorders, where misprocessing of sensory information accentuates anxiety and social behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences max) Focal Cortical Dysplasias (FCDs) are among the most common epilepsy-associated structural brain lesions and we and others have shown that 60-90% of patients with FCD type I (FCD I) and FCD type II (FCD II) lack any genetic abnormality when using currently available testing methods. We propose the most comprehensive genetic analysis to date of a unique cohort of FCD I and II patients with unprecedented deep clinical phenotyping. A better understanding of the genetic basis of FCD etiology will lead to the introduction of novel gene-based diagnostic strategies and targeted drugs to fully manage a patient's seizures while avoiding the spectrum of side effects typically associated with current therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Repeat expansion in C9ORF72 gene is the most common cause of both amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and Frontotemporal dementia (FTD), two adult onset neurodegeneration diseases. Dysfunction of RNA metabolisms has emerged to play crucial roles in disease etiology. Based on recent findings, we propose to decipher how the dysregulation of RNA modification affect the toxic repeat products and disturb the global gene network, and determine whether targeting the dysfunctional epitranscriptomic pathway can rescue the disease- related phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The organelle trans-Golgi network (TGN) serves as the major sorting compartment and the center for modifications of newly synthesized proteins. In this proposal we aim to dissect the conserved molecular and cellular mechanisms governing TGN remodeling by microbial factors and study the effects on eukaryotic cellular processes. Our discoveries will advance our understanding of TGN morphology maintenance and functions, which will lay the foundation for rational design of therapeutics for a wide variety of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary cilium is an antenna-like cellular protrusion that allows cells to respond to external signals that instruct cell growth, differentiation, and proliferation. Aberrant ciliary signaling causes pediatric syndromes and can promote cancer development, while imbalances in cilium assembly versus disassembly are commonly observed in tumors and may contribute to uncontrolled cell growth. This proposal aims to improve our understanding of the roles of primary cilia in health and disease by elucidating the molecular pathways that underlie cilium formation, function, and disassembly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Musculoskeletal disease is one of the leading causes of disability and health care expenses where an estimated 126.6 million Americans (one in two adults) are affected by a musculoskeletal condition costing an estimated $213 billion each year in treatment and lost wages. With an aging population, this figure is only set to increase and become worse since research is hampered by a low and slow rate of translation of basic discoveries into clinical practice, e.g. only 25% of highly promising biomedical discoveries resulted in a published randomized clinical trial and less than 10% were established in clinical practice within 20 years. This COBRE center implements a new concept for translational research, i.e. Virtual Human Trials, to expedite the process from concept development to new deliverable therapeutics, interventions, and devices for musculoskeletal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Mosaic chromosomal alterations (mCA) are a type of somatic mosaicism characterized by large chromosomal gains or losses. This proposal will develop novel approaches to quantify and localize mCA in kidney, blood and other non-neoplastic tissues to better understand how they contribute to aging and chronic disease. These efforts may help to identify cells with a high burden of mCA, which may lead to novel therapeutic approaches.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this research program is to gain detailed mechanistic insight into retrotransposition and pre-mRNA splicing. Retroelements and spliceosomal introns comprise ~70% of the human genome and defects in their function results in many human diseases. We aim to use the molecular insight into these essential genetic mechanisms as a foundation for the development of RNA therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Efficient sensory processing relies on the development of precise connectivity and deficits in sensory processing are common in many neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs). However, the mechanisms underlying circuit development and the etiology of sensory deficits in NDDs are poorly understood, precluding the development of effective therapies. In this proposal, we will use a combination of in vivo anatomic, electrophysiologic, and environmental modification techniques in transgenic and knockout mouse models to elucidate the mechanisms by which proper connectivity is established in the developing visual system and how these processes are disrupted in NDDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trauma is the leading cause of mortality in the US in people under the age of 45 and is predicted to be one of the top contributors to the burden of global disease in this decade. This project aims to understand the early immune response and identify immune-based markers of severe burn injury, one of the most common traumatic injuries worldwide. We will focus on neutrophils as the most abundant white blood cell and the first responders in the human immune defense system to injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  One of the molecular mechanisms through which both arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathies (AC) and fragile skin diseases (SFWHS and DCWHK) form is via mutations to the protein desmoplakin (DSP), a protein in the desmosome that helps connect the cytoskeleton of neighboring cells to each other. When DSP is destabilized, cell no longer connect to each other as strongly, and this leads to disease. The goal of this project is to study ways to stabilize DSP variants, which will eventually help us develop new therapeutic tools to counteract the molecular mechanisms that underlie desmosomal associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Maternal Immunization and Determinants of Infant Immunity (MADI) program aims to understand the maternal factors governing immune response during pregnancy and in early life. The MADI Data Management and Biostatistics Core has previously developed a data management tool for the program that provides access by program investigators to all program data. With this supplement funding, the Core aims to enhance its data management system with updated data sharing processes that will improve ease and accuracy; to develop existing data sets for compliance with common standards; and to deploy via the cloud free software that other research teams can use to support their own research in immunology and infectious disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Most cells in adult animals are in a non-cycling, quiescent state often referred to as G0. Some cells enter reversible states of G0 while others enter more robust and permanent states of G0, but the differences between reversible G0 and permanent G0 are poorly understood. This work investigates the molecular mechanisms that control different states of G0 across tissues, with an ultimate goal of generating tools to manipulate and control G0, which becomes improperly regulated in both cancer and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative LC8 is a universal hub protein that binds to intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) leading to a unique class of multi-valent complexes - ladder-like in structure and `reversibly ordered' in that disassembly is intrinsic to their function and regulation. The dynamic structural properties of LC8-IDP assemblies are critical to the organization and regulation of diverse cellular systems, while aberrant LC8 function is associated with many diseases, including cancer, neurodegenerative diseases and rabies viral infection. Yet, LC8/IDP complexes remain poorly understood due to their complex structural properties, so we will deploy an innovative array of computational and experimental techniques to quantitatively characterize their heterogeneity and fluctuations/dynamics on multiple scales.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Cyclic peptides are an exciting class of drug molecules capable of engaging challenging biological targets, and cyclic peptide natural products have been used in the clinic as immune system suppressants, antibiotics, and antifungals. Unfortunately, it is currently extremely challenging for researchers to design new cyclic peptide drugs to treat specific diseases because it is very difficult to predict the three-dimensional structures any cyclic peptide will adopt and to optimize their pharmacologic properties. In this proposal, we develop new computing algorithms that efficiently and accurately predict structures and properties of cyclic peptides, thereby allowing scientists to much more rapidly and robustly develop novel cyclic peptide drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Parent Grant R01GM147583) Turning on the right gene at the right time is essential for development and requires the dynamic recruitment of dozens of regulatory factors to specific genomic loci; defects in this process cause human disease. Emerging evidence supports a role for weak multivalent interactions in organizing regulatory factors into multi-component clusters that assemble and disassemble dynamically, yet these types of interactions have been difficult to study as they are only stabilized under specific conditions which enable cluster formation. Investigation into the mechanisms and functions of these weak multivalent interactions in the context of cluster formation will provide novel insights into a fundamental biological process with implications for developmental processes and aberrant gene activation in disease.

PHR: Understanding variation in access to healthcare and the physician workforce will provide actionable information on strategies to address disparities by providing targets for policy-level interventions. This application will use advanced GIS and spatial statistical methods to examine spatiotemporal patterns and identify persistent hotspots of poor outcomes, increased utilization and cost, and increased mortality in patients with diabetes across the VA healthcare system. We will leverage our expertise in diabetes care, equity research, GIS analysis, and advanced spatiotemporal statistics to (1) create a comprehensive and unique database, (2) create a workforce deprivation index that allows incorporation of variation in the physician workforce into policy decisions, and (3) incorporate neighborhood/community factors to inform VA policy to improve Veteran health. This innovative methodology will be applicable across disease states, and once developed can be disseminated to better target systems engineering and intervention development efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Most patients with relapsed small cell lung cancer (SCLC) have a very poor prognosis and the disease kills over 25,000 people annually in the US, highlighting the need for novel therapies to improve survival. A patient's own immune cells may be genetically engineered to recognize and kill tumor cells. This project is focused on using this technology to create patient T cells genetically engineered to optimally kill SCLC tumor cells and test this approach in preclinical models.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The class of biologic medications are highly effective, yet highly expensive medications. Biologics are different from standard medications because they can only be created using living systems, and are therefore cannot be exactly copied as a “generic” medication. Biologics are among the fastest growing class of medications and are used for diseases of the immune system, cancers, and other conditions. Biosimilars are copy versions of biologic medications and have recently been approved for use in immune conditions. Biosimilars for immune conditions have been shown in early studies to have similar efficacy as original biologics and are available at a significantly cheaper cost. However, many patients and providers have concerns regarding the safety and effectiveness of biosimilar switching as they are not identical. This proposal aims to use a learning healthcare systems approach to study the safety, effectiveness, and Veterans’ views of acceptance of biosimilar switching.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will enhance our basic understanding of the biological effects of precision particle radiotherapy, particularly proton beam therapy, on normal and tumour cells, with a focus on cells derived from solid tumours of the head and neck and brain which are particularly resistant to radiotherapy. This will be accomplished through analysing the comparative impact of particle radiotherapy delivered at both low and high (so called “FLASH”) dose rates on survival of normal versus the tumour cells, and how this this is mediated through specific effects on critical targets (DNA), under conditions of normal and reduced oxygen (hypoxia) which is important for solid tumours that are radiotherapy resistant. This will lead to development of optimal strategies using particle radiotherapy (protons) for the effective treatment of head and neck and brain tumours, minimising the commonly observed acute and long-term adverse side effects caused by the impact of the radiation on the associated normal tissues, and ultimately improve patient benefit and overall survival. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Breast cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer type among women and the incidence of brain metastases of breast cancer is steadily increasing. I have recently discovered a circadian rhythm in blood brain barrier (BBB) permeability to chemotherapeutics; this project exploits this circadian regulation of BBB permeability to optimally time chemotherapy administration to increase anti-tumor efficacy and reduce adverse side effects of brain metastases treatment. Together, this research will provide essential information with a high potential for clinical relevance to better treat patients with breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Carcinomas, solid tumors of epithelial origin, represent up to 90% of all cancer cases in the United States and present a persistent healthcare challenge. Immunotherapy and chemotherapy are promising treatment strategies for carcinomas, but they have limited efficacy and are associated with side effects that impact patient quality of life. This F99/K00 award proposal focuses on developing a peptide-based hydrogel for the local delivery of chemotherapies and immune checkpoint inhibitors to improve treatment efficacy while avoiding systemic toxicity and side effects.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacteria communicate using a process called quorum sensing to cooperatively change expression of genes required for pathogenesis. My lab studies the quorum sensing in marine Vibrio bacteria that are human pathogens to deteremine how cell-cell signaling affects gene expression. In this supplement proposal, I am requesting funds to purchase a ThermoFisher Scientific Sorvall Lynx 6000 superspeed centrifuge and rotors to support the proposed experiments and increase our productivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: REHABILITATION INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO D/B/A SHIRLEY RYAN ABILITYLAB
PHR: Project Narrative This project uses cutting-edge techniques from complex systems science and leverages an existing Intensive Comprehensive Aphasia Program dataset (n = 161) to bridge two prominent approaches to conceptualization and rehabilitation of aphasia, namely impairment-focused and life participation. We will model the constellation of relationships between language, cognitive, and psychosocial variables in persons with aphasia, detect putative causal relationships between these variables, and determine the prognostic value of our model. In the long-term, results from this project will a) change the conceptualization of aphasia to a more holistic view that recognizes the complex interplay between impairment and participation, and b) provide data-informed models to identify key intervention targets that will have widespread impact across a person’s life, resulting in improved communication and increased quality of life in a parsimonious and efficient manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The glucose-lowering effect of metformin and the underlying mechanisms have been extensively studied, but the effect of metformin on hepatic lipid metabolism and the action site of metformin warrant further research. To fill in the knowledge gap, we will perform liquid chromatography-high resolution mass spectrometry-based lipidomics, metabolomics, and 13C isotope tracing analysis, employ synthetic metformin probe and intestinal AMPK alpha 1 knockout mice, to quantitatively characterize the connections between metformin-induced metabolic alterations in intestine and hepatic lipid metabolism and to identify molecular targets of metformin. The findings of this study will unravel the role of metformin actions in intestine in modulating hepatic lipid metabolism and provide significant insights into strategies to prevent or treat dietary-induced fatty liver diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Rheological characterization of cells, tissues, and biomaterials using bulk shear rheology is an indispensable tool for understanding physiologically relevant biophysical properties. Recent advances in rheometer design enables sensitive in vitro and ex vivo rheological measurements needed to characterize and tune the viscoelastic properties of 3D printed hepatocyte organoid systems that mimic the mechanics of native liver tissues. Knowledge gained from the use of advanced rheological instrumentation will aid in establishing a platform for in vivo liver tissue restoration and ex vivo drug screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stress response mechanisms play a dual role in organism health- they are required for tissue homeostasis and also for minimizing damage during toxic conditions. Intimate molecular knowledge of these mechanisms will thus inform clinical approaches to prolong tissue function under pathobiological conditions. Consistent with the mission of the NIGMS, the research described herein aims to gain such mechanistic understanding and will have broadly relevance to many pathologies from neurodegeneration to cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Heart failure (HF) is the fastest-growing cardiovascular disorder and a leading cause of urgent healthcare utilization in the U.S. As managing HF at home has increased in intensity/complexity, the mental health and social determinants of health impact on persons with heart failure and their informal care partner dyads is of growing importance. The goals of this prospective, dyadic- and social determinants of health theory-informed study of 100 dyads are to gain insight to gain insight into the role that social determinants of health play as the root causes of some of the inequities about which we know, and additional inequities we are likely to discover in this study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Ubiquitin is a post-translational modification that regulates diverse cellular processes and its dysregulation is associated with many human diseases ranging from neurodegeneration to cancer. Here, we propose research directions that will result in a deeper understanding of how ubiquitin networks are regulated during conditions of stress to facilitate the cellular adaptive response. Dissecting these mechanisms will provide a platform for long-term exploration of ubiquitin networks as potential therapeutic targets in the treatment of human diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative The health of our cells requires that the enzymes we rely on to perform chemical reactions carry out their functions at the appropriate locations and times. This research will improve our understanding of the processes that rely on ASCC2 to function properly, such as DNA damage repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative CRISPR-Cas9 systems are frequently found in pathogenic bacteria, where they defend against phages but also prevent the horizontal transfer of antibiotic resistance genes and toxins. Here, we explore novel functions of Cas9 as a non-canonical transcriptional regulator, which could contribute to bacterial pathophysiology and inform new generations of regulatable Cas9 tools for the treatment of genetic diseases. We also study the heterogeneity of CRISPR-Cas immunity in single cells, which will have implications for the survival of human pathogens under stress and their treatment with phage therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The number one neurodegenerative and sensory disorder of the elderly is age-related hearing loss (ARHL), where there are no FDA-approved medical treatments, since its biological mechanisms remain elusive, and analytical techniques needed to clinically diagnose auditory pathologies are still lacking. One such auditory pathology relates to the noticeable decline of a critical part of the inner ear: the “cochlear battery”, commonly known as the endocochlear potential, and is considered as a predominant mechanism of ARHL and other types of hearing loss. The thematic focus of this proposal is to develop an innovative and non-invasive method to measure the “cochlear battery” clinically, to serve as guidance into future targeted therapeutic interventions, both technological and medicinal in nature.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The role of functionally distinct hepatic T cell subsets in providing protective immunity from hepatotropic viruses, such as hepatitis C virus (HCV), or mediating liver pathology during inflammatory liver disease is poorly defined. Using a mouse model of an HCV-related virus we will investigate the functional properties and potential interplay of distinct type 1 and type 2 T cell and natural killer T (NKT) cell subsets during different stages of hepacivirus infection in vivo. Our results should reveal new concepts of hepatic T cell immunity with implications for the development of HCV vaccine strategies and new therapeutic options for liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The loss of proteostasis during aging and upon stress leads to the accumulation of excess, damaged, and aggregated proteins which interfere with essential cellular functions and promote the onset of age-related diseases, particularly in neurons and muscle. This proposal will define the biochemical and physiological functions of an orphan lysine methyltransferase which is required for proteostasis, likely its via methyltransferase activity on molecular chaperones and other factors within the proteostasis network. These studies will broaden our understanding of the cellular mechanisms used to prevent deterioration of proteome integrity linked to diseases associated with stress and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Best of FORWARD Program will translate aspects of the American Gastroenterological Association’s FORWARD Program for a broader audience through a multi-faceted approach to mentorship and peer networking that will enhance the career development of underrepresented physician-scientists and equip them with the skills needed to be successful in the biomedical workforce. Our long-term goal is to enhance the diversity of the biomedical science research workforce studying digestive health and prepare individuals to assume leadership positions within our professional association and in academic medicine. The Best of FORWARD Program will provide greater access to mentoring, bolster research and leadership skills, and address diversity, equity, inclusion, and access by conducting skill-building in an intensive immersion experience while maintaining sustainable relationships with mentors and accessing education via mobile-app technology that allows for flexible and accessible mentor-mentee engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Protein-coding genes must generate functional RNAs at the appropriate levels, and this process is controlled by many different molecular machines, including the Integrator complex and the spliceosome. The proposed studies will characterize in detail how Integrator controls the amount of RNA that is produced as well as why abundant circular RNAs are generated from many protein-coding genes by the spliceosome. This will allow us to better understand how gene outputs are controlled, thereby providing important new insights into how gene misregulation can lead to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinical applications of transcranial alternating current stimulation (tACS), a promising neuromodulation technique, aimed at improving language outcomes in stroke survivors with aphasia are limited due to the complexity in selecting stimulation parameters. Our project proposes to evaluate a multimodal approach to optimize selection of tACS parameters in individual patients. This approach will facilitate future use of tACS as an adjunctive treatment to boost therapeutic outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this adminstrative supplement will be to support the purchase of a preparative HPLC instrument to support the research on the parent R01. The goal of the parent award is developing a diverse set of new chemical tools centered on tetrazine ligation– the fastest known bioorthogonal reaction. The work will advance new biotechnological, biomedical and pharmaceutical applications through new chemical tools for labeling biomolecules in the intracellular environment, new methods for selectively tagging and assembling proteins, and new technology for probing biological targets in living systems with spatiotemporal control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative: Circadian rhythms are beneficial to health, whereas their disruption can increase risk of disease. The goal of this proposal is to uncover fundamental knowledge of how circadian rhythms are generated and coordinated between cells and organs outside of the brain, using genetic mouse models and molecular approaches. The knowledge gained will be critical to understand the adverse health effects associated with rhythm disruption and guide the develop of the most effective therapies to counteract circadian disruption.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Iatrogenic surgical nerve injury continues to challenge even experienced surgeons, leaving patients with pain, loss of function and decreased quality of life. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging evidence suggests that activation of ascending projections through the right, but not the left, vagus nerve may activate dopaminergic reward circuits within the central nervous system. These recent findings raise the intriguing possibility that electrical vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) delivered to the right cervical nerve, rather than the traditionally-targeted left cervical nerve, could be used to modulate activity within these reward networks, providing novel strategies for the treatment of movement disorders. To gain further insight into the translational potential of VNS-driven dopaminergic signaling, in the current proposal, we test the neural mechanisms that underlie the neuroplasticity-promoting and behavior-reinforcing properties of VNS, and we examine the extent to which VNS-driven activation of central reward circuits is modified by experience.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of new synthetic methods in organic chemistry is critical to enabling the continued discovery and production of pharmaceuticals and other chemicals that directly benefit society and public health. This proposal aims to develop a series of novel methods for C–C, C–N, and C–S bond formation that will allow for the rapid preparation of medicinally-relevant scaffolds across a variety of disease states. The newly developed reagents, and their associated reactions and applications, will be of immediate utility to synthetic chemists and chemical biologists in both academic and industrial laboratories.

PHR: NARRATIVE Sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP) is the leading cause of death in patients with refractory epilepsy and thus a major public health problem. Understanding mechanisms for impairment of CO2-arousal in relevant animal models will importantly inform risk stratification and prophylactic strategies against this devastating disease.

PHR: Narrative The mission of the Wyoming Sensory Biology COBRE (SBC) is to foster and conduct high-quality scientific research that advances the understanding of our sensory systems and disorders related to them. SBC will accomplish its mission through the augmentation and strengthening of UW’s institutional biomedical research capacity by building a critical mass of investigators whose research interests are centered on sensory processes at the molecular, cellular, physiological and system levels, and by increasing the competitiveness of SBC investigators through mentoring and research support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The immunomodulatory impact of cannabis use in the context of the chronic inflammation experienced among people with HIV remains unclear. Previous studies on the epigenetic effects of HIV and cannabis use in heterogenous bulk cells only provide an average view of DNA methylation changes across various cell types and offer little insight into cellular epigenetic mechanism. Applying a novel computational deconvolution approach following by direct methylation sequencing validation, our goal is to identify cell-type-specific methylation aberrant sites and methylation quantitative trait loci for HIV infection and cannabis use that can be potential targets for drug repositioning.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because one in four young adults in the U.S. identi- fies as lesbian, gay, bisexual, or transgender (LGBT), and this growing population experiences large mental health disparities relative to cisgender, heterosexual people. An unprecedented number of state policies target- ing LGBT people have become law in recent years, likely exacerbating these disparities. Revealing the needs of at-risk groups—a major priority area for the NIH—will inform interventions to reduce entrenched disparities, promote protective policies, and dramatically improve mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Parent Narrative Clathrin-mediated endocytosis is the primary route of internalization from the plasma membrane and is required for cell viability and the proper response to extracellular cues like growth factor signaling. Mutations in the endocytic machinery, or the proteins that regulate this process, lead to a variety of diseases like cancer and neurodegeneration. This research will take an interdisciplinary approach to understand the mechanisms of endocytic initiation and cargo selection to understand CME in normal cells and how it is subverted in human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE.  The overall 5-year survival rate for oral cancer has not improved much over the last few decades with both conventional multimodal treatment and emerging immunotherapies known to have an adverse (and sometimes fatal) impact on quality of life. The goal of this proposal is to develop and characterize a novel biomaterial- enhanced, living immunotherapeutic vaccine platform for oral cancer we call “EcN-IL12Vax“. This transformative approach will provide the field with an invaluable tool that can be modified and leveraged for other solid cancers in future studies and could enable further exploration of additional therapeutics with substantial toxicity at narrow concentration windows where they are both safe and effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Identifying molecular mechanisms underlying chromosome integrity under normal physiology and during stress response is critical for our understanding of genome biology, cellular homeostasis, and physiology. This proposal will establish a leading edge on regulatory mechanisms of human genome based on our recent findings. Upon completion, this study will reveal innovative insights into the maintenance of DNA structure, stress response, and genome stability, representing a conceptual leap in our understanding of biology and cellular physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative To study the role of dysregulated renal ion transport in animal models of disease, new methods are needed to measure ion transport in the intact kidney in vivo. We propose to use multi-photon imaging of the intact kidney of live mice after transgenic expression of genetically-encoded ion sensitive probes in different nephron segments. We will express Chloride and pH-sensitive fluorescent proteins in cortical Thick Ascending Limbs, distal tubules and principal cells before performing in vivo multi-photon microscopy of renal tubular transport.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are the largest family of cell surface receptors in the human genome, and they are also the proteins most widely targeted by clinically used drugs. GPCRs are implicated in many different biomedical areas, including neuropsychiatric disorders, cardiovascular disease, cancer, allergy, asthma, or pain management. The goal of this application is to develop new state-of-the-art assay technology to improve and accelerate the study and pharmacological targeting of GPCR signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Title: Coordination of molecular motor activity in intracellular transport and assembly of cytoskeletal architecture. P.I. – Richard J. McKenney Project Narrative: Cytoskeletal motor proteins are molecular machines that transport cargos within living cells, a process critical for health and disease. How these machines are linked to specific cargo, how their motility is coordinated within the cell and how motors can also function to build large, dynamic cytoskeletal structures such as the mitotic spindle is not understood. Our research takes a reductionist approach to break down these complex cellular processes into their individual molecular components, study how the constituent molecules work in isolation, and how more complex behavior of systems of molecules arises. This proposal seeks to answer basic questions about how cells are organized with a long-term goal to provide new avenues of inquiry into the mechansims of the many diseases related to impaired molecular motor function, such as ALS, Huntington’s disease, and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Cloud-Based Learning Modules for Biomedical Data Science  PARENT AWARD T32GM132006 (PI: Henry, Clarissa)  The current T32 award supports an innovative, evidence-based training program that includes a co-mentorship framework and transdisciplinary research opportunities. The proposed supplement will facilitate bioinformatics and data science research training by developing reusable Cloud-based training modules to demonstrate workflows to: 1) analyze bulk RNA-Seq data to study gene expression in mouse, zebrafish and C. elegans; 2) analyze mature microRNA expression using small RNA-Seq data from mouse, zebrafish and C. elegans; 3) analyze single cell RNA-Seq data from mouse and zebrafish; and 4) modeling transcription factor networks from RNA-Seq data from human and mouse. These resources will be utilized by our T32 trainees in courses that provide instruction for running sophisticated tools with increasingly large data sets for a variety of analysis workflows, and shared with the scientific community to facilitate bioinformatics and data science research training.
PROJECT_TERMS: Engineering;pre-doctoral;Science;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Transdisciplinary Predoctoral Training in Biomedical Science and Engineering

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal investigates the molecular basis of alternative splicing —the inclusion or skipping of different exons in mRNA— may modulates the physiological activity of CaV3.1 a voltage-gated Calcium channel that is involved in spinocerebellar ataxia, epilepsy, and autism spectrum disorders in humans. Since patients with CaV3.1-associated pathologies display defects in Calcium current properties, understanding how alternative splicing may modulate the biology of CaV3.1 and how this modulation is regulated, may have broad and significant clinical implications in spinocerebellar ataxia, epilepsy, and autism spectrum disorders, and it may inform the design of novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The parent award aims to leverage state-of-the-art data-driven models for accurate estimation of protein-ligand binding affinity that has wide applications in drug discovery. In this proposal, a modern workstation is requested in order to run machine learning models and molecular dynamics simulations more efficiently. The outcome of this research will improve the current understanding of protein-ligand interactions and will benefit the computer-aided drug design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of this project is to develop molecular recording methods to record and recover key determinants in cell-fate transitions during early development. We propose to test and optimize our methods in synthetic embryo models that mimic the early mammalian development process. We anticipate that these experiments will deepen the current model of mammalian early development and substantially advance molecular recording technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Within the eukaryotic cell nucleus, the human genome is associated with core histones and other proteins to form a multifaceted complex known as chromatin. This complex brings about the orderly packaging of the immense length of DNA within the tiny volume of the nucleus and is directly involved in critical cell functions. This project aims to elucidate fundamental aspects of chromatin structure, and how chromatin modifiers regulate access to DNA within chromatin and contribute to control of gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will investigate cellular and molecular mechanisms of brain injury resulting from Congenital heart disease (CHD). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Splicing of gene transcripts is an essential process in human cells and frequently dysregulated in disease. Despite progress, the molecular-level mechanisms of splice site identification are incompletely understood. We seek to understand how the splicing machinery identifies gene transcripts for processing into legible RNA messages, thereby providing context for personalized medicines to treat patients with dysfunctional splicing.

PHR: Project Narrative This work is relevant to public health, as current treatments for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) have limited efficacy, modest increase in lifespan, and little symptom relief. PHR: Narrative Statement - P30GM133894 The purpose of the P30 Resource is to provide the biomedical community with access to state- of- the-art facilities for macromolecular crystallography, small-angle x-ray scattering, and x-ray spectroscopy/imaging, tools that are essential for the study of biological systems. They enable information that is prerequisite for understanding fundamentals of life, and provide methods that are central to the development of new therapeutics for human disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The gap junctions are a class of membrane channel proteins that form direct pathways for cell-to-cell communication. Dynamic mechanisms of channel gating are required to control these communication pathways, while their misregulation is associated with a range of pathophysiological conditions, including blindness, deafness, cardiac arrhythmia, stroke and cancers. Our research group is using methods in high- resolution imaging by electron cryo-microscopy (CryoEM) to understand the detailed mechanisms of gap junction regulation and how aberrant regulation of inter-cellular communication manifests in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because defects in membrane remodeling underlie debilitating diseases from cancer to neurological disorders, and because membrane trafficking vesicles serve as the cellular entry mechanism for both harmful pathogens and therapeutic drugs. Therefore, the proposed research on the basic physical mechanisms underlying membrane remodeling is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that seeks to develop fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human disability and disease. Ultimately, it is envisioned that a fundamental understanding of membrane remodeling will enable therapeutic manipulation of membrane traffic and other points of intersection between membranes and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Pendrin (SLC26A4) is an anion transporter that is expressed in epithelial cells, e.g., in the inner ear, thyroid, kidney, and lung where it plays a central role in ion homeostasis, and it is the molecular target of the non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug niflumic acid. Mutations in the Slc26a4 gene cause Pendred Syndrome and Enlarged Vestibular Aqueduct Syndrome (EVAS), both of which are genetic disorders characterized by early hearing loss in children and account for 5-10% of hereditary hearing loss. The physiology and pathophysiology of pendrin is poorly understood, and this project, by using structural studies in conjunction with advanced transport and binding studies, seeks to elucidate the mechanism and pharmacology of pendrin at atomic level to aid in the development of efficacious therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Statement: Obesity and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) devastate millions of Americans and place a tremendous burden on our healthcare system. Necessities of modern society put immense pressure on human physiology by forcing incongruity between endogenous circadian rhythms and environmental cycles, which worsens a range of health issues including obesity associated maladies and AD. This project aims to identify the neuronal circuits and the molecular players that control circadian rhythms and therefore identify therapeutic targets to circumvent these pathologies.

PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE The new Refeyn TwoMP Mass Photometer provides a highly sensitive technology to analyze single biomolecules in solution and is label-free. Yielding accurate mass measurements in under five minutes and for about $1 per measurement, the new mass photometer will directly benefit the parent project’s research plan to study the oligomeric state(s) and assembly of protein machines in equilibria and to optimize sample conditions prior to structure analysis work. The TwoMP Mass Photometer will strengthen our research capabilities and provide enhanced user access to this powerful technology, but it is currently not available at Baylor College of Medicine or in the greater Houston area.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RASopathies are a group of neurodevelopmental genetic syndromes that are characterized by overlapping clinical manifestations, including cardiac abnormalities, developmental delay, and tumor predisposition. The management of RASopathies is clinically challenging due to the heterogenous presentation of the symptom and no specific treatments are available; hence, novel therapies are urgently needed for these disorders. The present application addresses this clinical need by exploring potential new mechanisms and therapies in models of RASopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Ablordeppey, Seth Project Narrative According to the American Sleep Association, 50-70 million US adults have a sleep disorder, insomnia being the most common specific sleep disorder with 30% of adults reporting short term issues and 10% reporting chronic insomnia. Meanwhile, 37.9% US adults reported unintentionally falling asleep during the day at least once in the preceding month, while 4.7% reported nodding off or falling asleep while driving at least once in the preceding month. Given that drowsy driving is responsible for 1,550 fatalities and 40,000 nonfatal injuries annually in the US, this remains a serious public health crisis requiring serious attention. Meanwhile, neuropathic pain estimated in the general population to range between 3% and 17%, lacks an effective treatment as most of the available treatments have only moderate efficacy and present significant side effects that limit their use. Therefore, other therapeutic approaches, such as the development of biased 5-HT7R agonists which have been demonstrated to have therapeutic advantages for treating certain sleep disorders and neuropathic pain and are proposed in this application, are urgently needed. The current supplement is requested in support of the aims of this parent application. Contact PD/PI: Ablordeppey, Seth Project Narrative Page 8

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perturbations of the intercellular signaling systems that control organ growth are a major source of human disease, associated with a wide range of developmental, physiological disorders as well as most forms of cancer. The proposed research is relevant to public health because solving how such systems normally function to direct as well as terminate growth as organs develop is essential for the development of more effective diagnostic and therapeutic treatments for this enormously broad range of afflictions. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH's mission to reduce the burden to society arising from genetic and environmental disorders of fundamental aspects of human development and physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell division is an essential process by which replicated chromosomes are equally segregated to daughter cells, however this process is prone to errors, which can result in chromosomal instability and lead to cancer and developmental diseases. There are potential molecular mechanisms contributing towards faithful chromosome segregation that have not yet been adequately explored, one of which is the evolution and maintenance of chromosome organization throughout mitosis. Our proposed work of defining the spatial organization of mitotic chromosomes and kinetochores required for accurate chromosome segregation using innovative imaging methods is of fundamental importance to public health because a clear understanding of the mechanisms underlying faithful chromosome segregation will contribute towards developing better therapeutic and detection strategies for cancer and developmental diseases for improved patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to acquire new equipment, the NanoSight Pro instrument for nanoparticle tracking analysis (NTA) to enhance the capability and productivity of my research lab. The NTA system will be used to characterize the nanoparticles and bioparticles that will deliver immunomodulatory factors to reduce inflammation, enhance regeneration, and restore function in traumatized musculature.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Episodic Ataxia type 2 (EA2) and Familial hemiplegic migraine (FHM1) are neurological disorders resulting from mutations in the CACNA1A gene, which encodes the pore-forming subunit of the P/Q type calcium channel (Cav2.1). Recently, CACNA1A patients presenting primarily with cognitive defects have been described, suggesting a novel cellular mechanism may lead to their symptoms. Here we propose to delineate the effects of CACNA1A mutations on the calcium channel auxiliary subunit a2d.
