IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Host and microbial metabolites play a crucial role in the regulation of inflammation and are linked to the onset of diverse human diseases, such as periodontal disease, inflammatory bowel disease, cancer, and Alzheimer’s disease. This proposal aims to establish a CoBRE-Metabolomics facility under Functional Microbiomics Core by purchasing TSQ Quantis Triple-Stage Quadrupole Mass Spectrometer. This facility will enable identification and quantification of both targeted- and untargeted metabolites across various pathophysiological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to develop, validate, and apply a suite of powerful new tools to interrogate the functions, interactions, and cellular localizations of individual splice variants of HIV-1, which is the virus that causes AIDS and infects over 1 million people each year. In 2020, over 37 million people, including 1.7 million children, were living with the virus, and over 500,000 died from AIDS. For a robust eradication of the virus, additional research such as the work proposed here is desperately needed to eliminate knowledge gaps in our understanding of viral infection and replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: This study aims to examine the engagement, effective use, the potential for antimicrobial resistance, and potential transmission of bacteria among Doxy-PEP users. A prospective cohort of Doxy-PEP users will be enrolled to investigate factors, mapped to the information-motivation-behavioral skills theoretical model, to evaluate their impact on Doxy-PEP engagement and effective use. Biological samples from Doxy- PEP users, eligible non-users (a control cohort), and their sexual partners will be collected to assess trends in antimicrobial resistance of specific pathogens, the impact on the presence or absence of resistance genes, and the potential for transmission of pathogenic bacteria between sexual partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE Despite of potent antiretroviral therapies, HIV infection still persists attributing to the chronic inflammation and the accelerated aging-related diseases, thus requiring its elimination for a cure. We identified that HIV Nef protein induces polo-like kinase 1 (PLK1) through increase of its protein SUMOylation and nuclear accumulation, and propose to study PLK1 as a Nef’s novel host effector to promote survival and immune escape of HIV/SIV viral reservoirs. Chemical compounds targeting PLK1 will be investigated in terms of their therapeutic potential to reduce or eliminate persistent HIV/SIV viral reservoirs ex vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Natural products are the best source of drugs and drug leads and terpenoids, the largest family of natural products, have a wide range of clinically important activities including antibiotic, anticancer, antimalarial, and immunosuppressant properties. The proposed studies will lead to the discovery of new natural products with important biological activities, facilitate future discovery efforts by the development of systems dedicated to facile identification of terpenoids in bacteria, and result in the characterization of natural product biosynthetic enzymes. A greater understanding of terpenoid biosynthesis will also provide insights into how nature constructs medicinally relevant compounds and how these enzymes may be used as tools for future discoveries in biochemistry, bioengineering, and drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims at defining mechanisms responsible for the formation and maintenance of the neuromuscular junction (NMJ), and the survival of motor neurons. This is important because abnormal formation or function of the NMJ, as well as the loss of motor neuron, is implicated in neurodegenerative diseases such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Therefore, identifying regulatory mechanisms responsible for structural and functional changes in the NMJ will enable us to improve current treatment strategies for neurodegenerative diseases such as ALS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many human diseases including genetic disorders and cancers are caused by mutations in transcription factors or their dysregulation. The overall goal of this project is to determine the mechanism of transcription by eukaryotic RNA polymerase I (Pol I) and how it is dysregulated in disease. This work will provide fundamental knowledge about the basic molecular mechanism of Pol I transcription and discover key steps that may be targeted in cancer and developmental disorders to enhance health and reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The goal of this administrative supplement of the parent award, R35GM118090, is to purchase a Prometheus Panta from NANOTEMPER for the simultaneous detection of nano-Differential Scanning Fluorimetry (nanoDSF), Backreflection, Dynamic Light Scattering (DLS) and Static Light Scattering (SLS). The Prometheus Panta, will allow us to carry out protein and protein complex analysis rapidly, accurately, label- free, and with low sample requirement of ~10 L at a wide range of protein and protein complex concentrations of between 5 µg/mL – 250 mg/ml. This analysis will include protein and protein complex quality assessment and buffer condition optimization for biochemical and structural (X-ray crystallography and single particle cryo- EM) analysis, assessing thermal stability of protein, protein-ligand, protein complexes and protein mutants as a readout for protein ligand binding and protein integrity, respectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE from Parent Award Eukaryotic cells encode thousands of different membrane proteins that are critical for growth and survival. We have discovered a new pathway that directs the biogenesis of multi-pass membrane proteins at the endoplasmic reticulum membrane. Deﬁning how the cellular machinery coordinates this fundamental process is essential for understanding how healthy cells function, with important implications for the treatment of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: We propose to develop optogenetic and chemigenetic tools to visualize and control the metabolism of single mRNAs with high spatiotemporal resolution in live cells. We will use the tools to investigate the molecular mechanism of RNA decay and localized translation. The experimental tools will be valuable for studying post-transcriptional gene expression which is important to decipher the molecular mechanism of neural development, learning and memory formation, and to develop therapeutic treatment for neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Atherosclerosis is initiated and promoted by the arterial accumulation of apolipoprotein B (apoB)-containing lipoproteins which activate a chronic inflammatory response. Our group recently made the novel discovery that a key blood clot lysis protein, tissue-type plasminogen activator (tPA), in hepatocytes limits the production of apoB-lipoproteins in mice and cultured human primary hepatocytes. The overarching objective of this proposal is to explore the underlying mechanisms by which hepatocyte tPA lowers plasma apoB-containing lipoprotein- cholesterol levels, and thereby alleviates atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biofilm formation, a crucial bacterial lifestyle for persistence in particular niches, tolerance to antimicrobials and virulence in many pathogens, is governed by environmental and self- generated stimuli. How the information encoded in multiple sensory inputs is extracted and integrated to control biofilm development is poorly understood. Using the multi-drug resistant human pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa as model system, the proposed research will investigate how light, nutrients and population-density signals, individually and in combination, control biofilm development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Administrative Supplement to NIH R16 GM145403 (Stark): Introduction Sartorius Octet R2 System for Label-free Kinetic and Binding Affinity Analysis This administrative supplement application requests funds to purchase 2-channel Sartorius OCTET equipment for label-free, real-time quantitative measurement of protein-protein and protein-ligand binding affinities and rates, in support of a parent award entitled “Molecular Drivers of FABP-mediated Endocannabinoid Signaling for Appetite Regulation.” This Dip-and-Read Bio- layer interferometry platform will overcome the challenges of currently limited access to a colleague’s aging surface plasmon resonance instrument which is located at a distance from the parent project laboratory. The new equipment described in this supplement request will offer several advantages: (1) technological advances will improve ease-of-use, reliability, and throughput; and (2) it will improve the technical skills and productivity of a research team that includes trainees who span a broad range of career stages and demographic backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Fat reserves release hormones called adipokines that act on neural circuits to regulate decisions on several physiological processes including hunger, immunity, and reproduction. If not tightly coupled to energy status, adipokine release is detrimental to the organism and leads to obesity and metabolic disorders. By studying how fat stores communicate nutrient state to an organism we will elucidate the molecular and cellular mechanisms that underpin healthy energy balance.

PROJECT_TITLE: Cellular mechanisms governing nutrient sensing and organismal energy homeostasis

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Cognitive impairment and dementia are leading contributors to disability and are increasing at an alarming rate as the population ages. This project will provide important information on the function of the arterioles that perfuse the hippocampus, a deep brain region critically involved in learning and memory. We will investigate the role of hippocampal arterioles in cognitive decline associated with healthy aging, and how this may be accelerated during chronic hypertension and contribute to vascular cognitive impairment and dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Visual impairment is a terrifying prospect. Our long-term goal is to eliminate or reduce this health burden by understanding the biological mechanisms that underlie vision in health and disease. With this goal in mind, we propose to create a Center of Excellence in visual sciences at West Virginia University to strengthen the scientific community focused on understanding processes essential to optimal visual health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The circadian clock controls most aspects of human life and health. Based on our studies during the past 13 years, we believe that temperature preference rhythm in Drosophila is an innovative model for understanding fundamental regulatory mechanisms of body temperature rhythms in mammals. Our studies will expand the current understanding of mammalian body temperature rhythm, sleep disorders, and general sleep-associated issues, such as jet lag or the sleep disturbances common to night-shift workers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Human reproductive health can be compromised both genetically or by exposure to myriad compounds found in prescription drugs, food containers and toxic waste products found in the environment. This work is significant because it will identify genetic and biochemical pathways that may be direct targets of these insults during gametogenesis. A detailed understanding of these pathways will aid in identifying the underlying causes of human infertility, birth defects and pregnancy loss by exposure to environmental contaminants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurons can communicate with each other via electrical and chemical signals, as well as membrane-bound packets called extracellular vesicles. These vesicles carry cargo that can contribute to normal brain function, but in neurological disorders including Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s Diseases, they can also spread toxic proteins throughout the brain. Our research will help us understand how extracellular vesicles are packaged, released and spread in the nervous system, and may identify new strategies to treat a wide variety of neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excessive or inappropriate recruitment of immune cells is a major driver of tissue damage in inflammation-associated diseases including atherosclerosis, arthritis, and autoimmune diseases. The migration of cancer cells causes dissemination and metastasis which greatly reduces survival rates. Understanding the basic mechanisms that allow cells to maintain migratory behavior will suggest new therapeutic strategies to improve outcomes in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cortical spreading depolarizations (CSDs), or “brain tsunamis” are waves of electrical activity that occur in 60% of patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI) and are associated with poor outcomes. In this proposal we test the hypothesis that CSDs disrupt communications between the cortex and the hippocampus. Successful completion of this project will help determine how CSDs cause poor outcomes, and hence can identify treatment targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (From the original application) Defective and damaged proteins are rapidly degraded by a molecular machine called the proteasome. If the proteasome does not function efficiently, this can lead to toxic accumulation of abnormal proteins. This project aims to better understand how cells regulate the proteasome to prevent this from happening. Mis-regulation of the proteasome plays important roles in cancer, neurodegenerative diseases and some rare genetic disorders. In the long-term, our fundamental insights into proteasome regulation will lead to new treatments for these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Cilia are tiny hair-like projections on the surface of the cell that can serve as antennae to sense the cell’s environment or beat to move fluid. Defects in cilia cause disorders known as ciliopathies that affect numerous organs, including the brain, kidneys, eyes, and lungs, which require cilia for their formation or function. The aim of this project is to understand how a newly discovered family of widely conserved, yet poorly understood, ciliary proteins contributes to cilia assembly and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synapses are the primary substrates driving information transfer throughout our nervous system. Defects in synaptic communication are associated with a vast number of neurological, neurodegenerative, and neuropsychiatric diseases including epilepsy, autism, schizophrenia, ALS, and Alzheimer’s Disease. While their importance is undeniable, the mechanisms that establish and modulate the diversity of synaptic strength remain enigmatic. This proposal seeks to reveal fundamental insights into what determines and adaptively modifies the diversity of presynaptic function at glutamatergic synapses in development and plasticity. Ultimately, this knowledge is necessary to understand the etiology of neural diseases resulting from synaptic dysfunction and develop effective therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although sleep is generally believed to be essential for survival, the neuronal mechanisms by which it affects brain function are largely unknown. We propose to use non-human primates and perform multiple-electrode recording simultaneously in three cortical areas, including visual and prefrontal cortex, to examine, for the first time, the dynamics, coding, and mechanisms of the post-sleep improvement in neural function and perception. Our research has the potential to advance our understanding of the neural mechanisms underlying sleep and thus provide future solutions to ameliorate sleep disorder and its detrimental effects on cognitive performance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We are investigating wound-induced syncytia that form around epithelial wounds via cell-cell fusion. Our current results indicate that the initiating trigger for these fusions is plasma membrane damage to cells around the wound, as generated by our current ablation laser. We propose to use this equipment supplement to purchase a fiber laser that would not generate such collateral plasma membrane damage, enabling us to understand how this type of damage contributes to wound-induced responses, including the formation of wound-induced syncytia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance  Stimulant use disorder and depression are both more common in people with HIV (PWH) than in the general population and often co-occur, particularly in the context of chronic psychosocial stress. Psychosocial stress interacts with stimulant use and depression to compromise neuroimmune function and exacerbate central nervous system pathology associated with HIV disease, but the mechanisms that mediate these relationships are not well understood. Using a randomized controlled trial design, this study applies an evidence-based intervention that boosts positive affect in PWH to advance our understanding of the causal associations amongst these prevalent comorbidities in a population that is critical to ending the HIV epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maintaining the repertoire of small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNP) is crucial for regulate messenger RNA metabolism, which determines the isoforms of nascent transcripts and produces a variety of protein isoforms necessary for the cellular function. Therefore, investigating the quality control mechanisms of snRNP at the molecular level is fundamental for understanding gene expression profiles in both normal and disease development. The proposed study aims to investigate the molecular function of snRNP-specific proteins as gatekeepers of snRNP biogenesis and as key switch controlling the protection of full-length nascent transcripts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because defects in germline mechanisms are responsible for various genetic and epigenetic diseases. This study has high potential to identify novel epigenetic mechanisms that govern distinct sexually dimorphic processes in spermatogenesis and oogenesis. The outcome of this study will contribute to significant, transformative advances in germline biology, and to our understanding of human reproduction and reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to investigate how the nervous system and immune system interact to achieve the resolution of infection and the specificity of innate immunity, two important but poorly understood issues in immunology. Failure to properly resolve infection or to ensure appropriate innate immune responses to specific pathogens can lead to uncontrolled inflammation, which has now been recognized as a unifying mechanism for many inflammatory diseases, such as arthritis, sepsis, and inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the molecular and neuronal mechanisms responsible for neural regulation of both infection resolution and innate immune specificity could benefit the development of new treatments for infectious diseases and innate immune disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative  The proposed project is relevant to public health because it will develop and validate technology to detect ethylene as a unique biomarker of oxidative stress. Ethylene is a product of lipid peroxidation and in-turn a measure of oxidative stress, which is related to numerous diseases. The development of sensitive fluorescent probes could broaden the study of the biological production and role of ethylene, which is in line with the mission of the National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In all life forms on earth, DNA carries the hereditary genetic information. Transcription copies DNA into RNA, a key process that permits gene expression. On occasion, the nascent RNA can become entangled with the DNA, resulting in an alternative three-stranded nucleic acid structure called an R-loop. R-loops form universally under normal conditions and are thought to play physiological roles in cells, including human cells. Studies have suggested, however, that under conditions where transcription is perturbed, harmful R-loops are created, leading to DNA breaks and chromosome anomalies. What distinguishes “good” from “harmful” R-loops remains unknown. Similarly, how harmful R-loops arise as a result of perturbed transcription is unclear. Using innovative technologies developed by my group, we will characterize the formation of so-called harmful R- loops under conditions of perturbed transcription in human cells. We will also determine whether harmful R- loops, or perturbed transcription itself, are the cause of the DNA breaks. Finally, we will determine if an enzyme known to relieve the DNA break problem is acting by resolving harmful R-loops or remediating the altered transcription. This work will benefit our understanding of fundamental cellular processes acting in our genome and will provide insights into a range of human disorders linked to perturbed transcription.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Necroptosis is a type of genetically encoded necrotic cell death that is associated with many human diseases, including cancer, inflammatory bowel disease, liver injury, pancreatitis, neurodegenerative disorders, and a diverse range of viral, bacterial, and fungal infections. Here, we are requesting the IncuCyte® S3 live-cell imaging system for real-time and reliable quantification of cell death kinetics, perform label-free quantification of cell death using machine-learning algorithms, and monitor activation of necroptosis-mediating molecules. This live-cell imaging system will dramatically boost our capabilities, productivity, and rigor in deciphering the mechanisms that govern the execution of necroptosis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will test innovative multi-level interventions at the practice (primary care) and provider (physician, nurse practitioner) levels to increase dental attendance and improve overall health and quality of life for adults aged ≥ 55 years attending primary care visits. The behavioral interventions at the provider level and implementation strategies at the practice level will help older adults better understand the importance of oral health and to seek dental care for themselves. These novel interventions have the potential for a new oral health care model for primary care providers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative General strategies to impose stereocontrol over radical-mediated transformations have long eluded synthetic chemists. By repurposing and engineering naturally occurring metalloenzymes for new-to-nature metalloredox processes, we will develop biocatalytic radical reactions that occur with excellent stereochemical fidelity. Ultimately, this evolvable metalloenzyme platform will allow for the rapid assembly of clinically significant therapeutics of general societal importance.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Functional electrical stimulation (FES) is the use of small electrical currents applied to the nervous system to replace or compensate for the actions of neurons that have been damaged by injury or disease. The Center for Functional Electrical Stimulation (FES Center) maintains a rich environment that promotes new discoveries and provides the critical resources needed for innovation. It develops new, FES-based rehabilitation treatments for Veterans and civilians with neurological disorders such as spinal cord injury, stroke, Parkinson's disease, chronic pain, psychiatric disorders, epilepsy, and internal body functions such as bladder and bowel function, blood pressure, and inflammation. FES Center investigators (1) explore approaches for interfacing with the nervous system, (2) develop new stimulation technologies, (3) establish teams of scientist, engineers, and clinicians who explore the effectiveness and practicality of the FES treatments, and (4) work to move effective new FES treatment into clinical deployment.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Research conducted at the National Center for Rehabilitative Auditory Research (NCRAR) involves the diagnosis and assessment, rehabilitation and prevention of auditory and balance dysfunction. It is highly relevant to Veterans' health care because tinnitus and hearing loss are the number one and number two most prevalent service-connected disabilities, respectively, among all Veteran compensation recipients (Veterans Benefits Administration, 2019). Moreover, balance dysfunction is associated with blast exposure and traumatic brain injury often seen in Veterans of recent conflicts. Additionally, since nearly half of all Veterans are over age 65 (VA Strategic Plan 2018-2024), NCRAR research will remain relevant to Veterans' health because it focuses on the assessment and diagnosis, rehabilitation, and prevention of tinnitus, hearing loss and balance dysfunction, which are all disorders prevalent in aging Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Natural killer (NK) cells represent a high impact cellular target for gene therapy, but due to limitations in current methodologies for gene delivery, NK cells remain a largely untapped resource. Here, we propose that non-viral delivery via our Flowfect™ platform can alleviate this limitation on NK genetic modification at both research and large scale needed for pre-clinical studies. Due to the major potential impact NK cells represent in the clinical setting, non-viral Cas9 ribonucleoprotein gene knockout will allow for unrestricted therapeutic applications in viral immunity, autoimmunity, and cancer immuno-surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The parental project validates our hypothesis that when loaded with the same guide RNA, four human Argonaute proteins recognize the same target differently, causing distinct gene suppression outcomes. The binding kinetics and affinity of each AGO-RISC for the same target have not been characterized and need measurement with a dedicated system. The requested Octet R2 system will enable us to analyze and compare these aspects across the four homologs, providing initial insights into the target specificity of the four human RISCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE In all animals, the fertilized egg undergoes regulation of the maternally deposited instructions (mRNAs and proteins) and activation of its own genome. This project studies how the vertebrate embryo organizes multiple players to undertake these tasks, with the goal of understanding basic conserved principles of how genes are regulated that can be applied to other systems, including reprogramming of the cellular fates and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Narrative The biological significance of protein assemblies in both health and disease makes understanding the molecular underpinnings of their molecular motions and interactions essential for intervention. Protein interactions with collagen fibrils are critical for healthy cellular function, self-assembly of intrinsically disordered α-synuclein monomers leads to pathological oligomer and fibril formation associated with Parkinson’s Disease, and interactions of the SARS-CoV-2 spike glycoprotein mediate host cell entry. By integrating solution NMR with other biophysical tools and cellular assays, our studies will reveal mechanisms that underlie these protein– protein interactions and will inform design of therapeutics to encourage functional or discourage pathological interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to synthesize new asymmetric molecular structures, with selective and precise control over spatial arrangements of its atoms, is the primary requirement for life-saving drug discovery. The proposed research will use solid molecular frameworks as readily scalable and separable photocatalysts to drive spatially selective reactions by hosting the reactive intermediates within their precisely designed asymmetric pores. We anticipate the research on developing selective heterogeneous photocatalysis will have both fundamental chemical and biochemical scientific impacts as well as practical impacts in new drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to human health because the elucidation of evolutionarily conserved mechanisms that promote multipotent cell fate during quiescence is expected to advance the field of stem cell biology. The proposed work will illuminate a novel pathway involving FOXO transcription factors and RNA-binding proteins that are conserved from C. elegans to mammals. These factors are key regulators of stem cell fate across species. The project is relevant to the mission of NIH and NIGMS because it is expected to provide fundamental knowledge about stem cell biology and to lay the foundation for clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Ubiquitin is a post-translational modification that regulates diverse cellular processes and its dysregulation is associated with many human diseases ranging from neurodegeneration to cancer. Here, we propose research directions that will result in a deeper understanding of how ubiquitin networks are regulated during conditions of stress to facilitate the cellular adaptive response. Dissecting these mechanisms will provide a platform for long-term exploration of ubiquitin networks as potential therapeutic targets in the treatment of human diseases.

PHR: This administrative supplement is to fund the purchase of fast protein liquid chromatography (FPLC) equipment to aid purification of protein produced recombinantly and used for in vitro research studies. Significant quantities and high purity protein are necessary for experiments regarding the nature of cytochrome P450 enzymes and their roles in generating endogenous hormones and steroids key to regulating human health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Pioneer transcription factors can bind and open silent chromatin, leading to transcriptional activation. The pioneer factors Sox2 and Oct4 orchestrate cell-fate changes during development, yet how they selectively target and destabilize closed chromatin remains largely unknown. This project will investigate the molecular details of how Sox2 and Oct4 alter the structure and epigenetic state of chromatin, which will advance our mechanistic understanding of pioneering action and ability to manipulate stem cells for research and disease therapy.

Common neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs), including autism spectrum disorders, attention-deficit and hyperactivity disorder, intellectual disability, seizure disorders, and traumatic injury to the developing brain all have major social and economic costs associated. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Microbial communities relevant for human health are often dense, spatially structured, and interact both chemically and physically, for example by releasing toxins to prevent infection by external colonizing pathogens and building localized pressure to penetrate soft tissues. Our work will reveal the impact of mechanics and microbial antagonism on the evolutionary trajectories of microbial communities and will help us understand how spatial constraints impose selective pressures that lead to the increased invasiveness of microbial infections. By investigating the factors required for the successful replacement of a microbial strain by an invading antagonist, our results will help design better strategies for microbiome engineering and microbial replacement therapies.

PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative The proposed research seeks to develop the direct delivery of recombinant dCas9-histone demethylase protein complex to induce frataxin gene-targeted histone demethylation and DNA repair-mediated GAA repeat contraction in Friedreich's ataxia using human vault nanoparticles. The research will open a novel avenue for gene therapy for Friedreich's ataxia using human natural bionanoparticles. Thus, it directly relates to the NIH's mission of reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Latinx community bears a disproportionate burden of chronic kidney disease, and they are less likely to start recommended kidney replacement therapy, such as kidney transplant or home dialysis, compared to non- Latinx White individuals. Our funded parent grant allows us to conduct a patient-level randomized controlled trial of NAVIGATE-Kidney, a multi-level, community health worker intervention for Latinx with kidney disease, that will reduce kidney health disparities. The proposed supplement builds on the parent grant plan for enhancing diverse perspectives (PEDP) by increasing the research workforce through direct one to one mentorship of physician scientists focused on kidney health disparities research and through the development of a kidney disease community health worker training program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: This application seeks funding for a UV/Vis spectrophotometer in order to add critical UV/Vis spectrophotometric data to the parental study plan. The parental study aims to research the processes underlying the redox-mediated activations of Arf and Rho GTPases and to explore the therapeutic effects of novel redox-inert nucleotide analogs that desensitize the redox response of these small GTPases. The addition of the UV/Vis spectrophotometric approach will aid the discovery of the redox-inert desensitizer drugs that may lead to a molecular and mechanistic basis for developing therapies for immune disorders and other relevant diseases associated with the uncontrolled redox functions of these small GTPases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Intestinal bacterial pathogens are a major cause of morbidity and mortality globally and a leading cause of death among children. The goals of this proposal are to understand how specific metabolites from bacteria regulate host epithelial cells to protect against intestinal bacterial infection. The outcomes of these studies will benefit human health because they will inform the design of new approaches for improving intestinal immunity to fight infection.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: This project will develop novel mouse models to study hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) and their differentiation into various blood and immune cells. Current methods have limitations in tracking individual HSCs and their progeny in their endogenous microenvironment, limiting our understanding of their behavior. We will overcome this by creating a multi-color, multi-loci mouse reporter system using cutting-edge CRISPR/Cas9-mediated knock-in technology, that will allow for live tracking of HSCs in many tissues and organ systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Opioid use disorder (OUD) is the third leading cause of preventable death in the United States and negatively affects the quality of life of millions of people; we propose to test the best-available activators and inhibitors of the Neuropeptide S (NPS) receptor (NPSR1) for their therapeutic potential in rat models of distinct phases of OUD. More broadly, the experiments proposed will generate the preliminary data necessary to justify a large- scale, collaborative drug-development effort aimed at developing novel small molecule ligands of the NPSR1. Ultimately it is our hope that these efforts generate new and urgently needed treatment options for OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Chronic pain continues to be a major health, social and economic problem throughout the world, affecting an estimated 1 in 3 individuals. Current therapies for chronic pain offer only modest efficacy and/or have serious side-effects. As a result, there is a need to focus on treating pain, on preventing the development of chronic pain, and on research and development of novel treatments (including restoration of lost function and improvement of quality of life).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Our overall goal is to identify cross-sectional and longitudinal local patterns of cartilage and bone interactions unique to patellofemoral joint osteoarthritis and determine the mediation effects of gait biomechanics and bone morphology on disease progression. We will conduct a longitudinal cohort study investigating 100 people with isolated patellofemoral joint osteoarthritis, followed for 2 years. This work is urgently needed to fully understand bone-cartilage interactions and reveal biomechanical risk factors for patellofemoral joint osteoarthritis progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Sjögren’s syndrome (SS), a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease that affects ~ 4 million Americans, particularly women, is characterized by hyposalivation and dacryoadenitis with lymphocytic infiltration of salivary and lacrimal glands. Our research focuses on the cell surface receptors, P2X7 and P2Y2, for extracellular ATP, the chemical form of energy in a cell that when released from injured or diseased salivary and lacrimal gland tissue causes inflammation. The overall goal of these studies is to evaluate whether antagonism of the P2X7R and/or P2Y2R can protect the salivary and lacrimal glands from tissue damage in SS patients by investigating these novel signaling pathways in mouse models of SS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY LAS CRUCES
PHR: Project Narrative The New Mexico IDeA Networks of Biomedical Research Excellence (NM-INBRE) is strongly committed to (under)graduate research and education and strives to engage demographics underrepresented in STEM fields while expanding research/career opportunities for the students and increasing the number of competitive investigators in the scientific workforce. By adapting our existing NM-INBRE pangenomics workshop into an open-source Cloud Lab Module that can be taken independently or integrated into other curricula, we are greatly increasing the number of students and researchers that can utilize these modern pangenomics techniques in biomedical research. The short and long term benefits of this are many, including allowing current researchers to utilize these skills immediately in their biomedical research and arming students with these advanced skills prior to entering the (bio)medical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Sudden Unexpected Death in Epilepsy (SUDEP) accounts for between 8 and 17% of all epilepsy-related deaths and, although our understanding of SUDEP is rudimentary, there is increasing evidence that respiratory arrest after a convulsive seizure is the primary cause in many cases. In support of this, we have found that seizure-induced apnea that occurs during the tonic phase and failure of postictal breathing recovery produce SUDEP in mouse models. Using novel mouse models of SUDEP, we propose to use chemogenetic, optogenetic, and electrophysiological techniques to elucidate the underlying neural circuitry that is recruited to cause seizure-induced apnea and SUDEP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Classic Ehlers Danlos Syndrome (cEDS) is characterized by skin hyperextensibility and fragility, abnormal wound healing, and joint hypermobility, accompanied by chronic widespread pain, refractory to analgesics. The proposed experiments focus on skin and interactions between dermal fibroblasts and neurons in molecularly elucidated cEDS patients. This is an entirely new direction in the field that will advance our knowledge of mechanisms underlying pain in cEDS, and generate important new information into mechanisms of more prevalent painful conditions where neuron-fibroblast interactions play a role in the production of abnormal skin innervation and pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: There is a pressing need to find new compounds to help manage pain due to the ongoing opioid epidemic, and plants, being a source of other analgesic drugs, provide a useful starting point for discovering such compounds. Aconitum is a plant species used in traditional Chinese medicine that produces analgesic diterpenoid alkaloids, while American medicinal Aconitum species also produce diterpenoid alkaloids, but have not been explored in detail for analgesic properties. This project will analyze eight Aconitum species, specifically regarding their analgesic diterpenoid alkaloids that lack cardiotoxicity, with the goal of identifying lead compounds for future preclinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Selective and rapid transport of K+ ions across the cell membrane is controlled by potassium channels - trans- membrane proteins whose disfunction is linked to cardiac arrhythmias, epilepsies, and other channelopathies. Multidimensional ultrafast vibrational spectroscopy is a powerful technique for studying structure and dynamics of proteins. The GPU cluster we plan to acquire will significantly accelerate our proposed research designed to provide novel machine-learning-based framework for simulating vibrational spectra of proteins which will help interpret and design vibrational spectroscopy experiments aiming at elucidating the molecular underpinnings of activation and conduction of ion channels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid use disorder (OUD) continues to be a significant problem in urban areas disproportionately affecting lower income and minoritized populations. The findings from this study will provide an understanding of the neighborhood characteristics of urban communities and their influence on treatment outcomes for OUD. The findings from this study can contribute to future research and interventions that will focus on the larger and systematic issues prevalent in urban communities that impact OUD treatment retention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to elucidate fundamental knowledge of the link between three-dimensional genome organization and gene expression. This research will investigate the properties of cohesin complexes, identify and characterize novel cohesin-interacting proteins, and elucidate the role of cohesin-mediated DNA loops in regulation of transcription and chromatin state. This knowledge is critical for understanding human health and disease states linked to altered three-dimensional genome organization, such as developmental disorders and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Replication of the DNA within our genome requires a highly orchestrated series of molecular events to propagate genetic information during cell proliferation with high fidelity, and thus to suppress the onset of diseases such as cancer. This project will combine a unique genetic strategy in the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster with sophisticated imaging and molecular biology approaches to determine how the synthesis of histones proteins and their packaging of DNA into chromatin regulates the process and fidelity of DNA replication. Because of the high evolutionary conservation of regulators of chromatin and DNA replication, discoveries resulting from our mechanistic studies in flies will be directly applicable to humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Phase separation is a common cell biology phenomenon with unsolved implications in human aging and neurodegenerative diseases. Specialized instruments, such as the NanoLive microscope, can visualize phase- separated cell structures in living cells for a long period at unprecedented resolution, without harming cells. The use of it in our program will lead to new knowledge in phase separation biology and likely new drug targets to treat aging-related symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Program Narrative Neurosteroids and cholesterol are important signaling molecules that modulate the function of integral membrane proteins. The proposed research will define the specific binding sites for neurosteroids on various forms of their major target protein, the GABA type A receptor and for cholesterol on lipid scramblases and lysosomal signaling proteins. The work will identify site-specific agonists and antagonists for the sterol binding sites and provide new insights into the biological role of neurosteroids and cholesterol as allosteric modulators of protein function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plastin family of the actin cytoskeleton organizers contributes to the activation of immune cells, bone formation, cell division, migration, and adhesion as well as to shaping biological membranes essential for the absorbance of nutrients by the intestine, blood dialysis by kidneys, and audial perception by the inner ear. When disrupted or expressed ectopically, plastins contribute to the metastatic activity of cancer cells, autoimmune processes, congenital osteoporosis, syndrome of diaphragmatic hernia, and deafness. Our investigation will reveal fundamental molecular mechanisms underlying the activity of human plastins and will generate a strong and lasting impact on the fundamental understanding of the actin cytoskeleton leading to potential therapeutic interventions for cancers, familial osteoporosis, and autoimmune disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: Project Narrative There is a growing interest in the different types of non-canonical translation, including repeat associated non- AUG translation which is associated with RNA structure, translation in multiple frames and microsatellite expansion diseases. Having identified other forms of multi-frame non-canonical translation outside of RAN translation, the overarching goal of this proposal is to determine the RNA structures, protein networks and therapeutically relevant modifiers that govern different types of multi-frame translation. Together this information will provide a deeper understanding of the mechanism of multi-frame translation and the processes that govern human cellular proteome diversity, which in turn will enable informed therapy development across multiple microsatellite expansion diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: UPR COBRE Center for Neuroplasticity During Phase 3 the UPR Center for Neuroplasticity will continue to provide a multidisciplinary cadre of investigators with cutting-edge facilities, scientific capability, and multidisciplinary collaborations for the treatment of neurodegeneration-related diseases. Our projects are unified by shared thematic and technical factors toward understanding and treating neurological disorders, including, the origins of neural and mental health disorders, as well as elucidating the molecular basis for alcohol neuroadaptation, addiction, and neuroprotection. Our center will become a world-recognized center for the study of neurodegeneration-related diseases with therapeutic applications.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Targeting the molecular interactions of structural exopolysaccharides in bacterial biofilms is a promising new approach to treat persistent and hospital acquired infections resulting from biofilm infections. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Carbon monoxide (CO) gas has been identified as an essential signaling molecule in the human neuronal system and has been shown to have many therapeutic applications. Molecules that create CO gas upon activation with an external stimulus are commonly dubbed CO releasing molecules, or CORMs, and have shown to be vital tool in studying the effect of CO in biological systems. This research proposes to create a new class of CORMs based on organic molecules that efficiently produce CO gas, are directly polymerizable, and have predictable and well-defined products following the release of CO, attributes not currently accessible with state-of-the-art CORMs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Monitoring the burden of respiratory virus infections and disease is essential to public health surveillance and response, and foundational to preparedness for novel viral agents with pandemic potential. In this program, antibody test results and survey responses obtained from a large cohort of blood donors will be applied to calculate estimates of symptomatic and asymptomatic infections caused by major respiratory viruses nationally, within U.S. regions, and in specific race/ethnicity, sex, and age subgroups. Data generated in this program will also be used to investigate risk factors for infections; estimate antibody levels that protect against infections (including from new viral variants); and monitor uptake and attitudes towards vaccines, other prevention measures, and therapeutics.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-IP-24-046: Nationwide Cohort of Blood Donors to Estimate Burden of Respiratory Viruses and Immunologic Response

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic heavy alcohol consumption has been implicated in having negative effects on the skeleton. The proposed studies will evaluate the impact of heavy alcohol consumption on bone in a non-human primate model for voluntary drinking and in humans with chronic alcohol abuse who died following an accident. This research is important because of the large economic, social, and personal burden associated with poor bone health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public health relevance Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) transfer genetic information from the nucleus to the cytoplasm where they are translated. Establishment of the fly and frog lineages that provide continuity of the species and mammalian synaptic activity rely critically on mRNA localization. However, in humans, mislocalized mRNAs cause muscle disorders such as myotonic dystrophy 1 and have been linked to neurodegeneration, including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Our findings in this study will elucidate how organisms harness spatially organized mRNAs to promote development. Importantly, this knowledge will also enable fundamental understanding of how misregulation of mRNA localization could contribute to diseases such as MD1, ALS, and SCA.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The REACH (Research Expanding Access to Child Health) Center of Biomedical Research Excellence is providing the infrastructure needed for researchers across Delaware to join with stakeholders and community partners in the development, evaluation, and implementation of innovative interventions and models of care to overcome the complex socio-ecological factors responsible for pediatric health disparities. This Administrative Supplement to Recognize Excellence in Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility (DEIA) Mentorship will allow us to expand our REACH Center mentorship program to support a broader and more diverse group of investigators, staff, and trainees, cultivating their skills, benefiting the quality and impact of our research, and building a diverse biomedical research workforce. With this additional support, the REACH Center will propel scientific knowledge, technical capabilities, and clinical practice forward to improve healthcare for all children and families across Delaware with broad implications nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The activation of dioxygen by heme and nonheme metalloenzymes plays a critical role in many fundamental biological processes, including biosynthesis, detoxification, metabolic processes, and energy transfer, all of which directly or indirectly impact human health. The proposed studies focus on the synthesis and reactivity of small-molecule analogs of metalloenzyme active sites that process and manipulate various forms of oxygen. These efforts will provide fundamental knowledge relating to enzyme mechanisms which are implicated in a variety of diseases, including arthritis, cancer, genetic and neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: WONHWA CHO, PH.D. PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Lipid signaling is an important target for drug development for diverse human diseases, including cancer. Based on our recent research showing that membrane lipids directly and specifically control cellular activities of diverse proteins that are critically involved in cancer, we propose to elucidate the mechanisms underlying complex lipid-mediated cell regulation and develop drugs targeting lipid- protein binding interfaces. Given the general and fundamental importance of lipid signaling, our pioneering, innovative research should have major impact on broad areas of biology and medicine.

PHR: Narrative: Administrative Supplement to NIGMS MIRA R35GM122561 Parent project title: Dynamics and evolution of synthetic and natural gene regulatory networks This Administrative Supplement is a request for support for a Jess automated capillary-based western blot system by Bio-Techne, which allows for rapid detection of up to a dozen proteins in a single sample in a quantitative, highly reproducible manner, without a need for genetic modification. The Jess system will enable quantitative measurements of how synthetic biological control of genes affects protein levels, to be linked with cellular phenotypes. This will remove a bottleneck by providing information rapidly on multiple protein levels that can be further investigated to understand the network-level effects of synthetic biological perturbations, as proposed in the parent project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Desmosomes are protein complexes required for strong connections between cells, maintenance of tissue structure, and other cellular functions (such as proliferation and migration) via cell signaling. In our study, we propose to study how the desmosomal protein Desmoglein-2 controls the ability of cells to attach to and migrate on the extracellular matrix, a network of proteins which surrounds cells within tissues. These studies will provide important insights into how the attachments between cells control their migratory behavior, which is important during processes such as wound healing and tissue repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Many animals perform complex behaviors that are the result of varying arousal/motivational states, though identifying these states by behavior alone is challenging. In turn, how these states influence specific neuronal circuits to alter behavior is diffifcult in complex brains, but tractable in smaller invertebrate brains. We propose to use orb-weaving spiders to investigate how neuromodulation organizes behavioral states, and nematodes to understand how these states alter neuronal architecture.

PHR: Project Narrative The mission of the Rochester EHSC is to improve health through the creation of knowledge and discovery of mechanisms by which environmental exposures, singly and in combination, contribute to health risk across the life span, and translating findings into strategies to mitigate risks and improve human health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The project’s cornerstone is the integration of high-frequency neuromodulation, a method proven effective in invasive spinal cord stimulation therapies, into a non-invasive modality that targets the spinal structures non-invasively. By creating a compact, multilayer High-Frequency Trans-Spinal Magnetic Stimulation (HF-TSMS) system, we aim to modulate the neural pathways associated with pain transmission and management directly, offering a significant advantage over traditional surgical intervention methods. HF-TSMS seeks to mitigate the pain associated with sciatica, potentially reducing or eliminating the reliance on pharmacological treatments, which are often accompanied by significant side effects and the risk of addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding how interactions between dietary protein and the intestinal microbiota impact human health will allow rational design of customized therapeutic interventions that consider detrimental and beneficial impacts of different dietary protein sources. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will reduce the burdens of human illness. The research is also relevant to the mission of the NIGMS as it will provide new, broadly applicable methods to increase the understanding of functional interactions between humans and their microbiota, which lays the foundation for advances in disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biomedical research is rapidly shifting towards data-driven discovery powered by Artificial Intelligence (AI)/Machine Learning (ML), but many researchers lack the skills to unlock its potential. This project proposes a cloud-based NIGMS Sandbox module, "Practical Data-Centric AI/ML for Biomedical Researchers," to bridge this gap. The module dives into essential topics like data preparation, model building and interpretation, empowering biomedical researchers with hands-on skills and real-world tools through accessible Google Cloud platform, capstone projects, and diverse learning formats; therefore, this accessible learning journey will equip researchers to ethically apply AI/ML to their research, contribute to a future of AI-driven advancements, and elevate research quality through responsible practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell migration is an important process that occurs in many physiological and pathophysiological contexts, including embryogenesis, inflammation, wound healing and tumor metastasis. Our published and preliminary data indicate a previously unrecognized role for contacts between the endoplasmic reticulum and the plasma membrane in the migration of metastatic cells. This project seeks to understand the mechanisms by which calcium influx and lipid transfer are coordinated at these sites, and how they regulate cell motility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Natural product compounds occupy a central role in medicine in providing lifesaving drugs. Supply challenges however often constrain the biomedical potential of promising bioactive natural products from rare or environmentally sensitive marine organisms. Our discovery of the first terpenoid biosynthesis genes in marine animals and amongst the first in marine algae towards flagship bioactive molecules like the anti-inflammatory pseudodopterosin and anticancer halomon offers a path to bioengineering drug leads from marine organisms from sustainable laboratory microbial fermentation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Defects in the internal organization of cells and the transport mechanisms of their proteins and membranes underlie the pathogenesis of many human diseases including cancer, neurodegeneration (e.g., Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, ALS), brain injury and metabolic disorders. This research program aims to advance our knowledge of how transport within cells is spatially controlled by a unique family of proteins called septins. The proposed research will advance basic knowledge of cell biology, which in the long-term will be used to design better treatments that can reverse or slow down disease and/or to regenerate ailing cells and tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The abscission checkpoint is a cell cycle checkpoint that arrests cytokinetic abscission to ensure the upstream events of mitosis are completed properly before cells finally divide. This proposal will integrate new molecular signaling pathways that contribute to the maintenance of the abscission checkpoint as well as characterize cellular programs that promote faithful abscission during an abscission arrest. In the long term, our research may enable new therapeutic strategies, so that we are better able to diagnose and treat diseases when this checkpoint fails.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Methods capable of defining protein complex dynamic directly in living systems hold tremendous promise for defining the molecular mechanisms that underlie normal and disease signaling. Here we propose to develop and validate several complementary light-dependent proximity profiling platforms capable of detecting protein interaction dynamics in live cells with high spatial and temporal resolution, as well as minimal perturbation to the cellular environment. Application of these platforms to map the protein social network remodeling in response dysregulated cellular metabolism and redox regulation will provide an unparalleled view of disease signaling, as well as serve as a blueprint for future studies of other dynamic signaling pathways with photoproximity platforms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hermansky-Pudlak Syndrome (HPS) is a group of inherited autosomal recessive disorders caused by genetic mutations that alter the trafficking of lysosomal-related organelles/vesicles. In a subset of patients with HPS-1 and HPS-4, pulmonary fibrosis develops in the fourth or fifth decade of life, and is a major cause of morbidity and mortality. Experiments proposed in this project will define the cellular and molecular mechanisms of CHI3L1 receptor system, and whether CHI3L1 and its receptor systems are plausible targets to treat HPS-associated lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During cell division, each daughter cell must inherit exactly one copy of each chromosome as errors can lead to cancer and birth defects. Two large cellular machines are responsible for segregating chromosomes: the spindle and kinetochore. Here we probe how these machines’ building blocks together give rise to their function, aiming to uncover the mechanical design principles driving chromosome segregation and to ultimately better target dividing cells for therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Epigenetic information carriers and their signaling consequences play critical roles in all aspects of eukaryotic genome management, but many of their mechanisms remain poorly understood. My research program spans a host of traditional disciplines (discovery biochemistry, technology development, quantitative genomics, chemical biology, biophysics, and cell biology) with the goal of developing fundamental mechanistic understanding of epigenetic information systems.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying the mechanisms correlated with increased health care use among Black youth in foster care is important for improving health outcomes and reducing the high cost of healthcare. This study utilizes 11 years of linked child welfare and electronic health records data (N~7,500 patients) and incorporates the voices of young people in foster care through the use of a Research Participant Advisory Council to evaluate the salience of multiple social identities on healthcare use variation, coordination of medical care, and health care outcomes. Understanding the mechanisms for racial disparities within the healthcare system for foster youth may increase positive health outcomes, decrease health care costs, and promote equity in health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RESEARCH STRATEGY Background. NIGMS grant R35 GM148220-02 supports research on protein chemistry. This grant is focused on an increasingly important challenge in biomedicine—the traceless delivery of proteins to the cytosol of human cells. This ability provides far-reaching, long-term opportunities for high-impact advances in biomedicine, chemical biology, and allied fields. This supplemental application is for a single piece of equipment that is critical for the completion of the proposed research.  Need for the Requested Equipment. Grant R35 GM148220 proposes the use of diazo compounds to create “protein prodrugs”. In this approach, the esterification of protein carboxylates temporarily “cloaks” the anionic charge in a target protein (Figure 1), enabling membrane transversal. The internalized esters are hydrolyzed by cytosolic esterases, much like small- molecule prodrugs.  This research requires the ability to monitor quantitatively (1) the synthesis of novel diazo Figure 1. Key aspects of the research supported by grant R35 GM148220 and structures of esterified proteins formed from novel cognate α-aryl diazo compounds. Resistance to spontaneous hydrolysis is conferred by either steric interactions or an intramolecular n→π* interaction that elicits the Pauli exclusion principle. Release is achieved by esterase- mediated p-quinone-methide formation. compounds, (2) the rate at which those diazo compounds esterify carboxylic acids, and (3) the kinetic stability of the ensuing esters in both the absence and presence of human esterases. In the first two years of support, we have learned that spontaneous hydrolysis can limit the practical utility of nascent esters. (A typical half-life is a few days.) Accordingly, we are now seeking diazo compounds that generate esters that are stable to spontaneous hydrolysis but removable by cellular esterases. Our strategy is to generate esters that are protected by steric effects or Pauli exclusion (as only one electron pair can occupy an orbital). The esters are designed to be cleaved by p-quinone methide formation. We have conceived of many new α-aryl diazo compounds along these lines (e.g., Figure 1). We now seek to make and test them.  This request arises because there is an urgent, unexpected need for the requested equipment. First, our need for analytical chromatography greatly exceeds that expected upon submission of our grant application in January 2022 because of the need to make and test many new diazo compounds. Second, we have lost our ability to perform any analytical chromatography. Our laboratory had a functioning Agilent 1200 series HPLC instrument for analytical chromatography (Figure 2). This instrument was purchased in 2008 and was a workhorse for 16 years. With this instrument, we characterized hundreds of compounds and performed thousands of assays, leading to dozens of publications. Unfortunately, the instrument is broken and irreparable. We now have a daily need for this instrument that cannot be accommodated elsewhere. For example, the use of instrumentation facilities is slow and inefficient, does not allow for the use of columns appropriate for polar molecules like ours (e.g., C4 and HIC), and is expensive, putting an undue burden on the budget of our NIGMS grant.  Description of the Requested Equipment. We request support for the purchase of an LC/MSD instrument from Agilent Technologies (Lexington, MA). This instrument uses powerful mass-selective detection to enhance analytical precision and is designed for efficiency. Its single quadrupole provides both flexibility and insight. The instrument has these capabilities that are essential for our research: Figure 2. Photograph of the rust-laden, nonfunctional 16-year-old analytical HPLC instrument in our laboratory. · High mass accuracy (±0.005 Da) · Flexibility to detect compounds with ESI, APPI, APCI, and multimode ion sources · Diode array detector with ultrafast scan speeds · Automated multisampler for vials and microplates · Simple, intuitive software that includes the OpenLab chromatography data system (CDS) · Rapid confirmation of interpretations through a library-match search technology This instrument would not only meet the urgent, unexpected need described above but also enhance the overall impact of grant R35 GM148220 by facilitating nearly all of the synthetic and analytical procedures inherent in the proposed research.  Oversight and Training Plan. An engineer from Agilent Technologies would install the equipment, and a representative would provide training, both free of charge. To ensure that the requested instrument is accessible but maintained in like-new condition for the foreseeable future, we have designed a plan for instrument oversight. Specifically, we would house and maintain the instrument in MIT Room 18-344D, which is an equipment room within our laboratory. That location is ideal because of its central location and ready accessibility to personnel.  A postdoctorate in our research group, Dr. Bjarne Silkenath, would facilitate the training of individual users and provide oversight. Dr. Silkenath is a synthetic organic chemist who has much experience in both liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry. He would host training events in which he would present the capabilities of the instrument to potential users. After attending such a session, individual users would contact him to request hands-on training, access to documentation on standard operating procedures, and certification to use the instrument independently. Certified users would be provided with the opportunity to sign up for a particular block of time on a first-come, first-served basis. Lastly, prior to leaving our research group, Dr. Silkenath would be responsible for appointing and training his successor, who would be chosen based on their experience with the instrument and their accountability.  Other Users. The reach of the requested equipment supplement would extend beyond the laboratory of the PI. Specifically, the requested instrument would be shared with other departmental researchers, including Profs. Buchwald (R35 GM122483), Cummins (R01 GM130936), Movassaghi (R01 GM141963), Nolan (R01 GM118695 and R01 GM126376), and Shoulders (R35 GM136354). Notably, we have recently published joint papers with Profs. Buchwald, Cummins, and Movassaghi, and our groups have highly active collaborations.  Cost of the Requested Equipment. We have negotiated a 28% discount on the list price for an LC/MS from Agilent Technologies. The price quote is attached to this application. To supplement this cost, we would provide a computer (~$2000) to operate the equipment, and we would use institutional funds to purchase a yearly service contract for ~$6000 per year (see below).  Maintenance of the Requested Equipment. To ensure that the requested equipment is maintained in like-new condition, institutional funds would support a service contract from Agilent Technologies. The corporate headquarters of Agilent Technologies is in Lexington, MA, which is a 30-minute drive from our laboratory. Our department has many pieces of Agilent equipment and has negotiated a blanket contract to cover the cost of servicing that equipment. We project that the cost of servicing the new equipment would be ~$6,000 per year and would provide us with a yearly planned maintenance visit, technical assistance center service for operational and instrument set-up problems, and remote instrument diagnostics. Finally, we note that funds are not available in the budget of grant R35 GM044783 for the purchase of the requested equipment without the displacement of essential personnel. Summary We thank you for your consideration of this request for an equipment supplement, which is essential for the execution of the research proposed in grant R35 GM044783.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell fate engineering, for example the directed differentiation of pluripotent stem cells or the direct conversion among somatic cell types, holds great promise to improve disease modeling, drug screening, and to lead to regenerative medicine therapies. However, our ability to engineering cell fate with fidelity has been impeded by an incomplete understanding of the biological networks that govern development. In the parent award for this grant, we are addressing this problem through a combination of algorithm development and experimental validation, with an emphasis on cell types related to the synovial joint, as well as their developmental progenitors. The Imaging System that we request in this grant will transform our ability to address the overarching goals of the parent award by enabling us to perform more rigorous, robust, and quantitative imaging of our validation and discovery experiments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The presence of unstable forms of oxygen (reactive oxygen species) are known to have large consequences on wound healing and regenerative outcomes. But it is still not well understood how the same oxygen species regulate these two different processes, even though millions are affected each year by poor wound healing and an inability to restore functional tissue. This project seeks to identify the genes and signaling pathways downstream of reactive oxygen species that control wound healing versus tissue repair, in order to identify new targets for treatment to promote proper healing after injury, surgery, and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative from the Parent Award Through the application of advanced biophysical methods and computational approaches, we will address a range of exciting yet challenging biological phenomena including voltage-activation of a sensory membrane protein, metabolite transport across a bilayer, membrane protein folding, stress-induced phase separation, and properties of disordered proteins, both soluble and membrane bound. To address these topics in depth, we are expanding the applicability of hydrogen exchange techniques to membrane proteins under an activating voltage, during their folding, and even in vivo to examine their dynamics in cells. Our Upside simulation algorithm is powerful and enhances each of the experimental projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapeutic glycoproteins (biologics) such as antibodies address critical health care needs, but there are currently no simple methods for analyzing the attached glycans (sugar molecules) during the biologics production. The ability to monitor the glycosylation of biologics during their production would be transformative for biopharmaceutical R&D and would accelerate the creation of new biologics and biosimilars. Our innovative technology enables monitoring of protein glycosylation in near real-time in a robust and convenient manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: No Change from Original Project Narrative Project Narrative Septic survivors exhibit long-term immunologic dysfunction associated with higher rates of disability, depression, subsequent infections, and all-cause mortalities; however, our understanding of the regulation of these responses and their impact on disease is lacking. This proposal will integrate mechanistic in vivo studies with human data and quality of life outcomes measures to provide an in-depth assessment of the systemic epigenetic events that occur during sepsis and how their regulation of the post-septic immunosuppressive response effects the immunologic and functional outcomes of patients. The proposal has the potential to provide fundamental insight into disease regulation and novel therapeutics for the treatment of post-sepsis immunosuppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cytoplasmic compartmentalization mechanisms have the potential to influence broad cellular processes and pathways, including how, when, and where mRNAs are translated, silenced, or degraded. The research outlined in this proposal will elucidate the molecular and functional role of a new cytoplasmic niche between membrane- bound organelles and membrane-less RNA-protein organelles. We expect the results from these studies will yield fundamental insights into how cells under duress rapidly switch from bulk mRNA translation to sequestration, as well as, how cells prevent membrane-less organelles from developing into toxic RNA-protein aggregates.
