IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Cell plasticity, the ability of cells to change their phenotypes without genetic mutations, is crucial for the development and the progress of diseases such as cancer. Post-transcriptional mechanisms are essential for cell plasticity as they offer a route to regulate cell fate, specifically in response to rapid changes in response to environmental cues. This proposal investigates the mechanisms by which translational control and RNA modifications regulate cell plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About 40% of prescribed drugs target G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), which activate transducer proteins called G proteins and arrestins to produce effects that can be either beneficial or detrimental to human health. It is not known how GPCRs select the correct transducers needed to produce appropriate cellular or therapeutic responses, or how the cellular context affects this molecular mechanism. This project aims to increase understanding of how GPCRs interact with their transducers to produce coordinated cellular signals, and may facilitate the development of drugs with the capacity to fine-tune cell signaling and better treat disease. This supplement request will support acquisition of a BMG Labtech Omega plate reader, which will be essential for studying endogenously-expressed GPCRs and G proteins in their native context in real time. This instrument is the only one available with the capacity to monitor bioluminescence resonance energy transfer (BRET) with high temporal resolution. This supplement request will not change the scope of the project. The requested equipment will replace existing equipment that was used for the project but recently failed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell division is a key process in biology; it is the process by which cells separate their genetic material (chromosomes) into two identical daughter cells and coordinated by a microtubule-based machinery called the mitotic spindle. Although spindles are essential to the life of a healthy cell, and spindle malfunction can result in cancers and other disease states, we still do not know how microtubules are made at the correct location and time to build the mitotic spindle. Our work seeks to uncover exactly how microtubules make mitotic spindles, which will help explain not only how a cell divides, but can help us understand the origins of diseases that begin in improper cell division and cell regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE The aging and rural populations of northern New England suffer from numerous chronic health issues, including cancer, obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and substance abuse. The Northern New England Clinical and Translational Research Network, which includes healthcare, educational and research institutions in Maine, Vermont, and New Hampshire, has helped build a foundation for clinical and translational research in the tri-state region. In this renewal application, our goal is to strengthen our network of clinical and translational research through a learning infrastructure that is supported by the principles of diversity, inclusion, and equity, for the benefit of all residents in our region.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: RESEARCH STRATEGY: Understanding Double-Stranded RNA Recognition in Human Cells — Instrument Supplement Summary of parent grant R35GM150953 Recognition of double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) structures underlie many important biological processes, such as RNA interference, innate immune sensing of foreign RNAs, and post-transcriptional gene regulation. My lab focuses on two areas of dsRNA recognition: microRNA (miRNA) biogenesis and innate immune sensing. During miRNA biogenesis, Microprocessor, consisting of Drosha and DGCR8, recognizes and cleaves hairpin-like structures from long transcripts called primary miRNAs (pri-miRNAs). My previous work has built a unifying model of human pri-miRNA1 and discovered that some natural, suboptimal miRNA hairpins rely on neighboring optimal miRNA hairpins for efficient Microprocessor cleavage—known as “cluster assistance”2. Nearly 40% of human miRNAs reside in clusters, with many implicated in diseases and influenced by cluster assistance. We propose to dissect this fundamental regulatory mechanism in miRNA biogenesis using biochemical, single-molecule, and structural approaches (Project 1).  Recognition of dsRNA by innate immune sensors such as RIG-I and MDA5 initiates antiviral responses3. Recent studies show that endogenous dsRNAs can also activate these sensors, sometimes resulting in autoinflammatory and autoimmune diseases4. The recognition of self dsRNAs therefore needs to be restricted by proteins that modify, degrade, or shield endogenous dsRNAs. Building on our expertise in dsRNA recognition and processing, we proposed to 1) develop new biochemical methods to identify dsRNA ligands of innate immune sensors (Project 2), and 2) develop new genetic screen methods to identify factors that restrict self dsRNA sensing in innate immunity (Project 3). Together these studies will provide crucial insights into how cellular dsRNAs are sensed and regulated, with therapeutic implications for cancer, autoimmune and infectious diseases. Recent progress and scientific justification For Project 1, we have made important progress dissecting the mechanism of cluster-assisted pri-miRNA procesing. We had envisioned two models of cluster assistance: in a dimerization model, one Microprocessor binds the helper miRNA hairpin and promotes the binding of a second Microprocessor to the recipient hairpin; in a transfer model, Microprocessor binds and cleaves the helper hairpin and is then transferred to the proximal recipient (Figure 1). These processes could be mediated by ERH which I identified biochemically2, and SAFB proteins that the Herzog lab Figure 1. Working models of cluster assistance. identified through a CRISPR screen5.  To test these models biochemically, we utilized an in vitro pri-miRNA cleavage assay, which I previously established using lysates from cells that overexpress Drosha and DGCR8. This in vitro system recapituates cluster assistance, i.e., the defective miR-451 hairpin was cleaved faster in the context of the miR- 144~451 cluster. To test whether cleavage of the miR-144 helper hairpin is required for cluster assistance, we introduced modifications (phosphorothioate linkages flanked by 2′-O methylation) at both cleavage sites of the miR- Figure 2. Blocking miR-144 hairpin cleavage inhibited cluster 144 hairpin, which successfully blocked assistance. The line for each substrate represents the best fit of all of cleavage of the miR-144 hairpin (data not the data to an exponential reaction course, which generated the shown) by Drosha. Importantly, preventing the observed rate constants (k, shown ± 95% confidence intervals). Pri- processing of miR-144 hairpin abolished cluster miR-144*~451 has modifications to block miR-144 hairpin cleavage. assistance (Figure 2). This finding suggests that the dimerization model is unlikely. To strengthen this result, we are testing whether blocking one out of the two Drosha cleavage sites is sufficient to inhibit cluster assistance, and we will also test whether such cleavage-site modifications affect Micrprocessor binding.  1  We have also purified a C terminus-truncated form of SAFB2 and showed that it can enhance the cleavage of miR-451 hairpin in the cluster context in vitro. Therefore, cluster assistance can now be reconstituted using purified Microprocessor, ERH, and SAFB2 (Figure 3). Next, we will map the interaction between SAFB2 and Microprocessor using crosslinking mass spec. We will then introduce mutations that disrupt SAFB2–Microprocessor interactions to identify residues important for cluster assistance. Furthermore, as proposed in the parent award, we will use cryo-EM to provide the structural basis of cluster assistance.  For project 2, we proposed to identify endogenous dsRNAs that activate innate immune Figure 3. Reconstitution of cluster assistance using sensors. We have developed a novel approach using purified Microprocessor. Processing assays of pri-miR-451 mouse oocyte Dicer (mDcrO), which misses the and pri-miR-144~451 using purified Microprocessor, with the helicase domain and cleaves long dsRNAs much presence of SAFB2 and ERH as indicated above. The red star better than full-length mammalian Dicer6,7. We indicates 3′ radiolabel. transiently overexpressed mDcrO in HEK293T cells, performed small RNA-sequencing analyses to identify mDcrO-dependent small RNAs, and then predicted the dsRNAs from which these small RNAs are processed by mDcrO. We used MACS2 peak calling8,9 to identify sRNA clusters. Our initial experiments identified 1297 small RNA clusters derived from intermolecular and intramolecular dsRNAs. The majority (66%) come from intramolecular folding of repetitive elements. We identified 60 stem-loop structures in the 5′ UTR and 41 in the 3′ UTR of mRNA transcripts. We also identified 51 intermolecular dsRNAs formed by overlapping transcripts (27 at the 3′ end, and 24 at the 5′ end). We are currently investigating the editing status of these dsRNAs to understand how editing suppresses innate immune sensing of dsRNAs. Our preliminary data suggest that many of the intermolecular dsRNAs formed by 3′ overlaps do not have extensive editing, and we plan to pull-down these dsRNA pairs and identify potential proteins that prevent them from activating MDA5.  For project 3, we proposed to identify regulators that restrict sensing of endogenous dsRNA in human cells through CRISPR screens. We have made CRISPRi-compatible, GFP knock-in N/TERT-1 cells that reports IFN-β expression. We have verified this cell line in a mock screen (data not shown), and we are currently conducting a genome-wide screen to identify factors whose loss results in increased IFN-β expression. After obtaining the hits, we will verify and focus on RNA-related genes. We will then use biochemical, genetic, and other approaches to understand the mechanism by which these genes suppress endogenous dsRNA sensing. Rationale for the purchase of an ÄKTA pure micro system: Project 1 is a mechanistic project that relies heavily on protein and RNA purification. Although Projects 2 and 3 are discovery-oriented, we expect to move beyond discovery and conduct mechanistic studies using biochemical approaches. Currently we are using an ÄKTA pure 25 M system in the laboratory of my RNA Therapeutics Institute colleague Dr. Li Li. Dr Li’s system meets our current purification needs, but the ÄKTA pure micro system will be much better suited for our proposed cryo-EM studies because of specific requirement of sample concentration and quality. In addition, we routinely use the mammalian expression system (Expi293) for protein purification. The expression system is expensive and does not efficiently produce large quantities of RNA-binding proteins, so our experiments will benefit from the ability to purify minute quantities of proteins and RNA–protein complexes for analyzing protein–protein interactions, oligomerization states, and RNA–protein interactions. The small injection and elution volumes, improved resolution, and sharper peaks offered by the ÄKTA pure micro is ideal in this respect. I have recently hired a postdoc who has extensive experience with cryo-EM analysis of RNA–protein complexes, and who has used the ÄKTA pure micro system before. Therefore, we are prepared to take full advantage of this system. Plans for service contracts The service contract for the requested ÄKTA pure micro system will cost ~$6,600 per year. I will use my startup provided by the RNA Therapeutics Institute (my host department at UMass Chan Medical School) to cover the service contract for the duration of the project. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: People living with HIV (PLWH) show heightened distress and increased inflammatory burden, leading to greater complex morbidity including high prevalence of cannabis use disorder and major depressive disorders. However, the mechanisms governing stress-immune interactions in PLWH, and their associated distress and drug use are not well understood. Applying a powerful and novel cross-diagnostic human experimental paradigm with multiple complementary approaches, in this application, we will investigate the epigenetic mechanisms regulating “stress- genome” at cell type resolution among PLWH with complex comorbidities of cannabis use disorder and major depressive disorder.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the aims of the COBRE in Stroke Recovery at the Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC) is to strengthen innovative scientific cores that support/advance stroke recovery research. This equipment supplement will allow MUSC to purchase the NeuroFUS PRO Neuronavigated tFUS System that will not only provide cutting edge access to technology not typically available to stroke recovery researchers, but also will create novel, personalized tFUS interventions that have promise to treat a wide variety of post-stroke deficits by visualizing and administering precision noninvasive deep brain stimulation. This system is a first-in-class, state- of-the-art platform.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kentucky (KY) is a high priority Ending the HIV Epidemic (EHE) jurisdiction due to heavy rural HIV burden and exceptionally high rates of new HIV diagnoses driven by injection drug use. A central pillar of EHE is the prevention of new HIV infections through scale up of Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP) in people who inject drugs (PWID). The proposed study will deploy a novel, stepped-care intervention within rurally-located syringe service programs (SSPs) and conduct a robust test of efficacy on PrEP initiation and persistence among rural PWID, which is critical for achieving progress toward EHE goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The proposed research will be focused on technology development for ultra-high sensitivity deep proteomic analysis of limited biological and clinical samples. Comprehensive proteome characterization of such samples at the level of digests, intact proteoforms, native non-covalent protein complexes, and protein interactions is presently an insurmountable challenge in bioanalytical research. The proposed technology offers an unprecedented opportunity for expanding our knowledge of molecular mechanisms of disease processes and identifying new paths toward the discovery of diagnostic and prognostic biomarkers using minuscule sample amounts. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Skin color is genetically derived traits that is highly variable between human subpopulations and is determined by the quantity, type and distribution of melanin pigment. Variable melanin production by skin pigment cells not only drives skin color variation but also contributes to differential disease susceptibility among humans. This proposal seeks to understand the epigenetic and transcriptional mechanisms that govern variable melanin production resulting in human pigmentation diversity and has implications for human evolution, health and disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposed career development supplement to the RE-JOIN consortium, we will collect paired clinical pain data that occurs with both activity and rest in knee osteoarthritis with tissue level data. To better understand mechanisms of pain – a goal that compliments that of the consortium - we will collect patient-reported pain mapping, quantitative sensory testing, and magnetic resonance imaging and link it with histopathological data from the medial and lateral knee joints of discarded tissue from knee replacement surgeries in osteoarthritis patients. Through the acquisition, analysis, and dissemination of this knowledge, we hope to make major strides in our long-term goal to improve patient outcomes for those suffering from osteoarthritis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance to public health: Circadian clocks are biological timers that govern physiology and behavior; however, the underlying regulatory mechanisms are not fully understood. The fundamental insights will advance our understanding of biological timing and may ultimately lead to novel chronotherapies against clock-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A diverse array of chemicals and drugs including certain chemical warfare agents (sulfur mustard, lewisite), intravenous chemotherapy drugs (mechlorethamine-MEC, paclitaxel, liposomal doxorubicin), and environmental toxins (snake venom metalloproteinases and blister beetle cantharidin) can disrupt the dermal-epidermal junction (DEJ) and cause blistering, thereby placing a patient at risk for infection, loss of fluid and electrolyte homeostasis, and scarring; moreover, an effective antidote to blistering is still lacking and current medical treatments for blistering are limited to supportive therapy. The overall goal of the studies proposed here is to investigate the influence of rationally selected mast cell-derived mediators (histamine and tryptase), neutrophil-derived mediators (myeloperoxidase, MPO and matrix metalloproteinase 9, MMP-9) and keratinocyte-specific collagens (collagen IV, COL4 and collagen XVII, COL17) in the cutaneous response to DEJ disruption over time. The achievement of proposal objectives will more fully describe the complex response of skin to DEJ disruption and provide novel targets for the discovery of drugs capable of reducing blistering and restoring the DEJ.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The gut microbiota has a profound effect on human health and physiology, providing benefits to the host such as modulation of immune development, inhibition of pathogen colonization, digestion of dietary fibers and absorption of nutrients, while abnormalities in microbiota composition, or dysbiosis, have been implicated in numerous and diverse disease states. Microorganisms possess varied and efficient strategies for competing for nutrients in the human gut, on which they depend as a critical energy source, the molecular mechanisms of which remain poorly understood and are the focus of the studies proposed here. Our research will allow us to build an intellectual framework for the design of methods and molecules with which to remodel the composition of the gut microbiota in order to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Cytokine signaling is essential to immune function and is an area with great clinical therapeutic potential. Dozens of cytokine families have different roles in the immune system which all signal through their specific combinations Janus kinases (Jaks) and STAT proteins. We propose using biochemistry, biophysics, and protein engineering to understand how the different cytokine receptor families interact with the Jaks and STATs which will identify new targets for tuning cytokine signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Parent Grant) This project is devoted to the development of a novel integrative, structure-based, artificial intelligence driven methodology for rapid chemical probe discovery against any target protein. The candidate molecules will be experimentally validated for three selected targets, transcription factor brachyury, hydrolase NUDT5, and bromodomain BAZ2B, and then optimized, using computational algorithms, into lead molecules to seed chemical probe development. We expect that our AI-based computational approach to convert crystallographically- determined chemical fragments into lead compounds coupled with the experimental validation of computational algorithms will accelerate the discovery of new chemical probes, expand the coverage of druggable proteome, and support future drug discovery studies.

PHR: Narrative Biomedical research produces vast quantities of raw data that require analysis with suitable tools and interpretation to draw meaningful conclusions. The self-learning training module we propose aims to facilitate the analysis of extensive genomic datasets in a cloud environment, utilizing standardized tools without the necessity of local server downloads. This approach obviates the need for establishing a local IT infrastructure to handle large-scale data analysis, thereby democratizing access to data and resources across all institutions.

Our goal is to increase the number and quality of health professionals who apply expertise in epidemiology, biostatistics, prevention science, and services research to substance use research use research. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Respiratory viruses, like SARS-CoV-2 and RSV, can cause major problems in society by making people sick and causing death, especially in older people, babies, and those with weakened immune systems. The proposed work will provide critical information on who these viruses affect, how quickly they spread in communities and in households, and how well we are protected by vaccines and previous infections. This information will better inform how to protect people from getting sick, and allow us to respond quickly and effectively to new outbreaks.

PHR: Project Narrative Domesticated foxes, unlike their wild ancestors, respond in a positive, friendly manner towards humans, similar to domesticated dogs, who, unlike their wolf ancestors, are friendly to people. This project studies the genetics of these inherited behaviors in order to understand the causes and mechanisms involved and to potentially gain broader insight into a range of human neurological disorders that are characterized by impaired social reciprocity or by anxiety-related and/or aggressive behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative of Parent Award This study will uncover fundamental molecular mechanisms that regulate neural circuit development through interactions between cell surface proteins. Although our work is conducted in Drosophila, there is a subfamily of human proteins that corresponds to the Dprs and DIPs, called the IgLONs, which are important for neural circuit formation and have been linked to autism, schizophrenia, and dyslexia. By establishing how these proteins instruct precise neural circuit development, our work will build a foundation for clinical approaches to treat these debilitating diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - R35 PARENT GRANT The gut microbiota plays a role in protecting humans from disease, digesting food, and shaping immune system function. This project will investigate bacterial mechanisms that control why microbial community composition differs from one individual to another. A deeper understanding of these genes and pathways will inform design of personalized probiotics to treat diseases where the gut microbiota is perturbed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative from the Parent Award Stresses such as increased heat and oxidation cause condensation of protein and RNA into aggregates which drive a universally conserved response. Following our recent discoveries that these aggregates, long thought to be toxic, are instead often adaptive, we are pursuing an understanding of the novel functions and regulation of these adaptive condensates in the response to heat shock. We use integrated methods, from biochemistry to cell biology, to understand these phenomena in molecular detail, continuing our longstanding work in a budding yeast model and extending our efforts to understand physiological temperature-dependent responses in the immune system during fever.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance to Public Health The identification, recruitment, selection, and mentorship of scientists from diverse backgrounds to conduct research on Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) (i.e., AD-RCMAR Scientists) and to launch their independent research careers will enhance the diversity of the aging research workforce. The work of the AD-RCMR Scientists and the San Diego Alzheimer’s Disease Resource Center for Minority Aging Research will promote critical advances in our understanding and ability to target multilevel factors and interventions to address ADRD inequities among Hispanics/Latinos, limited English proficient (LEP) and refugee communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Zhou, Xianjin Project Narrative Glutamate excitotoxicity contributes to the pathogenesis of many different psychiatric disorders and is the primary mechanism for neuronal injury in neurological diseases. Currently, there is no medicine that can suppress glutamate excitotoxicity without inhibiting cognitive functions. Success of this application will open up a new avenue for the development of therapeutic long-lasting autoantibodies that specifically suppress glutamate excitotoxicity and enhance cognitive functions in many neurological diseases and psychiatric disorders including TBI, PTSD, and schizophrenia. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Misregulation of chromatin states either via misregulation of ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling enzymes or misregulation of heterochromatin is strongly associated with cancer and developmental defects. Yet how chromatin remodeling enzymes work or how heterochromatin is assembled and regulated is poorly understood. This proposal combines biophysical approaches with cellular tests to tackle these challenging questions, with the goal of identifying key steps that are targets for regulation and that can be controlled for therapeutic intervention in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Genome instability, which is associated with multiple human diseases, is a byproduct of mutations that accumulate in the human genome as a result of the error prone DNA copying translesion synthesis (TLS) enzymes. Recent publications and strong preliminary work from my lab have shown that the TLS REV1 polymerase regulates metabolic pathways, mitotic fidelity, and replication stress, all of which are known to be associated with genome instability. This proposal will determine the molecular mechanisms by which REV1 controls these non-TLS functions and their potential roles in genome instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Proper control over the cell cycle is essential to development, homeostasis, and regeneration. The regulation of differentiation and the specification of cell fates has been extensively studied, as have the fundamental mechanisms of cell cycle control, but ubiquitous correlations observed between cell fate and the cell cycle have not been studied in detail. To understand how cell fate regulates the duration of the cell cycle and how changes in the duration of the cell cycle influence cell fate, we will employ a combination of cell lineage tracing, spatial transcriptomics, and an evolutionary approach to studying the structure of developmental lineages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Pesticides, fungicides and insecticides are established risk-factors for neuronal injury and neurodegenerative onset. Here, we develop and test whether Carbon Quantum Dots (CQDs), which are nano materials synthesized from bio-waste precursors such as fruit peel, lignin, used frying oil and recycled paper, can restore cellular and organismal deficits induced by pesticide exposure. The proposed microscopy imaging work is important because, if successful, it advances a mechanistic understanding of how CQDs can exert their neuroprotective effects in vitro and in vivo by mitigating pesticide-associated neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Fear and anxiety underlie the most common forms of mental illness in the United States, with more than 30% of Americans experiencing an emotional disorder at some point in their life. Consequently, a major goal of NIH is to understand the neural mechanisms that underlie adaptive and maladaptive threat processing. The hippocampus and dopamine release (via the locus coeruleus and ventral tegmental area) both contribute to fear and anxiety, but it is not known how they interact during these states to promote the encoding of aversive memories. This represents a major gap in our understanding of the neural systems that contribute to emotional disorders. Altered catecholamine release accompanies schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and ADHD, which are often comorbid with fear and anxiety disorders. Alzheimer’s disease also produces severe atrophy of the locus coeruleus, which reduces catecholamine release throughout the brain and is thought to exacerbate amnesia. To determine how altered catecholamine levels impact these disorders, it is essential to establish the basic mechanisms by which neuromodulatory inputs to the hippocampus regulate the formation of aversive memories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative When a taste is placed on our tongues, we must recognize that a taste is on the tongue, identify that taste, decide whether it’s palatable or not, and then either swallow it or expel it. These processes require integration of information about taste from the periphery, which is relayed to the taste cortex, in part through the gustatory thalamus, though it is unclear how thalamus and gustatory cortex interact to produce activity in gustatory cortex that reflects stimulus identity and palatability, which we will study here. These results will increase our understanding of taste that will help us fight against a spectrum of feeding-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Even genetically identical bacteria may activate different subsets of genes leading to coexistence of diverse metabolic states and behaviors within a bacterial population. In this work, we will develop and apply high-throughput single-cell transcriptomics approaches to profile heterogeneous phenotypic states within complex bacterial communities such as spatially structured biofilms and reduced complexity microbiota. We will use the results to develop systems-level understanding of the fine-scale phenotypic structure and pave the way toward predicting the emergent properties of biofilms and natural microbiota.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tenuous housing relationships with landlords/property managers can increase feelings among tenants that they must move, resulting in a group of tenants to move (i.e. soft displacement), while another group of tenants stay yet continue to feel the pressure that they must move (i.e. potential displacement). Less is known about these two groups of marginalized renters since there is no court ordered eviction notice attached to their displacement; however, data from the parent award and new data gained through qualitative interviews provide the opportunity to do an in-depth investigation of how (soft vs. potential) displacement, economic hardships, psychosocial stressors, and other decision-making processes contribute to mental health disparities. The supplement also provides the opportunity to support two first-generation college graduates to strengthen their research skills and serve as role models for first-generation college students.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: A hallmark feature of many neurodegenerative diseases is an inability of neurons to meet their cellular homeostasis demands due to hindered autophagy activity. I hypothesize that neurons employ an alternate pathway, autophagy-dependent secretion, to offload damaged proteins and dysfunctional organelles when faced with an overwhelmed autophagy system. I propose to define the interplay between autophagy and secretion when neurons are stressed (Aim 1), and to challenge the hypothesis that neurons offload mitochondria for transcellular internalization (Aim 2).

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposal “Guiding the Safe and Effective Integration of Ambient Digital Scribes into Primary Care” outlines a clear strategy for swiftly developing a prototype guide to safely and effectively implement ambient digital scribes into their primary care practices, designed to help healthcare provider organizations of all sizes – ranging from large multi-facility healthcare systems to individual clinics and federally qualified health centers. This work will provide novel insight into how this new transformational AI-driven technology will change the workflow of primary care. Given the prevalence of primary care physician burnout and the inevitable ubiquity of this technology, this guide is a timely approach to addressing safety and equity concerns with implementing ambient digital scribes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Lewy body disorders are associated with the formation of insoluble protein aggregates that may spread from cell to cell, eventually appearing in multiple vulnerable regions of the nervous system. During the intercellular transfer of protein aggregates, innate immune cells residing in the brain may engulf and clear a portion of the aggregates, but this defense mechanism is not sufficient to fully prevent Lewy body disease. To boost this defense, we will determine if engulfment of protein aggregates can be kickstarted with a pharmacologically-induced immune cell depletion and repopulation event.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia, affecting 6.7 million Americans aged 65 and older, and causing a significant public health crisis. The project aims to develop a translational human-mouse neuronal chimeric brain model for studying tau pathology in Alzheimer’s disease. With this model, we will characterize tau pathology, dissect the relationship between the progression of tau pathology in human neurons and cognitive dysfunction, identify dysregulated cellular pathways in human neurons during the progression of tau pathology, and directly compare tau pathology between human and mouse neurons within the same brain environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adulteration of the illicit fentanyl supply with xylazine is rapidly spreading across the country. Xylazine reportedly enhances the euphoric effects of fentanyl, but the combination of the two drugs is also associated with increased risk of cardiorespiratory depression and resistance to standard opioid overdose medications. The goal of this research is to identify new treatments that have the potential to block both the desirable and the harmful effects of fentanyl-xylazine mixtures.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: INTER-AMERICAN INSTITUTE FOR COOPERATION ON AGRICULTURE -IICA
PHR: Project Narrative: With this new cooperative agreement, we intend to build upon the previous activities to help farms and facilities get an accurate message about the Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA) regulations and adopt and implement the Rules that pertain to them. The overall goal is to help exporters in Latin America strengthen their food safety programs in order to export safer food and comply with the United States food safety regulations. IICA has the capacity to implement many outreach and innovative capacity building activities relying on its extensive network of professionals trained under current and previous projects related to FSMA and food safety. IICA can find the most appropriate location/users (specific countries/farms, etc.) for any programs and, as appropriate, align with or consider ongoing and planned training by other organizations as part of the context for this proposal. IICA can work and conduct outreach with government, academia, and the private industry. These capabilities have brought success to the previous two cooperative agreements between FDA and IICA. Through this project, we will use innovative and well- tested approaches, new learning techniques, and robust evaluation to ensure sustainable knowledge building and improved understanding around FSMA implementation and compliance. PROJECT_TITLE: Modernizing, Expanding, and Measuring the Impact of FDA Food Safety Initiatives

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: CFTR modulators are a novel class of therapeutic compounds, and this research will contribute significantly to the understanding of the metabolism of these compounds in patients with cystic fibrosis to optimize therapy and usher in an era of precision therapeutics. The findings will enhance efficacy of CFTR modulator therapy for all patients with cystic fibrosis and help expand these novel therapies to all patients who might benefit from them. The knowledge gained in metabolism enzyme pharmacogenomics also has important implications for other diseases, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pulmonary infections, and asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the most important factors causing inter-individual variations in caries susceptibility and high dental caries prevalence worldwide is the host genetics, which influences the tooth anatomy and tooth hard tissue (enamel and dentin) quality. In our interest to understand host susceptibility to efficiently prevent dental caries, the proposed research will provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying dental caries risk due to dentin developmental defects caused by deficiency of Trps1 transcription factor in odontoblasts, which also leads to impaired enamel quality. The fundamental understanding of critical pathways controlling crosstalk between odontoblasts/ameloblasts will result in opportunities to achieve precision medicine and improve treatment options for diseases that impact dental hard tissue health, such as dental caries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This administrative supplement will expand the URI ESTEEMED program by (1) increasing the size of the annual student cohort augment training activities and (2) strengthening mentor training through the creation of a formal Inclusive Mentor Training Program at URI. The increased cohort size will directly improve trainee outcomes through improved peer-to-peer networking, additional opportunities for near-peer mentoring, and supplemental academic support, while the Inclusive Mentor Training Program will provide sustainable and intensive mentor training with a targeted focus on supporting trainees from diverse and underrepresented backgrounds. With these additional resources, URI ESTEEMED will develop and train a diverse cohort of students with the technical and soft skills necessary to excel in advanced research programs in bioengineering and related fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: The Sars-CoV-2 pandemic presented unprecedented challenges in many areas of healthcare, such as accurately forecasting the need for critical resources linked to public health interventions. This research develops novel multi-task graph constrained machine-learning techniques to jointly predict related resources at the local level, including behavioral information. These methods are developed utilizing data from the RadX projects in West Virginia, combining statewide public health surveillance and hospitalization data, and have generalizability beyond Sars-Cov-2 to other public health crises.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  The human microbiome consists of a dizzying array of bacteria that communicate and compete with one another using a chemical language consisting of secreted secondary metabolites. Among these microbes, Corynebacteria have recently emerged as important skin and upper respiratory tract residents that can cause opportunistic and difficult-to-tread infections, although their secondary metabolomes and how they interact with their environment remains unknown. In this proposal, we will use state-of-the-art methods to characterize the secondary metabolomes of three corynebacterial strains and to elucidate their roles in intra-genus, inter- genus, and inter-kingdom interactions, thus deepening our understanding of these bacteria and contributing to knowledge that can be used to develop therapies against corynebacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE:  The cerebral cortex, where high-level sensory and motor processing, cognition, and integrative behavior occurs, contains thousands of distinct types of specialized nerve cells (neurons) to perform such complex tasks; cortical projection neurons (PN) are the class of “long-distance” neurons carrying information within and away from the cerebral cortex to the spinal cord and other brain structures, enabling cortex function. It is only partially understood how specific genes and molecules control how these neurons normally develop or are affected by abnormal development, degeneration, or dysfunction in human disorders, including ALS, spinal cord injury, Huntington's disease, cerebral palsy, intellectual disability, autism spectrum disorders; this work also has relevance for regeneration and drug development, since current genetic analysis systems have major gaps in their abilities. We propose to develop an innovative and unprecedented synthetic biology system to uniquely investigate function of specific genes in specific domains (“growth cones” and “synapses”) that control building of brain and spinal cord circuitry and proper brain function; this work also has potential for development of innovative and uniquely specific therapeutics for a range of developmental, degenerative, and neuropsychiatric disorders, and toward future central nervous system regeneration for acquired injuries like spinal cord injury.

The NIH Bridges to the Doctorate Training Program at SFSU is a joint project between the Hispanic Serving Master’s institution, San Francisco State University (SFSU), and the pre-eminent PhD granting institution, the University of California San Francisco (UCSF). It prepares a diverse population of master’s students at SFSU to enter into top ranked biomedical Ph.D. degree programs such as UCSF, with the skills to successfully complete their Ph.D. degrees, en route to careers in the biomedical research workforce. The partnership between SFSU and UCSF addresses the need to diversify the scientific research community at the Ph.D. level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVES The proposed study aims to harness advanced natural language processing and longitudinal neural network approaches to build on our previously developed machine-learning prediction algorithms to identify patients at risk for opioid overdose or opioid use disorder. We will develop the prediction tool using all-payer electronic health records (EHR), Medicaid claims, and Medicaid claims linked with EHR data from the One Florida Clinical Research Consortium and translate the risk prediction algorithms into a clinical decision support platform integrated into the EHR system to identify patients at high risk of overdose and opioid use disorder. This innovative and integrated platform will better guide clinical providers and health care systems for improving safety of opioid prescribing in clinical practice, and prevent opioid-associated adverse outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tissue engineered heart valves (TEHVs), which have the potential to self-repair and grow with the patient, are a promising alternative to current valve replacements, especially for pediatric patients; yet TEHVs decellularized prior to implantation to minimize the immune response rely on repopulation of the matrix with host cells to facilitate remodeling of the matrix. The proposed project will determine how the dynamic mechanical environment of the valve regulates the attachment, infiltration, and differentiation of host cells into the TEHV matrix with the goal of optimizing TEHV design for host cell repopulation and adaptive remodeling under complex in vivo conditions. The mentoring activities will support students from marginalized communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small regulatory RNAs are an important but severely understudied class of regulatory molecules in bacterial cells. We propose to create an sRNA mutant library, containing 88 mutants, in the human pathogen Neisseria gonorrhoeae and go on to phenotypically characterize these strains in an effort to identify sRNAs that may represent potential targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oligomeric tau is a key pathogenic species of tau that is believed to drive the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease end related dementias and there is a critical need to develop novel anti-oligomeric tau targeting therapies to treat AD and related dementias. Our objective is to create and assess an innovative immuno-gene therapy method using peripherally deliverable AAV-mediated CNS expression of a single chain variable domain derived from the TOC1 oligomeric tau antibody, which specifically binds to an epitope that relies on conformations induced during tau oligomerization (i.e. dimers and higher multimers, but not filamentous tau). This project will facilitate the initial development and validation of a highly novel anti-oligomeric tau therapy, holding the potential for a significant impact on the treatment of AD and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of the Building Access to Food through Systems and Solidarity (BASIS) Study is to improve diet by providing culturally appropriate food access and attending to drivers that limit the ability to achieve nutrition security in Sunset Park – a community of Mexican and Chinese American families in Brooklyn, NY that has been hard-hit during the COVID-19 pandemic, has lagged in economic recovery, and where residents are disconnected from government supports. We aim to implement and evaluate a whole-of-community intervention that will prioritize sustainability in the long-term, in partnership with four farming/gardening organizations, one elementary school and three community-based organizations with programmatic offerings that will include linkage to federal, state and local aid and workforce development; a subsidized fresh produce box program, gardening and nutrition education; and a social marketing campaign to promote healthy eating. BASIS presents a powerful model to improve diet in immigrant communities by addressing determinants of food access in a community-centered, culturally competent way, and by fortifying community empowerment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: This R21 application, “Serum Exosome Detection and Monitoring of Alcohol-related White Matter Brain Pathology-Opportunities to Optimize Treatment and Monitoring of AUD-Related Organ and Tissue Damage in Diverse Populations” leverages gains from ongoing preclinical studies to logically extend the initial plan by utilizing serum-derived extracellular vesicles (EVs) to non- invasively detect oligodendrocyte-related white matter (WM) degeneration in humans with alcohol-related brain degeneration (ARBD). Banked serum samples from alcohol use disorder (AUD) subjects who participated in longitudinal monitoring or intervention (motivational interview or pharmacologic) trials in which the outcomes are known, will be used to characterize alterations in oligodendrocyte protein, sphingolipid expression, and indices of oxidative stress over time and in relation to disease progression or treatment. The results of this R21-supported research will facilitate a path for future clinical trials to non-invasively monitor progression and treatment responses in patients with AUD and WM ARBD from diverse socioeconomic backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: This work is a mechanistic study of innate and adaptive immune responses in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Having made a novel discovery of autoantibodies against Cyclic G/AMP (cGAMP) synthetase (cGAS) in SLE patients with active disease, we will examine the impact of biophysical changes triggered by cGAS ligand binding on the loss of tolerance to this antigen. This work may help explain why nucleic acid-binding proteins are both autoantigens and drivers of inflammation in SLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The functional units of the kidney, the nephrons, are established during development and do not regenerate later in life resulting in kidney failure after injury, disease, or age with the only cure being kidney transplant. Here we develop an easy-to-use modular 3D model of the developing nephron in which the biophysical and biochemical cues of the ECM, soluble factors, and stromal cell identity can be spatially patterned along the length of an epithelialized tube. This model will be designed such that it can be easily disseminated to the research community to rapidly increase mechanistic investigation of nephrogenesis for biological understanding, pharmacological screening, and tissue engineering applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Erectile Dysfunction is highly prevalent in American men, the severity of which is believed to be due in part to decreased oxygenation of the corpus cavernosum. The current method for measurement of penile oxygenation is through needle aspiration of penile blood, which is impractical for prolonged monitoring purposes due to patient discomfort and potential of further tissue damage. We seek to leverage our team’s recent innovation of a stretchable and flexible photodiode to create a wearable device for prolonged penile oxygen tension measurement that contours to the skin and stretches with movement, which we first seek to optimize and validate in a rodent model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although low-dose computed tomography screening lowers lung cancer death rates, it is widely underused, especially among groups experiencing health inequities. This project will adopt a new method to assess the real-world equity impact and cost-effectiveness of three different lung cancer screening strategies: the United States Preventive Services Task Force guidelines, the American Cancer Society guidelines, and an approach based on a lung cancer risk prediction model. Project results will inform lung cancer screening programs focused on equity, thereby enhancing the availability and utilization of lung cancer screening, especially for communities experiencing health disparities and bearing the greatest risk of lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Microbial imbalances are the basis of several oral and dental diseases and can be studied using high-throughput DNA and RNA sequencing methods. The ZOE 2.0 study investigated early childhood caries (ECC) and collected matched microbial DNA, RNA, and metabolomics data in a community-based sample of 300 3-5-year-old children, creating the largest cohort with this biological information in the oral health domain. We propose to advance our understanding of associations and biological interactions among microbial species and their relationship with ECC. We will accomplish this by identifying regulatory modules across all omics layers by developing a new clustering method. Next, we will leverage these multi-omics data by employing machine learning methods to identify ECC-predictive omics features and ultimately predict ECC status.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A major challenge in modeling human disease in animals is the variability in outcomes among individual animals, especially where disease mortality or morbidity limits downstream analyses of affected organs. We have designed new genetic tools to cause disease on only one side (left or right) of paired visceral organs and limbs, focused here on a proof-of-concept in the lungs using mouse models of viral pneumonia and cancer metastases. Our studies will provide new tools to cause disease and track cells in live mice, laying the groundwork for exciting applications in diverse mouse models spanning respiratory disease, arthritis, cancer, hepatitis and many others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The parent project aims to understand how deaf children build a vocabulary in sign language, and whether and how this differs for deaf children who have limited exposure to a sign language. The goal of the supplement is to 1) increase the PI’s capacity to mentor scientists from diverse backgrounds, 2) create professional development materials for scientists in ASL, and offer training to a deaf postdoctoral researcher.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE In 2019, Hispanic/Latinx individuals were awarded 8.6% of the 187,568 doctoral degrees awarded in the US despite accounting for 18.5% of the US population, and African American graduates were awarded 9.2% of degrees awarded despite accounting for 12.5% of the population, a disparity which drives a lack of diversity among faculty at leading health institutions and in the field of substance use research. There is a need to focus on the necessary first step to increasing diversity in substance use treatment and prevention research: getting college-aged scholars of color who have been underrepresented in academic medicine and public health to attend graduate programs at Research 1 (R1; Carnegie very high research activity designation) institutions where rigorous training will enable independence. The primary innovation of this R25 proposal is its ability to deliberately build a substantial and sustainable pathway between six Hispanic-Serving Institutions and New York University to both identify and enroll exceptional underrepresented undergraduate students into a training program that will provide a pathway to doctoral training in substance use research at R1 institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Developing engagement and policy translation skills of the next generation of rural cancer researchers will prove critical as many rural states experience rising cancer incidence amidst growing prevalence of cancer survivors. Greater access to comprehensive survivorship services could mitigate the growing mortality disparity between rural-urban cancer patients, but rural cancer centers need additional support to deliver such care locally. Leveraging the resources of an innovative cancer center network intervention, we propose to implement an evidence-based survivorship workshop adapted to fit the unique needs of rural communities and explore innovative approaches to disseminate our cancer equity research to rural policymakers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Innovative Mentoring through Professional Advancement and Cultural Training (IMPACT) program is an NIH-funded mentoring program designed to support historically underrepresented students in communication sciences and disorders (CSD). This supplement provides current participating students (undergraduates in CSD and clinical speech-language pathology graduate students) with coaching to help them develop robust professional identities and to develop skills in organization, stress management, time management, and self-sufficiency while adding an online cohort of underrepresented Doctor of Audiology graduate students. The addition of coaching paired with a robust mentoring program will support the retention and success of historically underrepresented groups pursuing clinical and/or research careers in CSD to better serve the growing and diverse population of the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The over-arching theme of this program is to train “comprehensive imaging scientists” in the skills necessary to identify clinically relevant problems and develop techniques to improve the prevention, detection, diagnosis, and treatment of human diseases. Trainees learn the full trajectory of medical imaging, including the application of machine learning methods, and emphasis is placed on experiential learning in clinical environments. The global program outcome is for our students to acquire the skill set needed to improve healthcare through imaging science.

PROJECT_TITLE: Comprehensive Training program in Imaging Science and Informatics

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Accurate chromosome segregation and repair of DNA breaks during sperm and egg development are essential for preventing infertility, miscarriages, birth defects, and cancer. Developing sperm and eggs accomplish this through specific exchanges of DNA, called recombination events. The proposed research will reveal the mechanisms of these recombination events to increase understanding of fundamental processes critical to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study investigates how an immune response to fats contributes to type 2 diabetes. By studying human pancreatic tissue from individuals with and without diabetes, we aim to understand how immune cells damage insulin-producing cells, important for regulating blood sugar. This work will provide new information for development of diabetes treatments and will support underrepresented students in biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative It is common for adults with end stage kidney disease (ESKD) to experience fatigue, at a level that influences whole person health. With the support of a patient advisory board, this project will develop and test a progressive muscle relaxation and walking intervention to reduce fatigue for adults with ESKD. Results will inform the development of a large-scale trial to reduce fatigue and promote whole person health for adults with ESKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ventricles of the human brain are lined with ependymal cells projecting numerous whip-like organelles, called motile cilia, which beat in a coordinated fashion to generate fluid flow. Motile cilia beating in the brain is important for proper development and defects in cilia beating are linked to numerous diseases, including hydrocephalus, scoliosis, intellectual disability, mood disorders, Huntington disease, and epilepsy. We are studying the mechanisms that regulate cilia beating in order to understand the functions of motile cilia and how their dysfunction contributes to neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the first steps in salient signal detection in cortical structures is the profound activation of dis-inhibitory interneurons expressing vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP). In contrast to the current view, we propose that VIP interneurons can be divided into functionally distinct groups. By combining viral techniques, neuroanatomical methods, in vitro and in vivo electrophysiology, we will determine how distinct, genetically defined types of VIP interneurons respond to aversive signal presentation and reward delivery as well as reveal their target selectivity, the critical parameters underlying circuit mechanisms of salient signal processing in cortical structures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE ASH1L regulates chromatin mediated mechanisms of gene expression by counteracting the activity of the polycomb repressor complex 2. The research goal for this administrative supplement is to define the extent to which the ASH1L/PRC2 axis modulates cell fate transitions and cell type specific gene programs in the developing human brain. In addition, we propose to promote DEI by providing research, scientific writing, scientific communication and career development experiences to trainees from underserved populations at multiple levels (high school, undergraduate, post bac and post-graduate).

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Patients with devastating chronic intestinal failure can survive only with parenteral nutrition delivered through an intravenous catheter. This care is very complex and requires expert physicians operating in multi-disciplinary teams. This project investigates whether intestinal failure patient outcomes can be improved by providing patients and their family caregivers education on best practice care through tele-learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goals of our research are to 1) elucidate the mechanistic link between skin microbiota and local immune dysregulation in rosacea skin and 2) elucidate potential systemic immune dysregulation in rosacea patients. Unlike prior studies, we aim to employ multi-omics data integration to 1) explain the complex relationship of the microbial environment and the host immune response in the skin, and 2) characterize the systemic immune dysregulation that can explain the systemic disease burden in rosacea patients. We anticipate that our findings will lead to the development of novel preventative and therapeutic targets and shift the way we study and manage rosacea toward early detection and prevention of systemic co-morbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: We propose to examine potential changes in brain oscillatory patterns in response to an intervention that uses breath-synched vibration during breathing meditation to enhance interoception in dissociative trauma-exposed people. We will investigate how change in these oscillatory patterns may be linked to dissociation change as well. We will assess interoception through self-report as well as via neural network response during an interoceptive functional magnetic resonance imaging task.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective mentorship is a critical component for academic and career development, particularly for trainees underrepresented in the biomedical workforce. The proposed supplement will enhance the program activities of the parent award by providing psychosocial well-being discussions to underrepresented trainees and additional mentor training to provide faculty with practical guidance on how to mitigate racial bias and stereotypes in the context of biomedical research mentorship. These enhancements will impact both the success of our trainees and the long-term, sustained effectiveness of our post-baccalaureate research training program for diversifying the biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will develop the next-generation of high-precision and multiplex base editors to provide an alternative and promising approach for the treatment of human genetic diseases. The advanced base-editing tools will not only greatly benefit the mechanistic study and treatment of cystic fibrosis, an autosomal recessive hereditary disease, but also contribute to other human genetic disorders and fundamental biomedical research.
